“The Social Dilemma” is the first film you'll watch and immediately want to toss your smartphone into the garbage can. And then toss the garbage can through the window of a Facebook executive. It's an eye-opening look into the way social media is designed ... “The Social Dilemma” is the first film you'll watch and immediately want...

“The Social Dilemma” is the first film you'll watch and immediately want to toss your smartphone into the garbage can. And then toss the garbage can through the window of a Facebook executive. It's an eye-opening look into the way social media is designed ...

“The Social Dilemma” is the first film you'll watch and immediately want to toss your smartphone into the garbage can. And then toss the garbage can through the window of a Facebook executive. It's an eye-opening look into the way social media is designed to create addiction and manipulate our behavior, told by some of the very people who supervised the systems at places like Facebook, Google and Twitter. Tim Kendall, a former president of Pinterest, admitted that years ago he couldn’t get off his phone even when he came home, despite having two young kids. “I am going to work during the day and building something that then I’m falling prey to,” he says in the film. “I couldn’t help myself.” The documentary is a well paced, absorbing look at the deep costs of Big Tech — fake news, election security concerns, radicalization, polarization and much more. Only in trying to dramatize those costs does it slip up badly. Director Jeff Orlowski interviews former tech execs, historians and social scientists but apparently doesn't trust them enough to tell the story. So he also employs a gimmicky family of five actors — two parents, three teens — to dramatize the lure of social media in a clunky way. Worse, he also employs an actor — a weirdly cast Vincent Kartheiser of “Mad Men” fame — to pretend to act like the computer software, sending alluring phone alerts from a console to one of the teens and cuing up videos he knows will be clickbait, while ominous music plays. “Yes, perfect,” Kartheiser purrs after sending a video of epic skateboard fails to the teen. “He’s primed for an ad!" Later: “Don't show him any more sports updates. He doesn't engage.” But we know — from the very talking heads — that this is an algorithm with no agency other than its program. Why humanize code? And why humanize code by portraying it as a sleazy middle-aged man who acts like a mid-level officer in “Minority Report”? The film then steps on itself. When one of the fake teens falls for a fake online conspiracy and attends a fake demonstration, it's juxtaposed against real footage of real violence and real demonstrations, muddying the water between fake and real — a terrible decision given what this film is about. Orlowski would have done better interviewing real teens buffeted by social media and real people caught up in conspiracies. Insulting our intelligence about artificial intelligence is not the way to go. The silly dramatizations mar an otherwise excellent documentary that shows how so many Silicon Valley leaders designed ways to keep us engaged online and that led to such things as Pizzagate, international destabilization,higher suicide rates in young people and a boom in depression. The film reveals much more than why you go from Googling the best sofa one minute to finding sofa ads on your Facebook stream the next. That so much online seems free is part of the trap: It's our private data that's being sold. As Aza Raskin, former Firefox and Mozilla Lab worker says: “Advertisers are the customers. We’re the thing being sold.” The film nicely delves into how algorithms that seek to maximize advertising revenue tap into psychology to keep us addicted to our screens. Did a friend just tag me? I got an alert! Hey, Facebook just invited me to an event. Those are all “positive intermittent reinforcements” and they keep us checking our phone for more, like a gambler hoping for a windfall at a Vegas slot machine. Whether or not these techniques were actively employed, stumbled upon or just a byproduct of a user-engagement model is a little murky. The film offers all sides as to whether software makers consciously exploit human vulnerabilities: The guy who helped create the “like” button for Facebook says he wanted to spread love in the world but a former Facebook executive admits purposely creating dopamine-driven feedback loops. If there is a hero here it is portrayed by Tristan Harris, an ex-Google executive who is now co-founder of the Center for Humane Technology and who hopes to change the system. He and critics like Jaron Lanier, author of “Ten Arguments for Deleting Your Social Media Accounts Right Now,” explain what the possible consequences are if we continue using our individual digital pacifiers — lots of cat videos, yes, and also civil war. Stick around after the film is over to hear lots of recommendations from former tech leaders who built the mess we're in: They turn off their notifications. They delete many apps. They urge regulation. They don't let their kids use social media. Think about that. “The Social Dilemma,” a Netflix release, is rated PG-13 for some thematic elements, disturbing/violent images and suggestive material. Running time: 94 minutes. Two and a half stars out of four. ___ MPAA Definition of PG-13: Parents strongly cautioned. Some material may be inappropriate for children under 13. ___ Online: https://www.netflix.com/title/81254224

urn:contentItem:5RWV-R771-JCB8-W02D-00000-00Review: Rescuing humanity from big tech;Can humanity be spared in big-tech world?2018-03-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisFfeaturesfeatures/arts and travelfeatures/book reviewsPg. 4Review: Rescuing humanity from big techCan humanity be spared in big-tech world?Katie Hafner Special To The Washington Post ;

HOW TO FIX THE FUTURE. By Andrew Keen. Atlantic. 330 pages. $26.

Over the past decade or so, books decrying the internet have been published at a steady clip. These what-have-we-wrought manifestos - Evgeny Morozov's "The Net Delusion," Jaron Lanier's "You Are Not a Gadget," Nicholas Carr's "The Shallows," to name but a few - are a chorus line of King Canutes yelling, largely in vain, against the incoming tide of insidious data mining, surveillance economies, endangered jobs and smartphone addiction.

The latest volume to wash up on the rocky shores of doubt is "How to Fix the Future" by Andrew Keen, an entrepreneur turned technology pundit. Published close on the heels of his 2015 curmudgeonly treatise, "The Internet Is Not the Answer," Keen's new book is far less grumpy, as the author trains his lens on tools he believes can help correct our course.

The title is a bit off. Forget the future. The book is a courageous attempt to offer some constructive solutions to a world already filled with monoliths that make the Microsoft of the 1990s, whose hegemony we once feared so much that the government saw fit to break it into pieces, look like a humble Etsy vendor.

Keen is mercifully brief with his indictments of big tech.

Just in case you need it, a quick refresher: Uber isn't merely exploiting its drivers but working overtime to render them unnecessary. Amazon (whose founder, Jeff Bezos, owns The Washington Post) has tentacles in pretty much everything, including health care and education. Apple's iPhone is turning us all into zombies. Facebook, conduit of fake news, is a crime scene. And just try to go 15 minutes without using something of Google's.

So what do we do? Keen asks, reasonably enough.

Keen offers a five-part solution, consisting of greater consumer choice, social responsibility, competitive innovation, smart regulation and enlightened education. At the center, not surprisingly, is humanity itself.

In his search for the humans who are playing key roles in preserving the fundamentals of a civilized society, Keen does something admirable: He hits the road, interviewing dozens of folks around the world who are doing, and saying, interesting, innovative things.

He visits the chief technology officer of Estonia, the first country in the world to offer "e-residency," an electronic passport that allows any small-business owner to use a variety of Estonian services and technologies. Intended as an antithesis to the "dark web," the country is reimagining cyberspace as civic space, Keen reports.

Then there's Singapore, one of the most wired countries on the planet, where Keen explores the Smart Nation initiative, whose goal, as its politicians would have us believe, is to reinvent Singapore so that digitized information becomes the foundation of a new public space for civic innovation.

Writes Keen, "The plan is to erect an electronic mirror that will enable (Singapore) to become ever more self aware."

So rosy is Keen's tone in parts that I was put in mind of a wide-eyed, if craggy-faced, 21st-century Dorothy, picking up valuable lessons on her way to Oz.

It was when Keen got to Singapore that I began to wonder if he might be looking for solutions in the wrong places. Singapore? I mean, I'd like to see cleaner sidewalks as much as the next San Franciscan, but doesn't Singapore take things a tad too far?

As Keen himself points out, human and free-speech rights champions, to say nothing of privacy advocates, aren't whistling Dixie with their worries over what Singapore might have in mind with its deployment of sensors and cameras across the island.

And the notion of e-citizenry, while fascinating, seems of questionable applicability to the United States.

Still, I came away from Keen's world travels grateful to him for enduring all those endless flights to far-flung places so we wouldn't have to.

Keen's trip to Brussels makes more sense. There he meets with Margrethe Vestager, the European commissioner for competition, who is bravely standing up to the likes of Google and Apple. Vestager imposed a 13 billion-euro fine on Apple in back taxes for the company's dodgy tax arrangements with Ireland. And she has set her antitrust sights on Google. Last year, she fined the company a record 2.42 billion euros for giving preferential treatment to Google Shopping, its price comparison service.

"How to Fix the Future" has its share of annoyances. The phrase "you'll remember," to remind us of someone or something he has mentioned plenty of times already, sometimes quite recently, becomes a distracting literary tic.

And there are mistakes. Some are easily forgiven. I can see getting Angela Merkel's name wrong (which Keen does); after all, the German prime minister isn't a constant presence in Keen's Silicon Valley-centric world. But misspelling the first names of Sergey Brin and Marc Benioff is just plain inexcusable. And an internet expert like Keen should know that science fiction writer William Gibson coined the word "cyberspace" not in his 1984 novel, "Neuromancer," but two years earlier in his short story "Burning Chrome."

Eventually our Dorothy returns to Kansas, which in Keen's case is his own backyard of Oakland, Calif. He describes with great admiration work being done by Freada Kapor Klein, a longtime tech activist. Together with her husband, Mitch Kapor, she has created a workspace in Oakland that blends high tech with humanism. Working to ensure that everyone gets a chance at a tech career, the couple invests in start-ups whose founders are women or people of color, and they've started a program that funnels underprivileged kids into math and science.

All of this, as Keen puts it, is a "counterweight to Silicon Valley's most corrosive indifference to the impact of its disruption on the world around it." Well put, and a brave ambition for a scary new world.

Katie Hafner is a journalist and author.

"How to Fix the Future" by Andrew Keen

Atlantic

urn:contentItem:3X4K-BDF0-00MP-T33C-00000-00Reviews Are in on Cramer Speech1998-06-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisCOMMENTARY; Email to the EditorsReviews Are in on Cramer SpeechByJune 15, 1998 5:32 PM ET

TheStreet.com publishes selected email received by the publication and its staff members. To send an email intended for publication in this section, email scientific approach to trading. Cramer, however, seems to prefer military history. His columns are replete with references to such well-known traders as Robert E. Lee and Erich Ludendorff. I can imagine Cramer humming martial tunes as he orders his funds into battle. When he feels Napoleonic, there's always La Marseillaise. (When he wants to be Hannibal, he'd have to make up his songs from the Punic Wars.) Perhaps you should include history in the trading curriculum. The battlefields may differ, but the tactics may be the same. 

-- Eugene Finerman (received 6/15/98) Dismal Business 

Dunlap's departure brings to mind the Buffett observation that when a guy with a reputation for excellence goes into a dismal business, it's the reputation of the business that survives. 

-- George Acton (received 6/15/98) Speech Reviews 

James Cramer: Just wanted to say, thanks for sharing the history and future strategy. 

-- Matt Bayly (received 6/15/98) 

James Cramer: Needless to say I'm glad, to say the least, that you let TSC live. I will only be able to retire at a reasonable age if I invest. To learn that I joined TSC. Thanks Jim, Dave Kansas, and the whole crew for the education. 

-- Thomas J. Reich (received 6/14/98) 

James Cramer: I am so happy you decided to continue with TSC. If I had known you were thinking about quitting, I would have gotten on a plane, flown there and tried to talk you out of it. 

-- Jeanne Merchant (received 6/14/98) 

James Cramer: Your one weakness is charging monthly subscription rates. Once you are comfortably above break even, the monthly rate should go to $0 or at least go down significantly. The number of subscribers will mushroom. 

-- George Seay (received 6/14/98) 

James Cramer: It was interesting and refreshing to read the "story" of TheStreet.com and understand your vision for the site. As a new "Home Depot do-it-yourself" investor I look to the site for daily information, direction, and insight to help me make informed financial decisions. While it is important for people to understand your vision, admiration, and zest to make TheStreet.com the absolute best source for market and financial information I think it is more important for those sentiments to be echoed by your readers and for that I say kudos! 

-- Matthew Shapiro (received 6/14/98) Axing the Chainsaw 

James Cramer: You were smart to unload Sunbeam. I think Michael Price wishes he had unloaded Al Dunlap sooner. Dunlap represents the dark side of American business. It takes no particular talent to take over the management of a business, fire half the payroll to produce a couple of good quarters and leave the business smoldering in your wake while you take off to "turn around" another company. 

-- Mark W. Zabell (received 6/15/98) Spots Be Gone 

Jesse Eisinger: Interesting story on Dusa. I had the kerotosis on the backs of both hands. At the doctor's office, they zapped each spot with each with a spray of liquid nitrogen. Just an instant of pain, like a pin prick. No further pain, quick healing, no scarring. Good luck Dusa. 

-- Jeffrey Warren (received 6/14/98) The Bottom 

James Cramer: In your recent column, you mentioned you have a way of spotting the bottom in a stock. Since many of us are trying to identify the bottom in many of our favorite stocks, how about a column detailing your methodology. You could frame it around some past experiences. 

-- Jonathan Daws (received 6/12/98) Eyes Peeled 

James Cramer: Thanks for your honest appraisal of Rowan and the oil services in general. I am currently long NE and have been keeping me eyes peeled for comments from you on the subject. I certainly value your opinion and this oil correction has been a real learing experience for me. I am not a trader (obviously), but I also hate loosing money. Your insight in this area has been quite helpful and look forward to your ongoing commentary. No flames from me. 

-- Brian Fryar (received 6/12/98) Nicely Adjusted 

James Cramer: I think your columns this week have been nicely adjusted to state not only that value matters, but also to give specific company examples. 

Almost everyone at my office uses the "it has gone down, now it must go up" method and then they give themselves a pat on the back for doing so much research. 

If we have a long bear, they will all leave, muttering that the market is not to be trusted. Will the 1980 attitude then prevail all over again? 

-- Bob Morgen (received 6/12/98) Giving Up Hope 

James Cramer: Your comparison of Techs to oil drillers was an eye opening slap in the face. And in my case it was probably a much needed slap in the face. I'm a big tech fan (tech investing has been so good to me over the past two years), but as your column pointed out to me -- my trading lately has been based more on hope then on strategy and discipline. 

Thanks for getting me pointed in the right direction again. 

-- Jason Winfrey (received 6/11/98) Good Advice 

Gary B. Smith: Your GBS Training System column was the best online trading advice I've read. Period. 

I'm a retired musician, and unfortunately, not a math whiz, so when I tackle projects like writing spreadsheets, writing/running backtests, keeping paper-trading portfolios for bottom-fishing/shorting data, keeping a trading diary, etc....it's out of the greatest reluctance that I begin these daunting chores, let alone maintain them… 

But you're darn right......the "zen" is bunk, and I *intuitively* KNEW that....I just never wanted to admit it to myself, because......hey......If I could just guess "up" or "down" right, and get "in sync" with the psychology, and be a "contrarian" trader, and blah, blah, blah.....BALONEY!!! 

I've been at this for longer than I care to admit, and your article really has me soul searching...… 

I really hope you'll concentrate on this theme Gary, and develop the idea with guys like me in mind........even if it's nothing more than a step by step glimpse of how you came by the conclusion to "buy at market" at the open, instead of gap-open techniques with limit orders… (Did you keep records of the actual fill, vs a paper trade fill and backtest it?) And do you trade on days that open down like today ? with trend or against ? 

You know, the works ! All the details.....not necessarily to copy, but to inspire innovation. 

I don't know *anyone* else that's doing this; to the contrary, most "trading" sights are strictly "wing and a prayer" outfits, where the "main guy" makes a trade recommendation, and all the unfortunates within his earshot, bid up his _already-filled_ order, getting at least ONE person out with a profit. (I wish I had a nickel for every one of these I've seen.....GAH!) 

Your column is terrific, and I hope you have the editorial freedom to go so far as to suggest that we collectively get off our bums, fire the newsletter/website/cnbc/aol gurus, start converting our mistakes to data that we can learn from, like you seem to have done. 

-- Dick London (received 6/11/98) The Intel Probe 

James Cramer: First, let me say that I strongly agree with you regarding the undue influence of lawyers, and other non-productive varmints, especially as it relates to distractions for companies like Intel. Second, I agree that Intel is a great company, and they have made me a lot of money through the years, and I love their products and the speed with which they evolve. 

However, I must respectfully disagree with you that there is absolutely no anti-trust issue with respect to Intel. Sadly, they have been guilty of some tactics similar to those of MSFT in recent times since they have controlled the PC hardware. For example, they were requiring that if a PC vendor wanted to have early system design info for each new generation of microprocessor chip, they had to use Intel motherboards (not ONLY microprocessors) in their first generation machines. Now, if there had been a reasonable alternative source of microprocessors, this might have been reasonable, but, of course, they had a functional monopoly. In an industry that moves as fast as the PC business, this of course meant that ALL first versions of a particular generation were on Intel motherboards, thereby precluding innovation by the PC vendor themselves. Or, if a vendor tried to go it alone, they would not be able to have a competitive product available during the critical first months of a new generation, which would have been tantamount to commercial suicide. 

There are other examples, as well--things such as Intel customers suddenly suffering parts shortages should they agree to use chips from an Intel competitor. 

Having said all this, I actually feel that this current investigation is probably good for INTC. At the very least,it will cause them to reassess their business practices, and (if they are still doing this sort of stuff) change in ways that are better for us, their customers. Given that Messrs. Barrett et al. are much less likely to take the arrogant approach of Mr. Softee, I would not be surprised to see a reasonable settlement that will be an obvious winner for everyone. 

-- Dave Kisker (received 6/11/98) Leave the Crash Helmet 

The waves of "impending crash" caveats that accompany just about every discussion of the U.S. stockmarket caused me to recall a sage's advice that, "the market always does what the fewest people expect". Well, there are certainly many people who expect a crash, but there are also a lot of people who believe the market is headed much higher. Is there another scenario that might be developing? I believe so. 

First, lets think about the economic background that investors face. The Asian economies have yet to find a bottom. Several of our telecom equipment analysts have indicated that the companies they follow should report in line second quarter results, but that companies that distribute to Asia (the manufacturer's customers) are experiencing large increases in inventory. Result: channel stuffing will enable many companies to hit June quarter forecasts, but second half forecasts will come down. If this is true, it explains why it seems that there have been a manageable number of pre-releases this quarter. Nonetheless, the conference calls may be a different matter. Conclusion: Domestic U.S. economic growth is unlikely to accelerate and should begin to slow as the year progresses. If so, inflation will be very low and with it, bond yields will decline. 

If the market does what the fewest expect, what could this scenario mean for investors? 

1. Continued high valuations (P/E, Price/Book, etc.). This will drive the valuation crowd crazy. Investors will scramble for anything with growth among a diminishing list of growth companies. This view helps explain the high valuations of internet stocks --- at least they have growth. 

2. Volatile individual stock prices. These high valuations will cause companies that disappoint to be slaughtered because confidence in future growth will be shaken (and investors will move quickly to the next hot growth story). 

3. Slowing growth, high valuations and periodic blowups will depress the typical investor's annual returns into the mid-single digits. Few individuals or money managers will be able to sprint through an investment landscape increasingly littered with landmines. 

4. Low bond yields will cause total returns from fixed income instruments to be less than 6%. Although the long bond might have a bit of price upside as yields drift toward 5%, total returns elsewhere along the yield curve won't provide double digit returns. 

Bottom line: Investors may get neither mid-teens returns nor a crash that enables them to buy on the dip. Instead, we may be headed for a several quarter period of sluggish performance as valuations gradually come back to more normal levels. As a old consumer goods analyst, this is exactly how large cap consumer stocks behave --- a few to several years of outstanding performance, followed not by a crash, but by flat line price performance as valuations catch up (take a look at KO in the late 1980's/early 1990's, or WMT more recently). 

-- Richard Davis Jr. (received 6/11/98) Hayden's an Asset 

An asset allocator is a welcome addition to TheStreet.com. I'd like to see a debate between Cramer and Vern Hayden on whether asset allocation maximizes returns or guarantees mediocrity. 

-- Roger Mann (received 6/10/98) Rewarded 

The only people who have been rewarded by the R.S. Contrarian Fund are those of us who were smart enough to get out last October when it was first nominated for the fund graveyard. Thanks TSC. Paul Stephens doesn't have a clue!!! 

-- Jim Puffer (received 6/9/98) Y2K, Revisited 

The article on E*Trade and Y2K is very interesting, but not necessarily accurate. Many non-legacy systems, built in the past couple of years, are still non-Y2K compliant. I know first hand of one bank in the Northeast, which shall remain nameless, that contract to have a new system built to keep track of its trading. They engage a consulting firm, which built the system totally with 2-digit dates. 

Webtrends 3.5, a program that I use to analyze my web site, is not Y2K compliant. This is not only not a legacy system, it is very recent and totally Internet oriented 

This is not to say that E*Trade is not Y2K compliant, I'm simply pointing out that just because it is "Internet" and "recent" doesn't make it Y2K compliant. Given the legacy systems it must interface with, they could very easily have Y2K issues. The article doesn't mention any statements from the company about Y2K. 

Overall, the securities industry is far ahead of just about any other industry in terms of awareness and progress. The initial SIA testing is scheduled for this July, and their testing methodology is available on the Internet. 

-- Jeff Jacobs (received 6/9/98) Perplexed 

I am still perplexed by Jim Cramer's characterization of his stock positions as "inventory". As near as I can ascertain, Cramer has long term opinions about the unfolding relative improvement of certain large companies. He believes that on a short term basis the markets in those stocks reach technically diifficult to sustain short term levels of excess enthusiasm or revulsion. His trading, therefore, is broadly "fading" the public order flow. 

This is not, however, what I think of as securities "inventory", which is the raw material of a truly market-making function, or the by-product of the distribution of new issues. 

In my experience, one of the most dangerous situations a trader can find himself in is confusing speculation with a market-making discipline. It often leads to a two sets of books mentality where the interim losses are consigned to a mental investment account and the mental market-making account feels great. 

Mr. Cramer's frenetic trading may be wonderfully cathartic for his hedge fund's senior partner; but one wonders at the end of the day, how much does it add to the performance of the firm's underlying, and presumably carefully formulated bets? Is it in large part grist for the insatiable moloch of Wall Street entertainment against a twice daily TheStreet deadline? 

-- Paul J. Isaac (received 6/8/98) The Ax 

Eric Moskowitz: Good series of articles on the various axes' on the Street. However, it is at times difficult to keep an eye out for comments from these analysts on a daily basis when the news agencies that report analysts upgrades/downgrades don't identify the analysts as "axes". Therefore, how about you guys putting out a "The Axe Has Spoken" column as soon as one of these analysts makes a change in recommendation. 

-- Brett Rule (received 6/5/98) New Fan 

Herb Greenberg: Regarding the recent discussion in your column about comments directed at JJC, I offer my 2 cents. First, I began reading TSC because of JJC. I subscribed for a year (and will continue for long after that, I suppose) because of JJC. I try to read everything he writes, whether in TSC or other venues. I have learned more from him about trading than could be bought at any price at any of this country's best b-schools. I am obviously an ardent fan of his. 

That said, I am also becoming an ardent fan of yours since your arrival at TSC. Perhaps it is the lawyer in me, but I like seeing the issues from "both sides of the street." It allows one to keep a clearer head, and that is what the entire exercise of TSC should be about. The "sniping" is taken for what it is: the good-natured ribbing of JJC from one who also admires his work and personna, while making valid points in disagreement. As I've said to you before, keep up the good work. 

-- Bill Luttrell (received 6/5/98) More Helpful 

Herb Greenberg: If you stop offering your perspective on the market, I'll cancel. Although I respect JJC, and his views re trading etc. are interesting, your columns are much more helpful in my effort to understand this market as an investor. So much noise and confusion out there! What we need is wisdom and perspective on things. That's why I read your columns and that's why I'm still a subscriber to TSC. 

-- Tim Mikkel (received 6/5/98) Fore 

James Cramer: When people hassle you about [a recent column on] Dell here is another analogy that my explain your bullishness. 

The four best golfers at a private club are Mr. Dell, Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP. They always shoot in the 70's with Mr. Dell usually shooting a couple of strokes better than the rest. There are lots of other members at the club but while being good players, they can't really compete with the big four. The club they belong to is know as an easy course(wide fairways, flat greens, few trees and sand traps). It is easy to score well. This course is the equivalent of the PC industry of the last couple of years, growth being so rapid everyone makes money. 

The big four decide to go on a golf vacation. By some miracle they are able to play Augusta National. Augusta National is the golf equivalent of today's PC environment "HELL". Needless to say Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP are completely overmatched by the course and shoot horrible scores. Mr. Dell sucks it up and scrambles his way to to another sub 80 round. Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP put on a brave face and say they are going to head to the driving range to make a few adjustments in their game. Things will be better tomorrow. 

The fundamental difference between Mr. Dell and the others(Mr IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP) is that Mr. Dell can adjust to the rapidly changing environment as the environment changes. Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP get annihilated by a change in the environment, go back home reflect on what happened, develop a plan to adapt, put the plan into action and hope things will be better tomorrow. They will always be killed by a negative change in the environment(hard courses) and do well when the environment turns positive(easy courses). 

The morale of the story is that Mr Dell is a better golfer and if your going to bet on Golf then bet on Mr Dell. CREAMer always rises to the top. 

-- Mike Yaffe (received 6/5/98) Kudos 

Herb Greenberg: I don't understand people who don't "get it". I think the ongoing debate between the you [and James Cramer] is one of the things that make TSC an interesting forum. I, for one, am sick and tired of all the whiners who expect this to be a promtional site that has nothing but "buys" and positive spin. Tell them to put on their rose-coloured sunglasses and spend more time at www.justhypeme.com , otherwise known as Silicon Investor. As a paying customer, I would rather see fewer articles written for newbies - your sophistication and expertise is what adds value. 

-- A. John Carlesso (received 6/5/98) Remember the Akron 

Jim Cramer: Enjoy your writing, your comments have made money for me. Thanks, and here is my favorite mental image of trading psychology. Have you ever seen the newsreel clips of the 1920's US Airship Akron disaster? The scene is like traders' thinking about when to take the loss or hold on. The airship was met by a party of about a hundred ground handlers grabbing the ropes when a sudden wind gust and loss of ballast control caused the ship to bob up and down twenty, thirty, forty feet three or four times before rapidly climbing to a thousand feet unable to descend and then crashing within the half hour. There was a rain of falling men from different heights. When does the trader take his loss? Like the ground handler he has to decide if he lets go for a 20 feet fall to suffer a broken leg or hold on for a litte longer until the ship gets back to only to only a 5 foot hop down. One could even hope to get back down uninjured. But then what if the ship just continues up and up… This happened to the ones who didn't let go before it was too late. However, one man did survive by hanging even to a thousand feet holding on for dear life and walked away from the crash landing. 

-- Sanford Friedrich (received 6/5/98) Trust 

James Cramer: I welcomed the wisdom you shared yesterday, it helped put things in perspective and clearly you were right until the market got sand-bagged by the Intel whiff. You are on the money though, the trust level is down - I think that's what I was trying to articulate in my mail yesterday. Why should a trader trust a market that constantly deflates and then only partially re-inflates the next day? Clearly, for a newbie like me it's hard to see why one should - how many times do you need to get your hands burnt before you stop after all? 

Perhaps that's the most frightening thing about the market - the general feeling appears to be falling to short sentiment, which is something I haven't had much experience dealing with (I did send mail to Smith a few weeks ago to go over it since I suspected we would end up in this sort of market sometime - didn't think it would be this quick though). Here we now have people using the chats on the Net to try to move stocks down, not up - perhaps the strongest evidence I've felt that the nature of the game is changing. I sure hope I'm wrong, since this is a game that I really don't look forward to playing in. 

-- Bryan McCormick (received 6/5/98) What Intel Didn't Say 

With everything INTC has already said about business slacking off, coupled with another wave of price cuts, does Intel really need to issue another statement saying its profits/revenue/growth won't be what people thought? 

-- Erik Milstone (received 6/4/98) Turning the Tables 

Since Mr. Cramer has been on CNBC so much, I would like to see him turn the tables and invite Mark Haines to show up for Mr. Cramer's new show, Real Money. Thanks for all the good work. 

-- Tom Delosso (received 6/4/98) Instructive 

James Cramer: I read everything you publish on TS.com and the articles that are most instructive (to me) are the "I Can Screw Up Too" ones where you describe and analyze your mistakes. I too evaluate my mistakes from every angle with the intention of learning how to avoid making the same mistake twice. Please keep it up. 

-- Jerry Daughan, Harpswell, Maine (received 6/4/98) Stretched 

James Cramer: Your arguments seem more stretched by the day. For some reason you don't want to acknowledge that there is a huge slowdown at the semiconductor and boxmaker level. Dell, GTW, may be good trades, but it's ludicrous to suggest that the fundamentals are improving. 

-- Steve Vita (received 6/4/98) No Reply 

Dan Colarusso: I have filed several e-mail type complaints with the NASDR office and the SEC enforcement-tips office over the past few months when I have seen "blatant" volume-spike options trading in calls or puts where there was no news, AND then after hours that company will come out with dramatic 'material' information which causes massive trading in the underlying stock the following morning-open. Some of these instances are so damm obvious that (you or I) figure that the regulators should have been able to see it, also. Most of the time, I never hear back from them. 

-- Gerald E. Naugle, Boulder, Colo. (received 6/4/98) Hear! Hear! 

As regards JJC's motion to start a "conference cancellation watch" on TSC, here's a second. 

-- Tom Scott (received 6/3/98) Terrific 

Gary Smith: Every time I read one of your columns I get ready to fire up the email to tell you how terrific I think your pieces are -- informative, motivating, and written with a style and dynamic (i.e., the way the words move you along) that remind me how excited I used to get when I got a sentence or paragraph right when I was writing a newsletter a number of years ago. This time I'm going to carry through and send this off. TheStreet.com is one of my favorite web sites and you're a big part of the reason. Thanks. 

-- Alan Kaplan (received 6/1/98)

urn:contentItem:3XRV-0CF0-00MP-T1J6-00000-00Reviews Are in on Cramer Speech1998-06-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITY; Email to the EditorsReviews Are in on Cramer SpeechByJune 16, 1998 10:34 AM ET

TheStreet.com publishes selected email received by the publication and its staff members. To send an email intended for publication in this section, email buy and holders. I am a 25-year-old equities trader at a midsize limited partnership and the next best source of knowledge away from the desk is your writing. Your daily synopsis of what you see going on helps me more than any news channel or site. 

-- Ed McCabe (received 6/16/98) Too Much Support? 

James Cramer: It seems to me that support levels and trend lines are meant to be broken. Dell, Costco, Safeway, AOL, Lucent are all leaders and are all under attack daily, yet they haven't cracked their support levels. Until they do and the towel is thrown into the ring, will we really have the capitulation that is so often talked about? 

-- Frank Degley (received 6/16/98) Battling the Market 

Gary B. Smith, I can certainly appreciate the scientific approach to trading. Cramer, however, seems to prefer military history. His columns are replete with references to such well-known traders as Robert E. Lee and Erich Ludendorff. I can imagine Cramer humming martial tunes as he orders his funds into battle. When he feels Napoleonic, there's always La Marseillaise. (When he wants to be Hannibal, he'd have to make up his songs from the Punic Wars.) Perhaps you should include history in the trading curriculum. The battlefields may differ, but the tactics may be the same. 

-- Eugene Finerman (received 6/15/98) Dismal Business 

Dunlap's departure brings to mind the Buffett observation that when a guy with a reputation for excellence goes into a dismal business, it's the reputation of the business that survives. 

-- George Acton (received 6/15/98) Speech Reviews 

James Cramer: Just wanted to say, thanks for sharing the history and future strategy. 

-- Matt Bayly (received 6/15/98) 

James Cramer: Needless to say I'm glad, to say the least, that you let TSC live. I will only be able to retire at a reasonable age if I invest. To learn that I joined TSC. Thanks Jim, Dave Kansas, and the whole crew for the education. 

-- Thomas J. Reich (received 6/14/98) 

James Cramer: I am so happy you decided to continue with TSC. If I had known you were thinking about quitting, I would have gotten on a plane, flown there and tried to talk you out of it. 

-- Jeanne Merchant (received 6/14/98) 

James Cramer: Your one weakness is charging monthly subscription rates. Once you are comfortably above break even, the monthly rate should go to $0 or at least go down significantly. The number of subscribers will mushroom. 

-- George Seay (received 6/14/98) 

James Cramer: It was interesting and refreshing to read the "story" of TheStreet.com and understand your vision for the site. As a new "Home Depot do-it-yourself" investor I look to the site for daily information, direction, and insight to help me make informed financial decisions. While it is important for people to understand your vision, admiration, and zest to make TheStreet.com the absolute best source for market and financial information I think it is more important for those sentiments to be echoed by your readers and for that I say kudos! 

-- Matthew Shapiro (received 6/14/98) Axing the Chainsaw 

James Cramer: You were smart to unload Sunbeam. I think Michael Price wishes he had unloaded Al Dunlap sooner. Dunlap represents the dark side of American business. It takes no particular talent to take over the management of a business, fire half the payroll to produce a couple of good quarters and leave the business smoldering in your wake while you take off to "turn around" another company. 

-- Mark W. Zabell (received 6/15/98) Spots Be Gone 

Jesse Eisinger: Interesting story on Dusa. I had the kerotosis on the backs of both hands. At the doctor's office, they zapped each spot with each with a spray of liquid nitrogen. Just an instant of pain, like a pin prick. No further pain, quick healing, no scarring. Good luck Dusa. 

-- Jeffrey Warren (received 6/14/98) The Bottom 

James Cramer: In your recent column, you mentioned you have a way of spotting the bottom in a stock. Since many of us are trying to identify the bottom in many of our favorite stocks, how about a column detailing your methodology. You could frame it around some past experiences. 

-- Jonathan Daws (received 6/12/98) Eyes Peeled 

James Cramer: Thanks for your honest appraisal of Rowan and the oil services in general. I am currently long NE and have been keeping me eyes peeled for comments from you on the subject. I certainly value your opinion and this oil correction has been a real learing experience for me. I am not a trader (obviously), but I also hate loosing money. Your insight in this area has been quite helpful and look forward to your ongoing commentary. No flames from me. 

-- Brian Fryar (received 6/12/98) Nicely Adjusted 

James Cramer: I think your columns this week have been nicely adjusted to state not only that value matters, but also to give specific company examples. 

Almost everyone at my office uses the "it has gone down, now it must go up" method and then they give themselves a pat on the back for doing so much research. 

If we have a long bear, they will all leave, muttering that the market is not to be trusted. Will the 1980 attitude then prevail all over again? 

-- Bob Morgen (received 6/12/98) Giving Up Hope 

James Cramer: Your comparison of Techs to oil drillers was an eye opening slap in the face. And in my case it was probably a much needed slap in the face. I'm a big tech fan (tech investing has been so good to me over the past two years), but as your column pointed out to me -- my trading lately has been based more on hope then on strategy and discipline. 

Thanks for getting me pointed in the right direction again. 

-- Jason Winfrey (received 6/11/98) Good Advice 

Gary B. Smith: Your GBS Training System column was the best online trading advice I've read. Period. 

I'm a retired musician, and unfortunately, not a math whiz, so when I tackle projects like writing spreadsheets, writing/running backtests, keeping paper-trading portfolios for bottom-fishing/shorting data, keeping a trading diary, etc....it's out of the greatest reluctance that I begin these daunting chores, let alone maintain them… 

But you're darn right......the "zen" is bunk, and I *intuitively* KNEW that....I just never wanted to admit it to myself, because......hey......If I could just guess "up" or "down" right, and get "in sync" with the psychology, and be a "contrarian" trader, and blah, blah, blah.....BALONEY!!! 

I've been at this for longer than I care to admit, and your article really has me soul searching...… 

I really hope you'll concentrate on this theme Gary, and develop the idea with guys like me in mind........even if it's nothing more than a step by step glimpse of how you came by the conclusion to "buy at market" at the open, instead of gap-open techniques with limit orders… (Did you keep records of the actual fill, vs a paper trade fill and backtest it?) And do you trade on days that open down like today ? with trend or against ? 

You know, the works ! All the details.....not necessarily to copy, but to inspire innovation. 

I don't know *anyone* else that's doing this; to the contrary, most "trading" sights are strictly "wing and a prayer" outfits, where the "main guy" makes a trade recommendation, and all the unfortunates within his earshot, bid up his _already-filled_ order, getting at least ONE person out with a profit. (I wish I had a nickel for every one of these I've seen.....GAH!) 

Your column is terrific, and I hope you have the editorial freedom to go so far as to suggest that we collectively get off our bums, fire the newsletter/website/cnbc/aol gurus, start converting our mistakes to data that we can learn from, like you seem to have done. 

-- Dick London (received 6/11/98) The Intel Probe 

James Cramer: First, let me say that I strongly agree with you regarding the undue influence of lawyers, and other non-productive varmints, especially as it relates to distractions for companies like Intel. Second, I agree that Intel is a great company, and they have made me a lot of money through the years, and I love their products and the speed with which they evolve. 

However, I must respectfully disagree with you that there is absolutely no anti-trust issue with respect to Intel. Sadly, they have been guilty of some tactics similar to those of MSFT in recent times since they have controlled the PC hardware. For example, they were requiring that if a PC vendor wanted to have early system design info for each new generation of microprocessor chip, they had to use Intel motherboards (not ONLY microprocessors) in their first generation machines. Now, if there had been a reasonable alternative source of microprocessors, this might have been reasonable, but, of course, they had a functional monopoly. In an industry that moves as fast as the PC business, this of course meant that ALL first versions of a particular generation were on Intel motherboards, thereby precluding innovation by the PC vendor themselves. Or, if a vendor tried to go it alone, they would not be able to have a competitive product available during the critical first months of a new generation, which would have been tantamount to commercial suicide. 

There are other examples, as well--things such as Intel customers suddenly suffering parts shortages should they agree to use chips from an Intel competitor. 

Having said all this, I actually feel that this current investigation is probably good for INTC. At the very least,it will cause them to reassess their business practices, and (if they are still doing this sort of stuff) change in ways that are better for us, their customers. Given that Messrs. Barrett et al. are much less likely to take the arrogant approach of Mr. Softee, I would not be surprised to see a reasonable settlement that will be an obvious winner for everyone. 

-- Dave Kisker (received 6/11/98) Leave the Crash Helmet 

The waves of "impending crash" caveats that accompany just about every discussion of the U.S. stockmarket caused me to recall a sage's advice that, "the market always does what the fewest people expect". Well, there are certainly many people who expect a crash, but there are also a lot of people who believe the market is headed much higher. Is there another scenario that might be developing? I believe so. 

First, lets think about the economic background that investors face. The Asian economies have yet to find a bottom. Several of our telecom equipment analysts have indicated that the companies they follow should report in line second quarter results, but that companies that distribute to Asia (the manufacturer's customers) are experiencing large increases in inventory. Result: channel stuffing will enable many companies to hit June quarter forecasts, but second half forecasts will come down. If this is true, it explains why it seems that there have been a manageable number of pre-releases this quarter. Nonetheless, the conference calls may be a different matter. Conclusion: Domestic U.S. economic growth is unlikely to accelerate and should begin to slow as the year progresses. If so, inflation will be very low and with it, bond yields will decline. 

If the market does what the fewest expect, what could this scenario mean for investors? 

1. Continued high valuations (P/E, Price/Book, etc.). This will drive the valuation crowd crazy. Investors will scramble for anything with growth among a diminishing list of growth companies. This view helps explain the high valuations of internet stocks --- at least they have growth. 

2. Volatile individual stock prices. These high valuations will cause companies that disappoint to be slaughtered because confidence in future growth will be shaken (and investors will move quickly to the next hot growth story). 

3. Slowing growth, high valuations and periodic blowups will depress the typical investor's annual returns into the mid-single digits. Few individuals or money managers will be able to sprint through an investment landscape increasingly littered with landmines. 

4. Low bond yields will cause total returns from fixed income instruments to be less than 6%. Although the long bond might have a bit of price upside as yields drift toward 5%, total returns elsewhere along the yield curve won't provide double digit returns. 

Bottom line: Investors may get neither mid-teens returns nor a crash that enables them to buy on the dip. Instead, we may be headed for a several quarter period of sluggish performance as valuations gradually come back to more normal levels. As a old consumer goods analyst, this is exactly how large cap consumer stocks behave --- a few to several years of outstanding performance, followed not by a crash, but by flat line price performance as valuations catch up (take a look at KO in the late 1980's/early 1990's, or WMT more recently). 

-- Richard Davis Jr. (received 6/11/98) Hayden's an Asset 

An asset allocator is a welcome addition to TheStreet.com. I'd like to see a debate between Cramer and Vern Hayden on whether asset allocation maximizes returns or guarantees mediocrity. 

-- Roger Mann (received 6/10/98) Rewarded 

The only people who have been rewarded by the R.S. Contrarian Fund are those of us who were smart enough to get out last October when it was first nominated for the fund graveyard. Thanks TSC. Paul Stephens doesn't have a clue!!! 

-- Jim Puffer (received 6/9/98) Y2K, Revisited 

The article on E*Trade and Y2K is very interesting, but not necessarily accurate. Many non-legacy systems, built in the past couple of years, are still non-Y2K compliant. I know first hand of one bank in the Northeast, which shall remain nameless, that contract to have a new system built to keep track of its trading. They engage a consulting firm, which built the system totally with 2-digit dates. 

Webtrends 3.5, a program that I use to analyze my web site, is not Y2K compliant. This is not only not a legacy system, it is very recent and totally Internet oriented 

This is not to say that E*Trade is not Y2K compliant, I'm simply pointing out that just because it is "Internet" and "recent" doesn't make it Y2K compliant. Given the legacy systems it must interface with, they could very easily have Y2K issues. The article doesn't mention any statements from the company about Y2K. 

Overall, the securities industry is far ahead of just about any other industry in terms of awareness and progress. The initial SIA testing is scheduled for this July, and their testing methodology is available on the Internet. 

-- Jeff Jacobs (received 6/9/98) Perplexed 

I am still perplexed by Jim Cramer's characterization of his stock positions as "inventory". As near as I can ascertain, Cramer has long term opinions about the unfolding relative improvement of certain large companies. He believes that on a short term basis the markets in those stocks reach technically diifficult to sustain short term levels of excess enthusiasm or revulsion. His trading, therefore, is broadly "fading" the public order flow. 

This is not, however, what I think of as securities "inventory", which is the raw material of a truly market-making function, or the by-product of the distribution of new issues. 

In my experience, one of the most dangerous situations a trader can find himself in is confusing speculation with a market-making discipline. It often leads to a two sets of books mentality where the interim losses are consigned to a mental investment account and the mental market-making account feels great. 

Mr. Cramer's frenetic trading may be wonderfully cathartic for his hedge fund's senior partner; but one wonders at the end of the day, how much does it add to the performance of the firm's underlying, and presumably carefully formulated bets? Is it in large part grist for the insatiable moloch of Wall Street entertainment against a twice daily TheStreet deadline? 

-- Paul J. Isaac (received 6/8/98) The Ax 

Eric Moskowitz: Good series of articles on the various axes' on the Street. However, it is at times difficult to keep an eye out for comments from these analysts on a daily basis when the news agencies that report analysts upgrades/downgrades don't identify the analysts as "axes". Therefore, how about you guys putting out a "The Axe Has Spoken" column as soon as one of these analysts makes a change in recommendation. 

-- Brett Rule (received 6/5/98) New Fan 

Herb Greenberg: Regarding the recent discussion in your column about comments directed at JJC, I offer my 2 cents. First, I began reading TSC because of JJC. I subscribed for a year (and will continue for long after that, I suppose) because of JJC. I try to read everything he writes, whether in TSC or other venues. I have learned more from him about trading than could be bought at any price at any of this country's best b-schools. I am obviously an ardent fan of his. 

That said, I am also becoming an ardent fan of yours since your arrival at TSC. Perhaps it is the lawyer in me, but I like seeing the issues from "both sides of the street." It allows one to keep a clearer head, and that is what the entire exercise of TSC should be about. The "sniping" is taken for what it is: the good-natured ribbing of JJC from one who also admires his work and personna, while making valid points in disagreement. As I've said to you before, keep up the good work. 

-- Bill Luttrell (received 6/5/98) More Helpful 

Herb Greenberg: If you stop offering your perspective on the market, I'll cancel. Although I respect JJC, and his views re trading etc. are interesting, your columns are much more helpful in my effort to understand this market as an investor. So much noise and confusion out there! What we need is wisdom and perspective on things. That's why I read your columns and that's why I'm still a subscriber to TSC. 

-- Tim Mikkel (received 6/5/98) Fore 

James Cramer: When people hassle you about [a recent column on] Dell here is another analogy that my explain your bullishness. 

The four best golfers at a private club are Mr. Dell, Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP. They always shoot in the 70's with Mr. Dell usually shooting a couple of strokes better than the rest. There are lots of other members at the club but while being good players, they can't really compete with the big four. The club they belong to is know as an easy course(wide fairways, flat greens, few trees and sand traps). It is easy to score well. This course is the equivalent of the PC industry of the last couple of years, growth being so rapid everyone makes money. 

The big four decide to go on a golf vacation. By some miracle they are able to play Augusta National. Augusta National is the golf equivalent of today's PC environment "HELL". Needless to say Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP are completely overmatched by the course and shoot horrible scores. Mr. Dell sucks it up and scrambles his way to to another sub 80 round. Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP put on a brave face and say they are going to head to the driving range to make a few adjustments in their game. Things will be better tomorrow. 

The fundamental difference between Mr. Dell and the others(Mr IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP) is that Mr. Dell can adjust to the rapidly changing environment as the environment changes. Mr. IBM, Mr. Compaq and Mr. HP get annihilated by a change in the environment, go back home reflect on what happened, develop a plan to adapt, put the plan into action and hope things will be better tomorrow. They will always be killed by a negative change in the environment(hard courses) and do well when the environment turns positive(easy courses). 

The morale of the story is that Mr Dell is a better golfer and if your going to bet on Golf then bet on Mr Dell. CREAMer always rises to the top. 

-- Mike Yaffe (received 6/5/98) Kudos 

Herb Greenberg: I don't understand people who don't "get it". I think the ongoing debate between the you [and James Cramer] is one of the things that make TSC an interesting forum. I, for one, am sick and tired of all the whiners who expect this to be a promtional site that has nothing but "buys" and positive spin. Tell them to put on their rose-coloured sunglasses and spend more time at www.justhypeme.com , otherwise known as Silicon Investor. As a paying customer, I would rather see fewer articles written for newbies - your sophistication and expertise is what adds value. 

-- A. John Carlesso (received 6/5/98) Remember the Akron 

Jim Cramer: Enjoy your writing, your comments have made money for me. Thanks, and here is my favorite mental image of trading psychology. Have you ever seen the newsreel clips of the 1920's US Airship Akron disaster? The scene is like traders' thinking about when to take the loss or hold on. The airship was met by a party of about a hundred ground handlers grabbing the ropes when a sudden wind gust and loss of ballast control caused the ship to bob up and down twenty, thirty, forty feet three or four times before rapidly climbing to a thousand feet unable to descend and then crashing within the half hour. There was a rain of falling men from different heights. When does the trader take his loss? Like the ground handler he has to decide if he lets go for a 20 feet fall to suffer a broken leg or hold on for a litte longer until the ship gets back to only to only a 5 foot hop down. One could even hope to get back down uninjured. But then what if the ship just continues up and up… This happened to the ones who didn't let go before it was too late. However, one man did survive by hanging even to a thousand feet holding on for dear life and walked away from the crash landing. 

-- Sanford Friedrich (received 6/5/98) Trust 

James Cramer: I welcomed the wisdom you shared yesterday, it helped put things in perspective and clearly you were right until the market got sand-bagged by the Intel whiff. You are on the money though, the trust level is down - I think that's what I was trying to articulate in my mail yesterday. Why should a trader trust a market that constantly deflates and then only partially re-inflates the next day? Clearly, for a newbie like me it's hard to see why one should - how many times do you need to get your hands burnt before you stop after all? 

Perhaps that's the most frightening thing about the market - the general feeling appears to be falling to short sentiment, which is something I haven't had much experience dealing with (I did send mail to Smith a few weeks ago to go over it since I suspected we would end up in this sort of market sometime - didn't think it would be this quick though). Here we now have people using the chats on the Net to try to move stocks down, not up - perhaps the strongest evidence I've felt that the nature of the game is changing. I sure hope I'm wrong, since this is a game that I really don't look forward to playing in. 

-- Bryan McCormick (received 6/5/98) What Intel Didn't Say 

With everything INTC has already said about business slacking off, coupled with another wave of price cuts, does Intel really need to issue another statement saying its profits/revenue/growth won't be what people thought? 

-- Erik Milstone (received 6/4/98) Turning the Tables 

Since Mr. Cramer has been on CNBC so much, I would like to see him turn the tables and invite Mark Haines to show up for Mr. Cramer's new show, Real Money. Thanks for all the good work. 

-- Tom Delosso (received 6/4/98) Instructive 

James Cramer: I read everything you publish on TS.com and the articles that are most instructive (to me) are the "I Can Screw Up Too" ones where you describe and analyze your mistakes. I too evaluate my mistakes from every angle with the intention of learning how to avoid making the same mistake twice. Please keep it up. 

-- Jerry Daughan, Harpswell, Maine (received 6/4/98) Stretched 

James Cramer: Your arguments seem more stretched by the day. For some reason you don't want to acknowledge that there is a huge slowdown at the semiconductor and boxmaker level. Dell, GTW, may be good trades, but it's ludicrous to suggest that the fundamentals are improving. 

-- Steve Vita (received 6/4/98) No Reply 

Dan Colarusso: I have filed several e-mail type complaints with the NASDR office and the SEC enforcement-tips office over the past few months when I have seen "blatant" volume-spike options trading in calls or puts where there was no news, AND then after hours that company will come out with dramatic 'material' information which causes massive trading in the underlying stock the following morning-open. Some of these instances are so damm obvious that (you or I) figure that the regulators should have been able to see it, also. Most of the time, I never hear back from them. 

-- Gerald E. Naugle, Boulder, Colo. (received 6/4/98) Hear! Hear! 

As regards JJC's motion to start a "conference cancellation watch" on TSC, here's a second. 

-- Tom Scott (received 6/3/98) Terrific 

Gary Smith: Every time I read one of your columns I get ready to fire up the email to tell you how terrific I think your pieces are -- informative, motivating, and written with a style and dynamic (i.e., the way the words move you along) that remind me how excited I used to get when I got a sentence or paragraph right when I was writing a newsletter a number of years ago. This time I'm going to carry through and send this off. TheStreet.com is one of my favorite web sites and you're a big part of the reason. Thanks. 

-- Alan Kaplan (received 6/1/98)

urn:contentItem:5WH5-CRG1-DXVP-V162-00000-00Review: ‘The Code’ busts Silicon Valley’s favorite myths about itself2019-07-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisBOOKSReview: ‘The Code’ busts Silicon Valley’s favorite myths about itselfStephen Phillip

The swath of the South Bay once so prized for its orchards and all-round Edenic charm that it was dubbed "the Valley of Heart's Delight" has spawned myriad imitators. Reflecting local topography, there's Silicon Glen, Silicon Fen, Silicon Roundabout, Silicon Steppe and, most egregiously, Philicon Valley (take a bow Philadelphia), among other wannabes.

But there's only one Silicon Valley. How to explain the sui generis success of this "high-tech Galapagos?" Margaret O'Mara's "The Code: Silicon Valley and the Remaking of America" sets out to crack the elusive code behind the code that has supplanted fruit as the valley's main export. The result is a fresh, provocative take that upends the self-serving mythologizing of the valley's own.

Conventional wisdom depicts the valley as a place apart, remote from and unbeholden to old power centers, the product of rugged individualism, its history a pageant of eureka moments in garages and dorm rooms. In this telling, government figures barely — as a scold or spoiler to be kept at bay — if at all.

Margaret O'Mara is the author of "The Code: Silicon Valley and the Remaking of America" (Penguin; 512 pages; $30). Photo: Jim Garner

A historian who worked in the Clinton administration before entering academia, O'Mara posits a counter-narrative in which the valley owes its origins — and survival during lean times — to defense contracts, and government emerges as "perhaps its greatest … venture capitalist." Whirring away in the background like electrical current through computer circuitry: a nexus of money, power and influence between the valley and Washington that predates Al Gore's internet boosterism, Obama officials' coziness with big tech or Google's high-powered D.C. lobbying operation.

But O'Mara is hardly proposing the valley as a creature of big government-by-stealth or enlightened bureaucratic design. Rather, the workings of government there have often been indirect, sometimes inadvertent, she writes, as much rooted in omission as commission — dwelling in the negative space of inaction and permissive regulation besides "largesse" and purposeful programs. Either way, a constant has been intensive politicking by valley brass — for all their professed libertarianism or apolitical leanings, far from passive recipients of grace and favor. It's a frame that casts familiar figures in a new light. Storied venture capitalist John Doerr provided seed capital to Amazon, Google, Sun and Netscape but, an emissary to Washington's elite, arch coalition builder and lobbyist in chief for the industry, he was also a consummate "policy entrepreneur," O'Mara points out.

"The Code" doesn't skimp on the milestones of valley lore — the "traitorous eight" splitting from Shockley Semiconductor to found Fairchild Semiconductor and modern-day Silicon Valley; or, "the mother of all demos" showcasing "the mouse, interactive computing, hyperlinks, networked video and audio" in 1968. But O'Mara spotlights the village of institutions, networks and ancillary services — corps of bankers, lawyers and marketers overlooked in many accounts of the valley's exceptionalism — behind the big moments.

She also supplements them with a concatenation of ostensibly small deeds, obscure statutes, legislative arcana and legal loopholes that proved deeply consequential.

Consider an alternative valley timeline beginning with the 1958 Small Business Investment Act: in its generous matching loans for startup investors a catalyst for the first wave of VC firms.

And in 1994, when merchants eyed the nascent web as a medium of commercial exchange but consumers balked at entrusting their credit card to websites, enter the government with a means of protecting this data that laid down the rudiments of secure online transactions and helped jump-start e-commerce — perhaps "the greatest return on investment in Valley history."

Meantime, we're still living with the reverberations of fine print in the 1996 Communications Decency Act. Industry lobbying, and the efforts of civil liberties advocates, purged it of sanctions against online porn peddlers but not a clause absolving platforms of responsibility for content posted to their sites.

Overall, the Clinton administration ensured the infant web wasn't captured by big business, but also that it wasn't smothered by regulation.

Then there's the outsize impact — for better and worse — of California's proscription of non-compete job contracts, allowing workers to decamp with impunity to rival firms. This has fostered a certain industry-wide collegiality, not to mention a fluid job market. And it's led to referral-based recruitment that's proved expedient in tapping an industry-wide pool in which new hires are readily attuned to a prevailing culture and, interchangeable as widgets, quickly productive. But it's also contributed toward a hermetic culture — self-propagating, incestuous and insular — in which recruitment has too often been confined to "charmed circles" of white, maybe Asian men, O'Mara writes. The result: "programmed in sharp gender and racial imbalances" — the valley's historical blind spots, all the more glaring for their coexistence with its often otherwise progressive mores.

Such happenstances lack the sexiness of hackathons and product launches, but they've been formative in the valley's culture and products. And they're of more than academic interest as the pervasiveness of the valley's cultural currency and products makes its pathologies, besides its ingenuities, the concern of us all.

Ironically, at a time when this influence is maximally felt, the valley is on its way to physically obsoleting itself, O'Mara adds. The cloud liberates entrepreneurs from place, permitting them to rent computing power and tap remote teams rather than investing in pricey hardware and on-site teams. And how many scrappy founders can afford to bootstrap a company in today's valley? The obituaries are already being written. But the valley's been written off before.

The Code: Silicon Valley and the Remaking of America

By Margaret O'Mara

Penguin Press

(512 pages; $30)

urn:contentItem:5WTW-T1C1-JD3Y-Y34N-00000-00Review the Concept of Vertical Separation and its Changing Role for the Telecoms Industry, 2019 Report2019-08-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisReview the Concept of Vertical Separation and its Changing Role for the Telecoms Industry, 2019 Report

August 16, 2019

The "Vertical Separation: A Code for Cord-Cutting Telcos?" report has been added to ResearchAndMarkets.com's offering.

No longer just a regulatory punishment', there are good business reasons for separation.

This report reviews the concept of vertical separation and its changing role for the telecoms industry.

Vertical separation' encompasses different concepts, ranging from rather mild reporting requirements to full ownership separation. The report shows that the concept is not unique to telecoms, but has been implemented in a great many industries.

Within telecoms, vertical separation was long considered a regulatory remedy for those cases where a dominant operator discriminated unduly against its rivals. The report sheds light on the main drivers of separation, and how they are changing this situation and are making vertical separation a reasonable business strategy for operators.

A number of case studies will illustrate the approaches already taken by several operators towards separation and how the current trend is evolving towards voluntary separation.

A conclusion wraps up this report.

Key Topics Covered:

1. Executive Summary

2. Introduction
2.1. What is vertical separation?
2.2. Flavours of separation

3. The relevance of vertical separation
3.1. Vertical separation is already practised across all network industries
3.2. and is discussed time and again for big tech

4. Separation drivers
4.1. Vertical separation: from stick to carrot?
4.2. The reason why the Code favours vertical separation
4.3. The well-managed quality of service of wholesale products facilitates separation
4.4. A promising long-term investment

5. Separation cases
5.1. Openreach
5.2. TDC
5.3. TIM: from voluntary' functional separation to voluntary structural separation?
5.4. CETIN/O2 CZ: the first operator to implement truly voluntary separation
5.5. Vertical separation is not a fixed-only' phenomenon

6. Wrap-up
6.1. Separation sees the convergence or combination of three essential forces
6.2. Telcos should explore the separation option

Companies Mentioned

- CETIN/O2
- Openreach
- TDC
- TIM

urn:contentItem:5RD4-TPD1-F021-64ST-00000-00Review: The Know-It-Alls: The Rise of Silicon Valley as a Political Powerhouse and Social Wrecking Ball by Noam Cohen;This latest attack on Silicon Valley is utopian and wrongheaded, says David Aaronovitch2018-01-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisSATURDAY REVIEWVersion:1Review: The Know-It-Alls: The Rise of Silicon Valley as a Political Powerhouse and Social Wrecking Ball by Noam CohenThis latest attack on Silicon Valley is utopian and wrongheaded, says David AaronovitchDavid Aaronovitch

It is hard now to recall the misty, innocent days when we thought Steve Jobs was fun and Amazon was useful. I am of that sandwiched generation who grew up with pens, typewriters and the indentation of the tip of the index finger that came from phone dialling. Then we adapted to PCs and smartphones and have been inclined towards gratitude for the way our lives were made easier and more interesting by the work of the Silicon Valley techies. That gratitude, however, is dying with us; the cursors turning to curses.

Noam Cohen's book is a competent, slightly humourless concoction - half polemic, half potted biographies of the big figures of Big Tech. Most significantly it is a not untypical representative of the mood of disenchantment. For him, Bill Gates and Larry Page are the Andrew Carnegies and JP Morgans of the millennial cusp - lawless robber barons who fix the terms of trade to suit themselves, then preen around giving money to charity and proclaiming their own virtues.

"These Silicon Valley leaders," he writes, "propose a society in which personal freedoms are near absolute and government regulations wither away, where bold entrepreneurs amass billions of dollars from their innovations and the rest of us struggle in a hypercompetitive market without unions, government regulations, or social welfare programs to protect us."

The good old world is destroyed. "Local stores, local newspapers, local unions, local political organisations are swept away as tech companies centralise profits." The small, intimate collective life (albeit governmentally regulated) of the prelapsarian world is flooded by their infernal devices, which by some semi-hypnotic power force us to buy them, use them and replace other things with them, despite ourselves.

Cohen has written on tech for, among others, The New York Times and knows something of the field. But if he is aware of the history of disruption (ie the history of human development) he doesn't acknowledge it. For Big Tech read Big Pharma, supermarket chains, the automobile, the railways, bankers, printing, Rupert Murdoch, cable TV, movies, novels and agriculture. Each and all of them has been accused of subverting the more natural and more local (and inevitably more hierarchical) order of things.

Today the cycle of disenchantment is ever quicker. It took us some time to get cross with Google for making so much money out of advertising to us, less to become angry with Facebook for exploiting our personal information, and almost none at all to go from regarding Uber and Airbnb as modern miracles to seeing them as sinks of exploitation.

According to Cohen, the Australopithecus of the evolutionary strain that led to Silicon Man and thence to Uber was developed in the postwar labs and offices of Stanford University in California. Situated in what became Silicon Valley, Stanford was a poor relation to the Ivy League schools, and to survive created a new model of entrepreneurial research. Its dean of engineering, the creator of Stanford Industrial Park and finally provost until 1965, was Frederick Terman. He sought out and procured some of the leading talents in emerging technologies and encouraged a model whereby they could develop and profit from the innovations their work created.

Just a generation ago the practical (and profitable) application of university research to industry was considered something of a grail. And Stanford was a model for it. Cohen invites us to see this joining of academia and enterprise as a grisly mixed marriage that brought forth the mutant that is ruining our world. From outside it is hard not to see it rather as an enlightened strategy that placed the US in the forefront of the technologies that have transformed the past three decades.

The once-heroes now antiheroes of Silicon Valley each get their shortish chapters. Gates of Microsoft is here, as are Marc Andreessen of Netscape, Jeff Bezos of Amazon, Larry Page and Sergey Brin of Google, Peter Thiel of Paypal, Jimmy Wales of Wikipedia and Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook. They're all men, they're all white, they're all rich and, as far as Cohen is concerned, they're all the same. So the politics of the one Trump supporter, Thiel (who is a conflicted libertarian), is held to represent the logical destination of all of them, even though most of them opposed Trump.

The most interesting chapter for me is the one on John McCarthy, the originator of the term "artificial intelligence". McCarthy was the son of American communists, both of whom worked for the party paper, the Daily Worker. At 17 he was an activist, but at the height of the Cold War drifted out of politics and dedicated himself to the new science of computing. He was one of the people poached by Terman to go to Stanford, where he helped to set up the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Lab in 1965.

Told by Cohen, McCarthy's journey is just another (and regrettable) drift from the left of his youth to the right of his senescence. And despite his many innovations and accurate predictions of the shape of the world to come, McCarthy's main significance for Cohen lies in his reaction to one incident that took place in 1989.

It was then that McCarthy successfully argued against taking down one of the new internet forums hosted, but not run by Stanford - rec.humor.funny - on the basis that it carried racist and offensive jokes. McCarthy's view was that the internet needed to be a place where free expression was allowed at all times.

Cohen believes that McCarthy's campaign was the origin of what Cohen sees as a terrible flaw. He writes: "Either you accepted offensive speech online or you were in favour of burning books. There would be no middle ground permitted, and thus no opportunity to introduce reasonable regulations to ensure civility online, which is our predicament today." Following McCarthy's dictum means that Facebook, Google and Twitter have "encouraged the public to stew in their own hateful juices and profited handsomely in the process".

It's ironic that a journalist such as Cohen should regard a commitment to freedom of expression as an essentially right-wing characteristic. McCarthy, of course, coming from a communist background, may have sensed more accurately the dangers involved in restricting what people could say on what would become the great universal platform. McCarthy may have read Orwell.

The problem is that the "middle ground" suggested by Cohen requires someone to decide what it is and to police it. It needs a censor. And why go to the trouble of burning books if you can use an algorithm to expunge certain kinds of expression?

I don't mean that Cohen is always wrong. Big money often means big arrogance and needs big oversight. But his alternative nirvana of a lovely big, diverse, chaotic Gormenghast of an internet, all free and yet somehow all regulated, with only good things happening and sin somehow filtered out by the actions of volunteer curators, is chimerical. Like all utopias, in practice we wouldn't like it when we got there.The Know-It-Alls: The Rise of Silicon Valley as a Political Powerhouse and Social Wrecking Ballby Noam Cohen, Oneworld, 272pp, £18.99

value.Title: Review: The People vs Tech: How the Internet Is Killing Democracy (and How We Save It) by Jamie Bartlett - Cambridge Analytica, Facebook, YouTube and the threat to politics;Democracy and technology are locked in a battle that only one of them can win, argues this timely polemic. Review by Camilla Cavendish

Extracts.SummaryText: ... Something I hadn't realised, but People vs Tech explains, is that being a "platform" rather than a "publisher" is not wholly positive for Mark Zuckerberg.
