urn:contentItem:5S3R-YY41-JCJY-G4WY-00000-00Review: The People vs Tech: How the Internet Is Killing Democracy (and How We Save It) by Jamie Bartlett - Cambridge Analytica, Facebook, YouTube and the threat to politics;Democracy and technology are locked in a battle that only one of them can win, argues this timely polemic. Review by Camilla Cavendish2018-04-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisCULTUREVersion:1Review: The People vs Tech: How the Internet Is Killing Democracy (and How We Save It) by Jamie Bartlett - Cambridge Analytica, Facebook, YouTube and the threat to politicsDemocracy and technology are locked in a battle that only one of them can win, argues this timely polemic. Review by Camilla CavendishReview by Camilla Cavendish

This book could not have come at a better moment, when we are all in the grip of the endlessly unfolding story of Cambridge Analytica. It's a bit breathless in its quest to paint technology as a relentless enemy, but it's pacey, and, when it comes to the workings of Big Tech, the blogger Jamie Bartlett clearly knows his stuff.

Bartlett is director of the Centre for the Analysis of Social Media at the think tank Demos. He believes that democracy and technology are locked in a battle that only one of them can win.

I'll come back to the democracy bit. Bartlett is at his strongest when explaining the inner workings of Big Tech. Every click and swipe builds the machine, which in turn exploits us for profit. We have all been complicit in building this machine, by giving away our data, and it's time to wise up.

He brings home, chillingly, the menacing passivity of algorithms. "I highly doubt," he writes, "that any one Google employee fully understands the company's algorithms, much like no single worker could now make a car or a pencil."

Algorithms update themselves, without human intervention. The logical goal, he writes, would be "for each of us to be reduced to a unique, predictable and targetable data point". You don't have to be quite that apocalyptic to feel alarmed that the YouTube algorithm "shapes what 1.5 bn users are likely to see". That's more than every newspaper in the world.

The book comes to life when Bartlett goes on the road. He mixes with crypto-anarchists in a cafe that, kookily, only accepts bitcoin. He meets a former tech executive who has bought guns and retreated to a remote island, appalled by the prospect of being watched. He conjures up some terrifying, sci-fi images: one is of drones the size of bumblebees that could use facial recognition to find and kill you.

He also visits Project Alamo, the heart of the Republican Party's campaign to win votes. There are detailed descriptions of how Cambridge Analytica, Vote Leave and Jeremy Corbyn's Labour Party have used big data. Cambridge Analytica apparently had the stunning insight that potential Trump voters tended to prefer American-made cars: I found myself hoping that no one was foolish enough to pay them for that.

Something I hadn't realised, but People vs Tech explains, is that being a "platform" rather than a "publisher" is not wholly positive for Mark Zuckerberg. Sunday Times readers will be aware that platforms don't have to exercise the same kind of responsibility as the editor of this newspaper. But Bartlett explains that this has created a dilemma for YouTube and Facebook. Knowing that lawmakers would like to regulate them as publishers, which would force them to comb through mountains of data, these companies are taking care not to behave too much like publishers, even to the extent of not cleaning out divisive or misleading stories. That will surely become a bigger and bigger problem for them - and their shareholders.

I found myself parting company with Bartlett on several occasions. He argues that social media creates a kind of permanent visibility, of "watching and being watched", which makes us more pliable. But it doesn't feel like that on Twitter. There is undeniably something in the idea that we are scared of the mob, but I don't accept that the silent majority have stopped thinking for themselves.

The book's overall thesis is that we have, "in exchange for the undeniable benefits of technology, allowed other components of a functioning political system to be undermined: control, parliamentary sovereignty, economic equality, civil society and an informed citizenry". I wasn't sure about that list, to be honest. No free society has true "economic equality", although Bartlett seems to think it should: he veers off-piste to talk about universal basic income. And while Brexit has certainly shrunk the power of parliament on that particular issue, because direct democracy trumps representative democracy, I don't agree with Bartlett that voters are hankering after ever more referenda. It seems to me it's quite the opposite.

I did wish Bartlett wouldn't keep letting his prejudices slip. He pulls together strong evidence of growing polarisation and intolerance in the echo chamber of social media. But he also makes quite clear that he thinks anyone who voted for Brexit or Trump is an idiot. It does not seem to occur to him that those people were perhaps not being manipulated by bots, but were fed up with the political elite and exercising their democratic right to say so.

What are Bartlett's solutions? He wants us all to become more discerning and sceptical about what we encounter online. He also believes that we must stop ourselves becoming too distracted, because distraction and information overload make us more likely to delegate decisions to demagogues or faceless algorithms. He is surely right about that - and there's an endearing moment when he discovers that he is checking his own phone 77 times a day.

He is light on how Big Tech should be regulated. He wants government inspectors to be able to "look under the bonnet" and examine digital algorithms - a power that some of us have already suggested should be given, in the UK, to the Information Commissioner. But he deals only fleetingly with the break-up of monopolies, which will surely be critical. I would have liked to read more detail on that, and on the "new digital ethics" that he wants companies to embrace but doesn't define. I also thought he might have said something about simplifying turgid "terms and conditions" which, he reminds us, we all solemnly tick without having a clue.

I enjoyed this book. It made me think. But I came away feeling that I have more faith in people than does the author. Perhaps that makes me naive, or superannuated. But punters can abandon Facebook, just as they left Myspace and Bebo. And People vs Tech makes clear that there is still time - just - for us to take back control.Ebury £8.99 pp256Camilla Cavendish was head of David Cameron's policy unit at 10 Downing Street from 2015 to 2016

urn:contentItem:5RRT-Y0S1-DY43-6219-00000-00REVIEW - US Supreme Court Holding Hearing of International Data Privacy Case Between Microsoft, DOJ2018-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisREVIEW - US Supreme Court Holding Hearing of International Data Privacy Case Between Microsoft, DOJ

BRUSSELS, February 27 (Sputnik) - The hearing of the case on international data privacy between the US Department of Justice (DOJ) and IT giant Microsoft, also known as the "Microsoft Ireland" case, is being held at the US Supreme Court on Tuesday.

The pending case was opened in 2013, when Microsoft challenged a warrant issued by US law enforcement officers to hand over emails of a target account, related to a probe into drug a trafficking case, that were stored on servers in Ireland.

Microsoft then argued that under US law, namely the 1986 Stored Communications Act, US-based companies could not be compelled to provide data held on servers outside the US, adding that the DOJ should take the relevant request to the Irish authorities​​​.

The US Department of Justice, in turn, contended that Microsoft, as a company operating in the United States, was required to respond to the law enforcement officers' request.

Despite the fact that the first round of hearings was won by the DOJ in 2014, the New York-based United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled in 2016 that the US government was unable to force Microsoft or any other company to hand over the emails that were held on servers outside the country.

In October 2017, the Supreme Court agreed to hear the appeal of US President Donald Trump's administration regarding the earlier ruling.

The Supreme Court is expected to issue the final verdict by the end of June.

OUTDATED LEGISLATION SHOULD BE ADDRESSED BY CONGRESS

Earlier on Tuesday, Microsoft President and Chief Legal Officer Brad Smith said in a statement ahead of the hearing in court that, in his opinion, the US authorities could not be guided by laws written three decades ago, referring to the Stored Communications Act.

"We can’t rely on laws written three decades ago, before the internet as we know it was invented. Ultimately the courts – including the Supreme Court – can decide only whether the Department of Justice’s approach passes muster under current law," the statement read.

Smith underlined that despite the court's decision the majority of the work should be done by the US Congress, calling on the legislative body to adopt a law that would correspond to today's realities.

"But while attention today will focus on the Supreme Court, we believe the most important work should take place in the Capitol building across the street, by the U.S. Congress ... The courts are not able to write a new law. Under the U.S. Constitution, only Congress can do that, using its tools to craft a nuanced solution that balances all the competing concerns by enacting a statute for the 21st century," Smith stressed.

TOUGHER PRIVACY RIGHTS PROTECTION IN EUROPE

The European Union is closely monitoring the case, since similar problems exist across across the Atlantic. In May 2018, the European Union is expected to introduce its General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). The new legislation will replace the EU Data Protection Directive 95/46/EC and harmonize data privacy laws across Europe to protect all EU citizens in their data privacy and reshape the way organizations across the region approach data privacy.

"There is a huge difference between what countries can decide in joint agreements on mutual legal assistance, and criminal law for individuals, where extraterritoriality cannot just be overruled like that. Microsoft is actually followed by the Irish government, when it refuses to deliver the emails that the US justice department requests. Can you imagine any dictatorship requesting tomorrow the same sort of access to its citizens’ data abroad?" a lawyer representing a big tech company said anonymously to Sputnik.

The GDPR will be tough for companies, organizations and individuals within Europe. In particular, the new privacy rights legislation is expected to extend its territorial competence to the organizations outside the European Union that provide goods and services to data subjects in the European Union.

In addition, the GDPR will require companies to make their requests for the processing of personal data consent more informative concrete and unambiguous.

EU SEEKS ACCESS TO PRIVATE DATA STORED OUTSIDE UNION

When it comes to access to private data in the interest of the EU authorities, EU member states still want to be a able to obtain information on servers across borders. That is why the European Commission is currently preparing relevant legislation.

"The EU executive wants law enforcement authorities to be able to access electronic evidence stored within the 28-nation bloc. This is known for a while and nothing new, there is a proposal in preparation on access to e-evidence for law enforcement (investigations and evidence within the EU). It was already discussed in the Justice council previously," Christian Wigand, a European Commission spokesman, told Sputnik.

The scope of the planned European legislation extends to data held elsewhere than in the European Union, which, according to experts, will be difficult to implement in reality.

urn:contentItem:5PKR-PPC1-F021-60G8-00000-00Review: World Without Mind: The Existential Threat of Big Tech by Franklin Foer;This furious polemic argues that the web threatens civilisation, says Hugo Rifkind2017-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisSATURDAY REVIEWVersion:1Review: World Without Mind: The Existential Threat of Big Tech by Franklin FoerThis furious polemic argues that the web threatens civilisation, says Hugo RifkindHugo Rifkind

Franklin Foer is furious. It takes a while to appreciate he is furious, granted, because he is a ponderous writer, and in World Without Mind: The Existential Threat of Big Tech he is apt to get distracted from his fury with lengthy passages about things such as the history of bookshelves, or whether Descartes really built a robot that looked like his dead daughter, Francine, which was thrown off a boat. (No.) But furious he definitely is. As the subtitle suggests, he believes that tech companies are ruining the world.

"Oh, that again," you might think. Foer, though, is well placed to make this criticism, because before tech companies started ruining the world, they first ruined his. Foer resigned/was fired in 2014 as editor of The New Republic, one of those liberal New York magazines that people pretend to read, due to disagreements with his proprietor. That proprietor was Chris Hughes, a founder of Facebook, who had bought an old media company and was set upon turning it into a new media company. Foer, who oozes old media despite not really being old enough, was far from keen on this.

Foer believes that tech companies have degraded the intellectual discourse of not just social media users, but also civilisation at large. They have, he argues, assaulted the very foundation of knowledge. For Foer, the foundational text of Silicon Valley was The Whole Earth Catalog, a countercultural magazine run by Stewart Brand in the late 1960s, which sought to spread niche knowledge to the hippy masses. Brand came up with the maxim "information wants to be free". Foer puts this as the inspiration behind Google's desire to scan every book in existence, waging war on the concept of copyright. The idea is that maximum human knowledge should lead to maximum human enlightenment.

Yet that's not what happened. For one thing, when you have endless available information you hit what David Foster Wallace called "total noise", an impenetrable blurt of everything. The historical problem of scarcity of information - the problem early tech evangelists sought to solve - has morphed instead into a scarcity of attention.

People need to filter. The tech answer to this is an algorithm, but algorithms are not neutral. Foer points out that Netflix and Amazon offer recommendations to their users, for example, but there the similarities end. Amazon directs its users to more familiar products (one third of its purchases come from its recommendations), whereas subscription-based Netflix directs its users to the unfamiliar because blockbuster movies cost more to stream.

Foer has a slightly tweedy disdain for the philistines of tech. You can feel the sneer, for example, in his quoting of Jeff Bezos, the Amazon founder, when he complains about physical books, "turning the pages . . . the book is always flopping itself shut at the wrong moment". Coming from a man whose firm sells 40 per cent of all books bought, this hurts.

Upworthy would create 25 headlines per story and study which one did best

Even so, Foer's denunciation of online journalism, which comes in his book's best chapter, is not just powerful, but essential reading for any journalist, or indeed reader of journalism. He notes that a memoir by the critic Alfred Kazin recalls that the fee for a book review in The New Republic of the 1930s was $150. Despite 80 years of inflation, Foer points out, this is also, dollar for dollar, the fee for a book review for the same magazine's website. Everything is falling apart.

"The core insight of Upworthy, Buzzfeed, Vox and other emerging internet behemoths," he writes, "was that editorial success could be engineered." A company can study which topics get the most clicks, and which writers. This has led to the phenomenon of headlines with a "curiosity gap". Upworthy, for example, once garnered 6 million clicks from the headline "9 Out Of 10 Americans Are Completely Wrong About This Mind-Blowing Fact". The fact in question was merely a dry statistic about income inequality. At the time, the company would create 25 headlines per story, and study which one did best.

Meanwhile, another internet trend has been to render articles "untethered entities" in much the same way that Apple's iTunes model ripped singles out of albums. The upshot, with both, is that the fun stuff soars and the worthy stuff fades away.

Foer's first contention is that this leads to nonsense. For example, last year's inconsequential story about a Minnesota dentist shooting a lion (Cecil, you remember) generated an astonishing 3.2 million individual stories online, which he calls "a deluge of ephemera dissecting the ephemeral".

His second, more contentious contention is that it led to the election of Donald Trump, because the news chased easy hits and Trump's outrages provided them.

In the end, "Facebook leads us to a destination that is the precise opposite of its stated ideal". In a nutshell, giving everybody everything was supposed to enlighten. Instead, because information requires curation, we end up with less.

Where Foer breaks ground is in elucidating why the internet's inbuilt urge to achieve crowd-pleasing consensus has done the opposite, polarising western societies. America's political split is caused by, he says, conformism. "Facebook has created two hive minds each residing in an ecosystem that nurtures head-nodding agreement and penalises dissenting views. A hive mind is an intellectually incapacitated one, with diminishing ability to sort fact from fiction, with a bias toward evidence that confirms the party line." We pick a tribe and conform to it, and cannot break free enough to even empathise with another.

Foer's solutions to all this are largely regulatory, technical and American, and might not terribly interest British readers. His main concession to a British edition is a foreword that, I must confess, gave me the hump. In it, he suggests that the British press was once a great national strength "like France's wine or Switzerland's timepieces", but that it has terribly declined over the past 20 years (ie while I've been working in it). As it happens, I think he's wrong, or not wholly right. Newspapers in the 1990s could be every bit as crap as they sometimes manage to be today.

Still, his book comes as a rousing recommendation of a subscription model newspaper that avoids the competitive ravages of virality. You're reading one. Well done you.World Without Mind: The Existential Threat of Big Techby Franklin Foer, Jonathan Cape, 272pp, £18.99

urn:contentItem:60KF-Y911-F11P-X0BV-00000-00Revisiting Facial Recognition Technology And Privacy Concerns – Analysis2020-08-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisRevisiting Facial Recognition Technology And Privacy Concerns – Analysis

By Sagnik Chakraborty*

In June 2020, IBM, Microsoft and Amazon decided to stop selling facial recognition technology to law enforcement agencies, in light of potential misuse of the technology. IBM went a step further and stopped the development of the technology altogether.

No other company or entity, however, is taking the high moral ground on facial technology. The use of facial recognition by governments around the world has become quite prevalent. China has used it enforce quarantine in Beijing[1] and to crack down on protestors in Hong Kong.[2] Dubai's Ooyun project uses facial recognition for smart policing.[3] Russia has used it against protestors[4] as well as to track citizens' movements during the coronavirus lockdown.[5]

It is now so prevalent that ordinary citizens know that they are being watched from all angles, public and private. For example, even when Facebook prompts a name to be tagged in a photo, it uses facial recognition algorithm to determine their presence in an image.

Facial recognition technology analyses facial images and interprets the identity of a person. The surface and features of a face are broken down into several data points to derive the output, with the precision of a plastic surgeon. For instance, the distance between the nose and lips; the width and breadth of a lip; protrusion of cheek bones and several other such conditions are used. Facial recognition tech is an Artificial Intelligence driven system. This is because when two unequal entities such as one version of person's facial expression is compared to his many photos taken across different time intervals, the system makes an intelligent judgement on whether it matches with the person's face.

The source of a facial image can be both physical – such as street cameras – and digital, such as social media. The captured image is then compared with thousands of images collected in a database made out of social media profiles, photographs provided for social identification cards such as Social Security, driver's licenses, passport etc. Technology companies can scrape the internet for images and videos containing faces, group them and map them to a single person. More data helps to train the facial recognition algorithm better, as every feature and expression is captured. For instance, it can recognise both a straight face and a laughing image of the same person. The more posts that are uploaded on Instagram, the more the facial recognition algorithm learns about the face.

The primary purpose of this technology is authentication and identification of a person. Authentication of an individual is a one-to-one verification process where the authenticating agency knows what it is searching for. For instance, at an immigration counter, the face of a traveller is scanned against the face of the person who he claims to be in the system. Identification of an individual is a one-to-many process where the identifier does not know the person being searched, like the identification of a suspect within a database of criminals.

There are two categories of players in this game – big tech and social media companies and the State.

Being a tech and social media giant like Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft is a huge advantage. Massive amounts of voluntary, in-coming facial images have created a global database. Facebook's facial recognition system known as DeepFace[6] uses the tech to enrich the user experience on its platform. The rate of accuracy with which Facebook prompts the user with the name of the person in an image, has increased significantly over the years, and trained on large datasets of faces to reach an accuracy of 97.35% today.

Streaming services such as Amazon Prime Videoleverages an in-house Amazon product called X-Ray[7] to help the viewer identify the celebrity of screen. It uses the movie cataloguing website IMDB, also owned by Amazon, as the backend database for this process.

Amazon sells its facial recognition software called, Rekognition.[8] Amazon Rekognition claims to identify objects, people, scenes. It can also detect emotions such as happiness or sadness on people's faces.Microsoft provides an API (Application Programmig Interface) called Face,[9] a re-usable code which can be downloaded by a customer for facial analysis. Age, emotion, pose, smile, facial hair and other features can be determined with Microsoft Face.

These companies have major customers: governments across the world.[10] [11] Their many agencies use facial recognition to provide government services and national security. The recent controversy surrounding police departments in the U.S using ClearviewAI software, a U.S. based surveillance company, to quell public protests,[12] [13] has brought to the forefront of the wide usage of such technology.

Facial recognition tech is a favourite policing tool because all current identification systems require close proximity between the person and the device. For instance, fingerprints require a person to touch a scanner; iris scanner, though contactless, requires a person to be near the scanner. Facial recognition allows identification from afar, eliminating the need for person-device proximity.

This gives the state unprecedented power over its citizens. The virtuous use of tracking and identifying criminals can easily convert into profiling citizens taking part in protests. For this very reason, the Chinese government banned the use of masks in the Hong Kong protest.[14] It's easier to pick protestors once their facial image from a protest is captured and mapped against a database of citizen's photos.

This problem multiplies manifold when the tech companies and government are intertwined. The Chinese government uses Face++ a product from Megvii,[15] a Facial recognition AI software company based in Beijing. Other Chinese companies such as Yitu[16] and SenseTime[17] also produce this tech which can be easily used for mass surveillance. China is accused of using this technology for the religious profiling of its Uighur population.[18] The fear of such abuse has resulted in many states in the U.S. such as Californiato ban this technology in police body cameras.[19] Regional bodies like the European Union are still debating whether to adopt this technology[20] or not.

Others are moving ahead. Russian courts in March 2020[21] have struck down a challenge to the use of facial recognition tech.[22] [23] Malaysia, Uganda, Zimbabwe have tied up with Chinese companies to implement facial recognition.[24] India's National Crime Records Bureau plans to implement a country wide automated facial recognition system (AFRS). It has released a tender for proposals from tech companies for it.[25]

The technology has still not been perfected, though. A major challenge is the problem of misidentification, especially for women and individuals with darker skin tone. For instance, Amazon's Rekognition falsely identified 28 non-white U.S. lawmakers as criminals. A study by MIT and Microsoft found an error rate of 35% for darker skinned women.[26] [27]

The fear of a dystopian world is legitimate, especially if the technology is not fool-proof. Though facial images are considered sensitive biometric data as per Europe's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and India's Personal Data Protection Bill 2019, these regulations exempt government agencies from their purview, on grounds of public safety and national security. India needs to be particularly careful because it is a heterogenous country, with varied ethnicities and facial types. Till the technology matures, facial recognition should be used only as a medium of screening individuals, along with other identity verification methods.

urn:contentItem:5V3Y-2821-F021-61V2-00000-00Revisiting the themes of 20182019-01-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisRevisiting the themes of 2018IC companies team

In common with past years, our recent bumper Christmas edition looked at the state of investing in 2018, and what might be in store in 2019. We also ran the rule over our tips of the week in a year when bullishness appeared to run out of steam.

It's important to be honest about how those tips performed, and how we can learn from their timing and analysis. But to focus only on binary market calls would downplay much of what the Investors Chronicle does, which often involves a lot more nuance.

With this in mind, we are revisiting several of our recent cover features - from the FAANGs to property and bitcoin to banking - to test, review and update our thinking on the themes that caught our attention in 2018.

Retail and urban logistics performed as we expected, although the number of retailers seeking protection through company voluntary arrangements was worryingly high Well-forecasted Our fundamental take on what would happen in the real estate market in 2018 ('The property forecast', February) proved to be broadly spot on, assuming you live in the real world. However, sentiment provided the key factor in how share prices performed. In short, those sectors seen as most vulnerable to the disruption created by a messy Brexit took a hit, and discounts to net asset value (NAV) widened accordingly, even in sectors such as primary healthcare where the Brexit question is largely irrelevant.Retail and urban logistics performed as we expected, although the number of retailers seeking protection through company voluntary arrangements was worryingly high. Some retail landlords have yet to wake up to the trend towards e-commerce, or at least have left it too late. Troubled landlord Intu (INTU) was given a lifeline after a bid from Hammerson, but that turned sour and shares in Intu ended the year down 25 per cent. Conversely, the big-box landlords such as   Tritax Big Box (BBOX) and   LondonMetric (LMP) benefited from ever-increasing demand for warehouse space, although this didn't stop Tritax's share price from taking a hit.Much as we pointed out last year, life in the London office market continued to prosper, giving a clear signal that the idea that a rush for the exit would devastate the market was just plain wrong. The landlords did react, however, with speculative projects being wound down, which ironically will help to support rents as supply dries up. Outside London, the big catch-up continues, with cities such as Manchester and Leeds really buzzing. Office space has also been reduced through use of permitted development rights, which allows it to be converted to residential use.And the residential side continues to change. Institutional funds have found a conduit into the build-to-rent sector in an attempt to generate a decent return at a time when gilt-edged stock yields remain nominal, or in some cases negative, when adjusted for inflation. For the likes of east-London-focused builder   Telford Homes (TEF) this capital-light model, whereby the build schemes are forward funded by the institutional landlord, has formed a growing part of the business model.The Brexit poison even managed to permeate the healthcare sector, with the three quoted primary healthcare centre providers,   Primary Health Properties (PHP),   Assura (AGR) and   MedicXFund (MXF), all losing ground on their share prices despite being one of the most defensive boltholes in the real estate market.Brexit doesn't stop people getting older and seeking medical attention, and modern healthcare centres are a key factor in helping to take pressure off A&E units. And the vast majority of the rental income generated is paid for indirectly by HM Treasury. Rent reviews are starting to show open-market rents moving higher, while other rents are linked to inflation. Student accommodation provided one of the bright spots as share prices in companies such as on Unite (UTG) finished up on the year, with demand for quality student digs expected to continue. JCFAANGs finally fumbleWe were perhaps hasty when we suggested investors should approach super hot US tech with caution ('   Fear the FAANGs', March). For the first half of 2018, these five US giants - Facebook (US:FB), Apple (US:AAPL), Amazon (US:AMZN), Netflix (US:NFLX) and Google-owner Alphabet (US:GOOGL) - drivers of the longest bull run in history and widely heralded symbols of success in corporate America - looked unstoppable.Apple and Amazon smashed through the hotly anticipated $1 trillion market capitalisation barrier after reporting solid second-quarter earnings in August. At that point, Amazon's share price had risen more than 75 per cent since the start of the year, second only (among the five FAANGs) to Netflix, which was up 202 per cent.Even Facebook and Alphabet, which had been targeted by European regulators for several months, were shrugging off concerns. Between 27 March and 25 July - while Mark Zuckerberg was attempting to explain to global governments why the personal data of 50m Facebook users had been mined by Cambridge Analytica for political activity - his company's share price climbed 42 per cent.But as the heat of the summer began to fade and global stock markets started to get the jitters, our March concerns were vindicated. By November, the share prices of all five of the FAANG companies had fallen more than 20 per cent from their peaks, losing the equivalent value of half the FTSE 100 index. In the past few months, a shift in sentiment has made investors far less forgiving of mistakes. Netflix shares were hammered when the online streaming group missed expectations for subscriber growth over the summer. Facebook has finally succumbed to a negative regulatory outlook, which also seems to be hurting its daily user count. In mid October, Alphabet and Amazon - long-time stalwarts of impressive revenue growth - reported that they had failed to hit top-line expectations, and Apple's omission of sales volumes has been widely interpreted as a sign that the world has finally reached peak iPhone. Even with the recent share price fall, investors who buy shares in Amazon today are betting on eye-watering levels of multi-decade growth in profits Macroeconomic volatility seems to have put an end to (or at least paused) a strong period of market growth. And if that is the case, the FAANG stocks simply look too expensive to keep attracting investment. Even with the recent share price fall, investors who buy shares in Amazon today are betting on eye-watering levels of multi-decade growth in profits.That feeds into the second fear flagged in our March feature: that big tech has been a major beneficiary of passive momentum. That's fine during the good times and further inflows are a given. But in indices weighted according to market value, the share of overvalued stocks is likely to decline if sentiment turns and the markets begin to fall. According to JPMorgan flows strategist Nikolaos Panigirtzoglou, the worst recent sell-offs occurred when equity exchange traded funds (ETFs) suffered the biggest outflows. We're not at that stage yet, but it's worth being wary that the tide is turning on a wonderful few years of growth. Investors who looked at the FAANGs as stalwarts of growth and momentum should (still) proceed with caution. MBBanks held back by geopolitical tumultEarlier this year the valuation gap between shares in UK-listed banking giants and their challengers had narrowed considerably. After almost a decade of being punished by investors for a litany of provisions and impairments that culled profitability, share valuations for the big five major banks began rising. Meanwhile, those of alternative lenders - which had traditionally traded at a substantial premium thanks to a track record of delivering high returns on equity, solid loan book growth and decent dividend yields - began to be priced for lower growth. Against this backdrop ('   The Banks Strike Back', April), we questioned whether this reversal in ratings was deserved and was likely to continue in the longer term.In fact, geopolitical events and subsequent concerns around the outlook for the global economy have overtaken the underlying operating performance of both sets of lenders. For domestically focused lenders such as   Lloyds (LLOY),   Barclays (BARC) and   Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS), fears of a Brexit-induced worsening in the UK economy and ensuing rise in loan defaults have left shares in all three trading at near-12-month lows. Alternative lenders such as   OneSavings Bank (OSB) - which specialise in buy-to-let mortgages and asset finance - have not escaped that downturn in confidence. Meanwhile the ongoing US-China trade spat and slowdown in Chinese economic and credit growth have had a similar effect on the valuations of   Standard Chartered (STAN) and   HSBC (HSBA). That bearishness is understandable given geopolitical uncertainty, but it belies a relatively solid performance by lenders big and small. RBS returned to paying dividends for the first time in a decade after settling with the US Department of Justice over alleged historic mis-selling of mortgage-backed securities, while improving returns on equity and regulatory capital levels meant Standard Chartered also recommenced dividend payments. There were also glimmers of hope for Barclays' investment banking operations, which had dragged down the group's return on equity. Pre-tax profits here were up 9 per cent during the first nine months of the year and the return on average allocated tangible equity rose to 9.6 per cent from 8.4 per cent in the prior year. However, margin pressures remain across the sector. For larger banks, pain has come from an increasingly competitive mortgage market and the gradual run-off of higher-yielding back books. Meanwhile, alternative lenders have continued to limit the amount of asset and motor finance business they write. That has borne fruit for those with the biggest exposure to those markets -   Close Brothers' (CBG) net interest margin has stabilised at 8 per cent, while   Secure Trust's (STB) cost of risk (impairment losses as a percentage of the loan book) reduced to 1.9 per cent during the first half, from 2.5 per cent in the prior year. For now, impairment levels remain benign for both sets of lenders, but that could change if predictions of a slowdown in global growth prove well-founded. EPSpeculative capitalWhat happens when one throws all traditional investment criteria out of the window? We tested this approach ('   Sink or swim', June), and tried to identify Alternative Investment Market (Aim) stocks with high-growth potential but which might have been eliminated via a normal vetting process.We devised a new, counterintuitive form of analysis - looking for businesses with zero, or low, revenues; those for which analysts expected huge revenue growth; and those operating in particularly niche fields.Then we considered the pros and cons of a number of stocks within these categories. Could they really achieve their anticipated heights? Given the enhanced risk arguably tied to these small-caps, we eschewed our typical 'buy', 'hold' and 'sell' stamps - instead employing the terms 'sink' and 'swim'.Two of those companies highlighted the risks of a definitive call either way, and just how unpredictable 'all-or-nothing' investments can be.   Xeros (XSG), a developer of polymer beads and associated technologies for the commercial laundry and tannery industries, reducing the water and energy used in cleaning processes, was a case in point, and one stock we thought would swim. We recognised the company's lack of full commercialisation, and the possibility it might need more cash, but concluded that its market opportunity looked significant, especially amidst heightening global concerns around water shortages.Xeros's half-year results to June revealed an 81 per cent rise in revenues to £1.87m, helped by sales of commercial laundry machines in hotels and lodgings. Service income also more than doubled. Meanwhile, joint house broker Berenberg noted that domestic laundry is "where the value is", estimating that the addressable market here is worth over £2.8bn in annual royalty fees worldwide. But the slide has been inexorable, and notwithstanding recent agreements signed, the shares are now down over 90 per cent in the year to date. Tuesday 27 November saw a major decline on the news of a proposed placing and open offer to raise around £20m at a deeply discounted price.Conversely, our doubts over   OptiBiotix (OPTI) - a developer of compounds to modify the human microbiome's response to certain diseases - proved overly sceptical. At the time, we were concerned by house broker FinnCap's lack of future financial estimates, and analyst comments that the early-stage nature of OptiBiotix's contracts made it "difficult to forecast with any degree of certainty". However, the group successfully raised cash in May, implying shareholder enthusiasm. But we perceived the potential for diversification, with OptiBiotix having various specialist tech platforms. It had already floated   SkinBioTherapeutics (SBTX) separately, retaining a stake.Half a year on, and 2018 can be said to have been a success. OptiBiotix has signed 18 agreements this year, including a US manufacturing and supply deal with US Pharma Lab Inc - which the company says gives it strategic access to the world's largest probiotic market. It has also created another wholly owned subsidiary, ProBiotix, which could ultimately list. We're still wary about the absence of forecasts and, on that basis, wouldn't buy into OptiBiotix at this stage. But for current shareholders with high risk thresholds, it could be interesting to hang on as OptiBiotix pursues its transition from development to commercialisation. The shares are up around 30 per cent in the year to date. HC There are some signs that a previously super-hot US economy could slow in the coming year The contrarian takeDid it pay to be hedged in the second half of 2018? Six months ago ('   How to be a contrarian', June), we walked readers through several bearish investing strategies, all of which explored ways of reducing overall portfolio risk. It's early days, but the results have been encouraging thus far.The first was a medium-term bet against US equities. Our thinking - that an already overvalued share market could suffer once the sugar rush of the Trump administration's massive tax cut faded - has not yet come to pass. But there are some signs that a previously super-hot US economy could slow in the coming year: capital spending is slowing, and projections for consumer spending are thinning. Some of these nerves were probably reflected in October's sell-off, which has left the S&P 500 index slightly down since June.Second, we argued that China's staggering debt levels could ultimately lead to pressure on the renminbi. Ultimately, an export-focused nation such as China is not averse to its currency weakening, but what matters to foreign exchange traders is the rate at which currencies move relative to one another. And for the renminbi, the currency that matters most is its chief competitor, the US dollar.So far, the short yuan/long dollar trade we highlighted has worked, whether or not it is China's indebtedness that has moved the market, or the ever-strengthening greenback. In fact, the renminbi is 9 per cent down on the dollar since our feature.The third call was a bullish long-term view on gold, which we highlighted for its strong track record as a hedge in a multi-polar multi-currency financial system. Over the past 25 years, gold has outperformed all major currencies, and it is that sort of timeframe we see as appropriate for the yellow metal, particularly in its raw commodity form. Since June, gold has held up in sterling terms, but drifted in its most-followed denomination - the US dollar - largely thanks to the availability of higher-yielding 'risk-free' assets.A bullish call on grain prices has also gone sideways, although it's hard to imagine this remaining the case indefinitely. As a recent report by the InterAcademy Partnership made clear, the global food system looks set to struggle to mitigate the increasingly dire effects of climate change and water insecurity, and all that implies for crop yields.In short, it is probably too early to say too much about most of our calls. But that doesn't mean contrarian takes need years to pay off. As part of the feature, we also compiled a list of London's 10 most-shorted stocks at the time, based on fund disclosures of any short position equivalent to at least 0.5 per cent of a company's market capitalisation. Although the bearish calls had been volatile in the year to June, the mini-portfolio has been largely vindicated in the months since.On average, the stocks have shed 19 per cent of their value in the half-year since we wrote the piece, with   Debenhams (DEB) and   Restaurant Group (RTN) shedding 70 and 53 per cent, respectively. Only three of the companies -   Marks & Spencer (MKS),   Greencore(GNC) and   Aggreko(AGK) - saw their share prices rise, and then only by single digits. Investors in construction firm   Kier Group (KIE), now at the top of the most-shorted list, should take note. ANA reliable betIn May, the US Supreme Court overturned the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act (PASPA), leaving it up to individual states to set their own rules on sports betting. Since writing about the ruling shortly after it was made ('Gambling's American dream', June), UK gambling companies have been eager to take advantage of the new frontier of US sports betting, teaming up with American operators rather than cracking the market individually. These opportunities have become ever more important for the UK bookies as gambling regulations in the UK have tightened. And just as we thought, the UK bookies clearly believe in the American dream.For   GVC (GVC) chief executive Kenny Alexander, the repeal of PASPA will make the US the world's biggest regulated market for gambling within five years. His company has wasted no time swooping in on the US market, signing a 50:50 joint venture with MGM resorts in August. The partnership will combine MGM's brand and multi-state licences with GVC's technology; each will invest an initial $100m (£79.2m) to create an industry-leading sports betting and online gambling platform.Not to be overshadowed,   William Hill (WMH) signed a deal with casino group Eldorado Resorts for digital- and land-based sports betting and online gaming across Eldorado's 21 properties across 11 states. The partnership initially gives William Hill access to 23m US customers, a number that is likely to increase once Eldorado completes the acquisition of Tropicana Entertainment.   Paddy Power Betfair (PPB) has had a tougher time breaking into the US market. It completed the acquisition of US fantasy sports website FanDuel in July, but losses are now expected in the second half due to the seasonality of fantasy sports. Management had expected the deal to be immediately earnings accretive.Meanwhile, the UK bookies are bracing for the impact of the stake cut on fixed-odds betting terminals (FOBTs) from £100 to £2. The cut comes into effect in April 2019, and is expected to shrink cash profits at GVC's UK retail division by around 15per cent.William Hill was forced to impair the value of its UK retail assets by a mammoth £883m as a result of the FOBT decision. It's estimated that total net gaming revenue could fall by between 35 per cent and 45 per cent, while adjusted operating profits could drop by anything between £70m and £100m, and could prompt up to 900 shop closures.And on top of the FOBT stake change, the bookies will also soon face an increase in offshore gaming duty. At the time of our feature, we speculated that this tax could be increased to make up forsome of the lost taxes from FOBTs. Indeed, in the recent Budget Chancellor Philip Hammond announced an increase in the tax from 15 per cent to 21 per cent.This continued crackdown on gambling in the UK is likely to push the bookies to focus any global expansion plans even more heavily on the US. The dealmaking does not look set to slow down anytime soon. JF The Financial Conduct Authority, which doesn't regulate bitcoin but has authority over some cryptocurrency derivatives, has repeatedly issued warnings on scams

Why Bitcoin is on life support

Just over a year ago, we cautioned investors to be wary of bitcoin ('Bitcoin: gamble or gold mine?'). Our warning came in November, and for another month or so our advice appeared to go unheeded.

The first half of December 2017 was the peak time to be a 'HODLer', as holders of bitcoin are known. In the preceding 12 months, the leading cryptocurrency had climbed an astounding 2,000 per cent in dollar terms. The lessons of the 17th century Dutch tulip mania, when a rush towards an extraordinary spike in tulip bulb prices was followed by an almighty crash, were quickly being unlearned.

And then remembered. The price of bitcoin now sags 82 per cent beneath its December 2017 peak. The situation is dire for many trusting observers, who were sold this worthless thread of computer code in exchange for their life savings. At least the tulip bulbs had some substance.

Diehard cryptofans believe that the decentralisation of currency and the end of fiat money is still inevitable. Used for years in the darkest corners of the internet to pay for drugs, hitmen and worse, cryptocurrencies will pave the way towards the democratisation of finance. There's still a pulse to bitcoin.

So, why is bitcoin on life support? Risk appetite has come down, according to Russ Mould, investment director at platform AJ Bell, owing to a tightening of monetary policies around the world and the subsequent reduction in liquidity levels.

This, he argues, has made investors more careful, and with "less cheap cash around", bitcoin took a dive. Bitcoin could rally next year, he added, "if the markets push back sufficiently on the US Federal Reserve, and the Fed bottles it".

As with most revolutions, factions emerged. In this case, thousands. Bitcoin, whose supply is capped at 21m, has been undermined by rival cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin Cash, which 'forked' off. Initial coin offerings (ICOs), which launch new cryptos, were banned in 2017 in China and South Korea. The Financial Conduct Authority, which doesn't regulate bitcoin but has authority over some cryptocurrency derivatives, has repeatedly issued warnings on scams.

Given the zeal of bitcoin's supporters, its decline and fall might have appeared funny to those watching from the sidelines. But reports of believers who sunk their life savings into bitcoin render it a tragedy. Neither should one ignore the huge energy output needed to extract bitcoin; coal mining and oil drilling are dirty businesses with terrible environmental consequences, but at least the end products provide fuel. Bitcoin appears to have fuelled little but manic speculation.

The arrogant techno-punks who pumped this garbage to the general public won't be held to account. A rally is possible, but unlikely, and given the lack of regulation, we hope bitcoin goes away. Gold bars would've been a better investment for the buyers. Bars of another kind would be more suitable for the salesmen. AJ

urn:contentItem:5V42-M111-JCBW-N307-00000-00REVISITINGTHE THEMESOF20182019-01-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 32,33,34,35,36REVISITINGTHE THEMESOF2018

Magazines, like investors, tend to make a big fuss about year ends, and with good reason; we all need to take time to pause, think and reflect. The IC companies team reviews cover features from 2018 In common with past years, our recent bumper Christmas edition looked at the state of investing in 2018, and what might be in store in 2019. We also ran the rule over our tips of the week in a year when bullishness appeared to run out of steam.

It's important to be honest about how those tips performed, and how we can learn from their timing and analysis. But to focus only on binary market calls would downplay much of what the Investors Chronicle does, which often involves a lot more nuance.

With this in mind, we are revisiting several of our recent cover features - from the FAANGs to property and bitcoin to banking - to test, review and update our thinking on the themes that caught our attention in 2018.

Well-forecasted Our fundamental take on what would happen in the real estate market in 2018 ('The property forecast', February) proved to be broadly spot on, assuming you live in the real world. However, sentiment provided the key factor in how share prices performed. In short, those sectors seen as most vulnerable to the disruption created by a messy Brexit took a hit, and discounts to net asset value (NAV) widened accordingly, even in sectors such as primary healthcare where the Brexit question is largely irrelevant.

Retail and urban logistics performed as we expected, although the number of retailers seeking protection through company voluntary arrangements was worryingly high. Some retail landlords have yet to wake up to the trend towards e-commerce, or at least have left it too late. Troubled landlord Intu (INTU) was given a lifeline after a bid from Hammerson, but that turned sour and shares in Intu ended the year down 25 per cent. Conversely, the big-box landlords such as Tritax Big Box (BBOX) and LondonMetric (LMP) benefited from ever-increasing demand for warehouse space, although this didn't stop Tritax's share price from taking a hit.

Much as we pointed out last year, life in the London office market continued to prosper, giving a clear signal that the idea that a rush for the exit would devastate the market was just plain wrong. The landlords did react, however, with speculative projects being wound down, which ironically will help to support rents as supply dries up. Outside London, the big catch-up continues, with cities such as Manchester and Leeds really buzzing. Office space has also been reduced through use of permitted development rights, which allows it to be converted to residential use.

And the residential side continues to change. Institutional funds have found a conduit into the build-to-rent sector in an attempt to generate a decent return at a time when gilt-edged stock yields remain nominal, or in some cases negative, when adjusted for inflation. For the likes of east-Londonfocused builder Telford Homes (TEF) this capitallight model, whereby the build schemes are forward funded by the institutional landlord, has formed a growing part of the business model.

The Brexit poison even managed to permeate the healthcare sector, with the three quoted primary healthcare centre providers, Primary Health Properties (PHP), Assura (AGR) and MedicXFund (MXF), all losing ground on their share prices despite being one of the most defensive boltholes in the real estate market.

Brexit doesn't stop people getting older and seeking medical attention, and modern healthcare centres are a key factor in helping to take pressure offA&E units. And the vast majority of the rental income generated is paid for indirectly by HM Treasury. Rent reviews are starting to show open-market rents moving higher, while other rents are linked to inflation. Student accommodation provided one of the bright spots as share prices in companies such as on Unite (UTG) finished up on the year, with demand for quality student digs expected to continue. JC_ FAANGs finally fumble We were perhaps hasty when we suggested investors should approach super hot US tech with caution ('Fear the FAANGs', March). For the first half of 2018, these five US giants - Facebook (US:FB), Apple (US:AAPL), Amazon (US:AMZN), Netflix (US:NFLX) and Google-owner Alphabet (US:GOOGL) - drivers of the longest bull run in history and widely heralded symbols of success in corporate America - looked unstoppable.

'Even with the recent share price fall, investors who buy shares in Amazon today are betting on eye-watering levels of multidecade growth in profits' Apple and Amazon smashed through the hotly anticipated $1 trillion market capitalisation barrier after reporting solid second-quarter earnings in August. At that point, Amazon's share price had risen more than 75 per cent since the start of the year, second only (among the five FAANGs) to Netflix, which was up 202 per cent.

Even Facebook and Alphabet, which had been targeted by European regulators for several months, were shrugging offconcerns. Between 27 March and 25 July - while Mark Zuckerberg was attempting to explain to global governments why the personal data of 50m Facebook users had been mined by Cambridge Analytica for political activity - his company's share price climbed 42 per cent.

But as the heat of the summer began to fade and global stock markets started to get the jitters, our March concerns were vindicated. By November, the share prices of all five of the FAANG companies had fallen more than 20 per cent from their peaks, losing the equivalent value of half the FTSE 100 index.

In the past few months, a shift in sentiment has made investors far less forgiving of mistakes. Netflix shares were hammered when the online streaming group missed expectations for subscriber growth over the summer. Facebook has finally succumbed to a negative regulatory outlook, which also seems to be hurting its daily user count. In mid October, Alphabet and Amazon - long-time stalwarts of impressive revenue growth - reported that they had failed to hit top-line expectations, and Apple's omission of sales volumes has been widely interpreted as a sign that the world has finally reached peak iPhone.

Macroeconomic volatility seems to have put an end to (or at least paused) a strong period of market growth. And if that is the case, the FAANG stocks simply look too expensive to keep attracting investment. Even with the recent share price fall, investors who buy shares in Amazon today are betting on eyewatering levels of multi-decade growth in profits. That feeds into the second fear flagged in our March feature: that big tech has been a major beneficiary of passive momentum. That's fine during the good times and further inflows are a given. But in indices weighted according to market value, the share of overvalued stocks is likely to decline if sentiment turns and the markets begin to fall. According to JPMorgan flows strategist Nikolaos Panigirtzoglou, the worst recent sell-offs occurred when equity exchange traded funds (ETFs) suffered the biggest outflows. We're not at that stage yet, but it's worth being wary that the tide is turning on a wonderful few years of growth. Investors who looked at the FAANGs as stalwarts of growth and momentum should (still) proceed with caution. MB Banks held back by geopolitical tumult Earlier this year the valuation gap between shares in UK-listed banking giants and their challengers had narrowed considerably. After almost a decade of being punished by investors for a litany of provisions and impairments that culled profitability, share valuations for the big five major banks began rising. Meanwhile, those of alternative lenders - which had traditionally traded at a substantial premium thanks to a track record of delivering high returns on equity, solid loan book growth and decent dividend yields - began to be priced for lower growth. Against this backdrop ('The Banks Strike Back', April), we questioned whether this reversal in ratings was deserved and was likely to continue in the longer term.

In fact, geopolitical events and subsequent concerns around the outlook for the global economy have overtaken the underlying operating performance of both sets of lenders. For domestically focused lenders such as Lloyds (LLOY), Barclays (BARC) and Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS), fears of a Brexitinduced worsening in the UK economy and ensuing rise in loan defaults have left shares in all three trading at near-12-month lows. Alternative lenders such as OneSavings Bank (OSB) - which specialise in buy-to-let mortgages and asset finance - have not escaped that downturn in confidence. Meanwhile the ongoing US-China trade spat and slowdown in Chinese economic and credit growth have had a similar effect on the valuations of Standard Chartered (STAN) and HSBC (HSBA).

That bearishness is understandable given geopolitical uncertainty, but it belies a relatively solid performance by lenders big and small. RBS returned to paying dividends for the first time in a decade after settling with the US Department of Justice over alleged historic mis-selling of mortgage-backed securities, while improving returns on equity and regulatory capital levels meant Standard Chartered also recommenced dividend payments. There were also glimmers of hope for Barclays' investment banking operations, which had dragged down the group's return on equity. Pre-tax profits here were up 9 per cent during the first nine months of the year and the return on average allocated tangible equity rose to 9.6 per cent from 8.4 per cent in the prior year.

However, margin pressures remain across the sector. For larger banks, pain has come from an increasingly competitive mortgage market and the gradual run-offof higher-yielding back books. Meanwhile, alternative lenders have continued to limit the amount of asset and motor finance business they write. That has borne fruit for those with the biggest exposure to those markets - Close Brothers' (CBG) net interest margin has stabilised at 8 per cent, while Secure Trust's (STB) cost of risk (impairment losses as a percentage of the loan book) reduced to 1.9 per cent during the first half, from 2.5 per cent in the prior year. For now, impairment levels remain benign for both sets of lenders, but that could change if predictions of a slowdown in global growth prove well-founded. EP Speculative capital What happens when one throws all traditional investment criteria out of the window? We tested this approach ('Sink or swim', June), and tried to identify Alternative Investment Market (Aim) stocks with high-growth potential but which might have been eliminated via a normal vetting process.

We devised a new, counterintuitive form of analysis - looking for businesses with zero, or low, revenues; those for which analysts expected huge revenue growth; and those operating in particularly niche fields.

Then we considered the pros and cons of a number of stocks within these categories. Could they really achieve their anticipated heights? Given the enhanced risk arguably tied to these small-caps, we eschewed our typical 'buy', 'hold' and 'sell' stamps - instead employing the terms 'sink' and 'swim'.

Two of those companies highlighted the risks of a definitive call either way, and just how unpredictable 'all-or-nothing' investments can be.

Xeros (XSG), a developer of polymer beads and associated technologies for the commercial laundry and tannery industries, reducing the water and energy used in cleaning processes, was a case in point, and one stock we thought would swim. We recognised the company's lack of full commercialisation, and the possibility it might need more cash, but concluded that its market opportunity looked significant, especially amidst heightening global concerns around water shortages.

Xeros's half-year results to June revealed an 81 per cent rise in revenues to £1.87m, helped by sales of commercial laundry machines in hotels and lodgings. Service income also more than doubled. Meanwhile, joint house broker Berenberg noted that domestic laundry is "where the value is", estimating that the addressable market here is worth over £2.8bn in annual royalty fees worldwide. But the slide has been inexorable, and notwithstanding recent agreements signed, the shares are now down over 90 per cent in the year to date. Tuesday 27 November saw a major decline on the news of a proposed placing and open offer to raise around £20m at a deeply discounted price.

Conversely, our doubts over OptiBiotix (OPTI) - a developer of compounds to modify the human microbiome's response to certain diseases - proved overly sceptical. At the time, we were concerned by house broker FinnCap's lack of future financial estimates, and analyst comments that the early-stage nature of OptiBiotix's contracts made it "difficult to forecast with any degree of certainty". However, the group successfully raised cash in May, implying shareholder enthusiasm. But we perceived the potential for diversification, with OptiBiotix having various specialist tech platforms. It had already floated SkinBioTherapeutics (SBTX) separately, retaining a stake.

'There are some signs that a previously super-hot US economy could slow in the coming year' Half a year on, and 2018 can be said to have been a success. OptiBiotix has signed 18 agreements this year, including a US manufacturing and supply deal with US Pharma Lab Inc - which the company says gives it strategic access to the world's largest probiotic market. It has also created another wholly owned subsidiary, ProBiotix, which could ultimately list. We're still wary about the absence of forecasts and, on that basis, wouldn't buy into OptiBiotix at this stage. But for current shareholders with high risk thresholds, it could be interesting to hang on as OptiBiotix pursues its transition from development to commercialisation. The shares are up around 30 per cent in the year to date. HC The contrarian take Did it pay to be hedged in the second half of 2018? Six months ago ('How to be a contrarian', June), we walked readers through several bearish investing strategies, all of which explored ways of reducing overall portfolio risk. It's early days, but the results have been encouraging thus far.

The first was a medium-term bet against US equities. Our thinking - that an already overvalued share market could suffer once the sugar rush of the Trump administration's massive tax cut faded - has not yet come to pass. But there are some signs that a previously super-hot US economy could slow in the coming year: capital spending is slowing, and projections for consumer spending are thinning. Some of these nerves were probably reflected in October's sell-off, which has left the S&P 500 index slightly down since June.

Second, we argued that China's staggering debt levels could ultimately lead to pressure on the renminbi. Ultimately, an export-focused nation such as China is not averse to its currency weakening, but what matters to foreign exchange traders is the rate at which currencies move relative to one another. And for the renminbi, the currency that matters most is its chief competitor, the US dollar.

So far, the short yuan/long dollar trade we highlighted has worked, whether or not it is China's indebtedness that has moved the market, or the ever-strengthening greenback. In fact, the renminbi is 9 per cent down on the dollar since our feature.

The third call was a bullish long-term view on gold, which we highlighted for its strong track record as a hedge in a multi-polar multi-currency financial system. Over the past 25 years, gold has outperformed all major currencies, and it is that sort of timeframe we see as appropriate for the yellow metal, particularly in its raw commodity form. Since June, gold has held up in sterling terms, but drifted in its most-followed denomination - the US dollar - largely thanks to the availability of higher-yielding 'risk-free' assets.

A bullish call on grain prices has also gone sideways, although it's hard to imagine this remaining the case indefinitely. As a recent report by the InterAcademy Partnership made clear, the global food system looks set to struggle to mitigate the increasingly dire effects of climate change and water insecurity, and all that implies for crop yields.

In short, it is probably too early to say too much about most of our calls. But that doesn't mean contrarian takes need years to pay off. As part of the feature, we also compiled a list of London's 10 most-shorted stocks at the time, based on fund disclosures of any short position equivalent to at least 0.5 per cent of a company's market capitalisation. Although the bearish calls had been volatile in the year to June, the mini-portfolio has been largely vindicated in the months since.

On average, the stocks have shed 19 per cent of their value in the half-year since we wrote the piece, with Debenhams (DEB) and Restaurant Group (RTN) shedding 70 and 53 per cent, respectively. Only three of the companies - Marks and Spencer (MKS), Greencore (GNC) and Aggreko (AGK) - saw their share prices rise, and then only by single digits. Investors in construction firm Kier Group (KIE), now at the top of the most-shorted list, should take note. AN A reliable bet In May, the US Supreme Court overturned the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act (PASPA), leaving it up to individual states to set their own rules on sports betting. Since writing about the ruling shortly after it was made ('Gambling's American dream', June), UK gambling companies have been eager to take advantage of the new frontier of US sports betting, teaming up with American operators rather than cracking the market individually. These opportunities have become ever more important for the UK bookies as gambling regulations in the UK have tightened. And just as we thought, the UK bookies clearly believe in the American dream.

For GVC (GVC) chief executive Kenny Alexander, the repeal of PASPA will make the US the world's biggest regulated market for gambling within five years. His company has wasted no time swooping in on the US market, signing a 50:50 joint venture with MGM resorts in August. The partnership will combine MGM's brand and multi-state licences with GVC's technology; each will invest an initial $100m (£79.2m) to create an industry-leading sports betting and online gambling platform.

Not to be overshadowed, William Hill (WMH) signed a deal with casino group Eldorado Resorts for digital-and land-based sports betting and online gaming across Eldorado's 21 properties across 11 states. The partnership initially gives William Hill access to 23m US customers, a number that is likely to increase once Eldorado completes the acquisition of Tropicana Entertainment.

Paddy Power Betfair (PPB) has had a tougher time breaking into the US market. It completed the acquisition of US fantasy sports website FanDuel in July, but losses are now expected in the second half due to the seasonality of fantasy sports. Management had expected the deal to be immediately earnings accretive.

Meanwhile, the UK bookies are bracing for the impact of the stake cut on fixed-odds betting terminals (FOBTs) from £100 to £2. The cut comes into effect in April 2019, and is expected to shrink cash profits at GVC's UK retail division by around 15 per cent.

William Hill was forced to impair the value of its UK retail assets by a mammoth £883m as a result of the FOBT decision. It's estimated that total net gaming revenue could fall by between 35 per cent and 45 per cent, while adjusted operating profits could drop by anything between £70m and £100m, and could prompt up to 900 shop closures.

And on top of the FOBT stake change, the bookies will also soon face an increase in offshore gaming duty. At the time of our feature, we speculated that this tax could be increased to make up for some of the lost taxes from FOBTs. Indeed, in the recent Budget Chancellor Philip Hammond announced an increase in the tax from 15 per cent to 21 per cent.

This continued crackdown on gambling in the UK is likely to push the bookies to focus any global expansion plans even more heavily on the US. The dealmaking does not look set to slow down anytime soon. JF Why Bitcoin is on life support Just over a year ago, we cautioned investors to be wary of bitcoin ('Bitcoin: gamble or gold mine?'). Our warning came in November, and for another month or so our advice appeared to go unheeded.

The first half of December 2017 was the peak time to be a 'HODLer', as holders of bitcoin are known. In the preceding 12 months, the leading cryptocurrency had climbed an astounding 2,000 per cent in dollar terms. The lessons of the 17th century Dutch tulip mania, when a rush towards an extraordinary spike in tulip bulb prices was followed by an almighty crash, were quickly being unlearned.

And then remembered. The price of bitcoin now sags 82 per cent beneath its December 2017 peak. The situation is dire for many trusting observers, who were sold this worthless thread of computer code in exchange for their life savings. At least the tulip bulbs had some substance.

Diehard cryptofans believe that the decentralisation of currency and the end of fiat money is still inevitable. Used for years in the darkest corners of the internet to pay for drugs, hitmen and worse, cryptocurrencies will pave the way towards the democratisation of finance. There's still a pulse to bitcoin. So, why is bitcoin on life support? Risk appetite has come down, according to Russ Mould, investment director at platform AJ Bell, owing to a tightening of monetary policies around the world and the subsequent reduction in liquidity levels.

This, he argues, has made investors more careful, and with "less cheap cash around", bitcoin took a dive. Bitcoin could rally next year, he added, "if the markets push back sufficiently on the US Federal Reserve, and the Fed bottles it".

As with most revolutions, factions emerged. In this case, thousands. Bitcoin, whose supply is capped at 21m, has been undermined by rival cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin Cash, which 'forked' off. Initial coin offerings (ICOs), which launch new cryptos, were banned in 2017 in China and South Korea. The Financial Conduct Authority, which doesn't regulate bitcoin but has authority over some cryptocurrency derivatives, has repeatedly issued warnings on scams.

Given the zeal of bitcoin's supporters, its decline and fall might have appeared funny to those watching from the sidelines. But reports of believers who sunk their life savings into bitcoin render it a tragedy. Neither should one ignore the huge energy output needed to extract bitcoin; coal mining and oil drilling are dirty businesses with terrible environmental consequences, but at least the end products provide fuel. Bitcoin appears to have fuelled little but manic speculation.

The arrogant techno-punks who pumped this garbage to the general public won't be held to account. A rally is possible, but unlikely, and given the lack of regulation, we hope bitcoin goes away. Gold bars would've been a better investment for the buyers. Bars of another kind would be more suitable for the salesmen. AJ

urn:contentItem:5TJ4-1F51-JD34-V2N8-00000-00Revolut a grim arrival for big banks2018-10-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisFINANCIAL SERVICESPg. 16Revolut a grim arrival for big banksJames Eyers

Technology | An upstart hopes to become the 'Amazon of finance'.

"I never want Revolut to be referring to itself as a bank," says its head of marketing, Chad West. "We are an alternative to a bank. We are completely different."

Revolut, headquartered in London, was only founded three years ago; it now has over 3 million customers in Europe, a number that has doubled over the past nine months.

The neobank is attracting 7000 new customers each day, and expects this will be 10,000 by the end of this year.

In April it secured $US250 million in fresh venture capital funding for global expansion, at a valuation of $US1.7 billion. It's the fastest-growing unicorn tech company in Europe.

And according to its website, Revolut is about to land down under. Ominously for the major banks, without any advertising, 20,000 Australians have already signed up to its waiting list.

Revolut expects to have a prepaid debit card live in the Australian market by the end of the year. It will launch in the new year and is targeting 150,000 local users by the end of 2019. It's also taking on New Zealand, part of an ambitious plan to also capture Millennial customers in the United States, Canada, Hong Kong and Singapore.

Mr West reckons timing for the Australian launch is solid. The loss of trust in the big four banks on the back of the Hayne commission should help it lure customers away from the incumbents, he says.

"When we launch in Australia, our main goal is to be an alternative to traditional banks. We are very anti-bank, and people have really resonated with that," Mr West says in an exclusive interview with The Australian Financial Review from London, ahead of an appearance at the Intersekt Festival in Melbourne on October 29, where he is delivering a keynote address.

Revolut's arrival will also worry other budding neobanks in Australia, such as Volt, Xinja and 86 400, which are also trying to lure Millennials away from the big four. The rise of "challenger banks" will be discussed at this week's Sibos conference in Sydney.

Revolut has already secured the necessary licensing in Australia for its payments cards by piggybacking off an AFSL licence held by an existing bank that Mr West declined to name.

It plans to use the new start-up bank licensing regime established by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority and become an "authorised deposit-taking institution" (ADI), which would allow it to take deposits.

Revolut built up its big customer numbers in Europe by providing an ultra-low-cost foreign exchange options for travellers. Its cards have no fees for overseas withdrawals and transfers, and exchange rates are the same banks get in wholesale markets. This will also be the case in Australia.

Revolut was also able to scale because its banking application was better than those offered by the British and European incumbents - something that will be harder in Australia, given the big tech investment by the majors on their banking applications.

Mr West agrees Australian banks "are certainly better than UK banks and most European banks". But he adds "they are still nothing special".

"None of them are offering the real, in-depth analytics we are offering on spending, none are even close on the FX spreads, none of them have an app designed as beautifully as ours."

Revolut has aspirations to become the "Amazon of finance". Pressed to explain, Mr West says customers don't want half-a-dozen apps on their phone managing different elements of their financial life. "They want to have everything centralised in one brand they know that they trust.

"Customer are becoming lazy and expecting more from the services they use. I don't want my bank to bombard me with offers. I want to give my bank my criteria and to give me one solution right to me that matches my criteria."

The philosophy of Revolut is more tech than fin. "We are a tech company first and foremost. We are redefining banking on a global scale," he says.

Like Netflix and Spotify, Revolut is pushing towards a subscription-based model: it has 150,000 customers paying £6.99 a month; and 80,000 paying £12.99 a month. These include all-you-can-eat insurance deals, personal concierges and cashback offers. Like Uber and Amazon, Revolut has no plans to become profitable any time soon.

Mr West says Revolut doesn't consider banks its main competition - rather, it will come from Facebook and Amazon "when they inevitably break into finance". Oozing confidence, he says "with our capital, brand awareness and unique style marketing, we won't struggle to win the Australian market over".
