urn:contentItem:5RXW-G9P1-JBHT-D38H-00000-00Richard Windsor and Erik Nielsen are on BB Surveillance.2018-03-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisRichard Windsor and Erik Nielsen are on BB Surveillance.WalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

RICHARD WINDSOR, FOUNDER, RADIO FREE MOBILE; AND ERIK NIELSEN, CHIEF ECONOMIST, UNICREDIT GROUP; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BB SURVEILLANCE

MARCH 20, 2018

SPEAKERS: RICHARD WINDSOR, FOUNDER, RADIO FREE MOBILE

ERIK NIELSEN, CHIEF ECONOMIST, UNICREDIT GROUP

GUY JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Joining us from Dubai is Richard Windsor, he's founder of Radio Free Mobile, he (INAUDIBLE) top tech. Also with us for the hour, he is Erik Nielsen and he is Unicredit Group Chief Economist.

So, Erik, thank you so much. Stay there, because we'll get to you in a second.

Richard, when it comes to the tech selloff --

RICHARD WINDSOR, FOUNDER, RADIO FREE MOBILE: Good morning.

LACQUA: -- what exactly -- good morning to you -- what exactly freaked the markets? Is it that, you know, had a trajectory, where a lot of these stocks were going when you were driverless cars could go now next and now it's all hanging up in the air?

WINDSOR: No, I think you got a number of factors. I mean you've had the really large -- the really tech companies that have had, you know, one of the greatest runs they've ever had. You've got the prospect of increasing interest rates.

And then also, if you look at the stocks that are dependent on monetization of user data like Google and Facebook and Twitter, these are the ones that have most impacted. So I suspect it's more about these factors, combined with increasing fear of regulation in terms of what people can and cannot do with data that has been given to them by users that are causing the problems.

LACQUA: Yes, we also heard that the E.U. was probably considering a digital tax as a trade to this few (ph) kind of rages on. What would that look like?

WINDSOR: Great question. Very difficult to tell, I mean, I guess what they would look to do would be to impose a tax on revenues that have been derived in the region. That would be the simplest way of doing it as I presume.

But overall, I mean, my personal opinion is hold data issue is it will eventually blow over. And the reason why it will blow over is because there's a fundamental misunderstanding in my opinion in terms of how the internet works and users seem to have the opinion that the internet is free, isn't and never has been. What you're actually doing is just paying for service with personal data.

Once users get more accustomed to that, then I think that there will be an easier situation where you can choose. You pay the cash or you pay with personal data, and that's how I think it's going to evolve going forward.

GUY JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Do you value these companies though at the same level if that is the case? Because, as you say, at the moment, there is this misapprehension that the service is free. But basically these are data monetization companies.

WINDSOR: Exactly. And actually, I think it is. As a matter of fact, the research that Radio Free Mobile has done over the last five years actually (INAUDIBLE) this out, which is that, you know, you have a choice. Let's just take for example, Google. Google has a choice. You could basically come to Google and say yes, you can use my personal data and I will use -- get your services for free or I don't want you to use my personal data, I'll tell you what, I'll pay you $5 a month for the service.

Now, obviously, these companies would set the pricing of that service at the level at which there should be no real impact on revenue overall.

JOHNSON: Do you think there's a breakup risk here, Richard?

WINDSOR: In terms of?

JOHNSON: Are these companies too big, too powerful, somebody pointed out to me earlier on, they spend a huge amount of money in terms of lobbying in Washington. They control huge sways (ph) of the technology sector across the United States and across the world. We've seen it in history, when companies and sectors become too big, there is a regulatory impetus that starts but ultimately ends up leading to breakup.

WINDSOR: I think it's this possibility, but it's a very distinct possibility. If you look at Google, your first question want to ask is, well, what am I going to break it up into? Because, you know, and there is a reasonable argument in this level of Google that it is a one-trick pony, but it does search and everything else is fairly minor.

As a result of that, you would have great difficulty breaking that up into its constituent parts. In the same, you could level exactly the same accusation at Facebook. Facebook generates almost all of its revenue off its social network, so the question is, what would you break it up into?

LACQUA: Let's also bring Erik Nielsen of Unicredit into the conversation. Erik, I know you don't look at this thing day out, but you must have a view on driverless cars and automation and even the end of cash, and the impact it has on the economy in 5, 10, 15 years. Does anything that happens in the last, you know, the last couple of days change that deal?

ERIK NIELSEN, CHIEF ECONOMIST, UNICREDIT GROUP: I'm getting more and more nervous. I think we had maybe an overshot in terms of globalization after the crisis and through the crisis sort of extent and I see a lot of winding back of this. And I think what you're referring to and what we just talked about on the -- in the I.T. industry and the tech industries. I share sort of guy sort of skepticism here.

I mean, to some extent, these companies have been broken up in the sense that they're not free to operate in China and Russia, for example, right? There are positive words that we don't want this, right, and all the Europeans are saying a little bit, I don't really think you pay enough taxes because you shoveling through islands, so maybe, so we should say exactly as Richard said, maybe we should tax the pays with the revenues come in.

But this whole thing is not a smooth process, right? So you have to worry a little about this sort of how that impacts the economy in a negative way.

JOHNSON: But we find ourselves in a situation where the Chinese, as long as you got -- they two sort of two buckets of tech stocks around the world at the moment, you got the kind of the U.S. bucket and you got the Asian bucket, which is largely the Chinese buckets.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: Europe doesn't have much.

NIELSEN: No.

JOHNSON: So it kind of falls into one of those two. The Chinese bucket is going to be made up of companies that are going to get bigger and, therefore, potentially stronger, whereas there is increasingly this regulatory taxation burden that is likely to be put on the U.S. once.

NIELSEN: Right.

JOHNSON: So are we putting ourselves at a disadvantage -- are we heading down the road of a kind of trade war their tech versus our tech? Are we putting ourselves at a disadvantage?

NIELSEN: I don't know if we -- yes, from a very sort of liberal kind of world view we are, in a sense, but I think what we have seen is some of the backlash to what's this in the (INAUDIBLE) of things and (INAUDIBLE) now where these companies seems to be if the reporting is correct, meddling with the political process.

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: So then I think most people will think, well, then there has to be some measures to take this back, right? So I -- and that's what I meant by what I said before. I don't think that taking it, but I think politically, it's understandable and probably desirable, but it's not smooth for the economy as this happens.

LACQUA: And, Richard, what are you watching out for in the next 74 hours? Will it be testimonies to kind of exactly understand where a lot of these big companies go from here?

WINDSOR: My personal suspicion is that things are -- that, you know, you had a bit of fuzz. People start to get worried about the use of data. Obviously, actually and if you look at the data leak, there is piece of happen where at 50, I think it was 50 million accountable data and 50 million of Facebook accounts made it into a private data analysis firm.

If you actually look at Facebook has actually changed its policy so you can no longer do that. So what I suspect will actually happen is there's going to be talk, a bit of softness, but I, you know, I think at the end of the day, we're coming into earnings season. Quite possibly, we're going to have another reason a good season from the big tech companies.

So as a result of that, I suspect a small correction, but then, you know, continuation of business as normal, at least for another quarter or so.

LACQUA: All right, Richard, thank you so much. Richard Windsor there, founder of Radio Free Mobile and Erik Nielsen of Unicredit stays with us.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Erik Nielsen still with us from Unicredit. Erik, where's the tipping point in this story? The Chinese and we've -- we saw this sort of 18 months ago with the Davos speech that was delivered by the Chinese premier, have tried to play sort of the calm, rational actor in this story, but you just kind of wonder where they are being pushed to and at what point they start to retaliate, because that's when the game really starts. Where do you think that point is?

NIELSEN: I don't know, but I think there are a couple of things going on, right? The one part is that it's I think it's an irony that China is now the defender of free trade, right? At the end of the day, they have a lot of subsidized industries --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- and all the rest of it, and so the real tragedy for me here is that these are the protector of the (INAUDIBLE) lateral world have decided that they don't want to be, as the U.S., they don't want to really be the free trade champion anymore.

So, now, we are in this back room and ironically somebody getting sort of - -

JOHNSON: They fills it.

NIELSEN: Job filling in, exactly, in a peculiar way. But where do this -- where do they draw the lines? It's impossible to say, because it's a big political decision for them at the end of the day. They have to do something, but I suspect they will retaliate very modestly, because they don't want I say the exactly --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- they don't want the trade war.

JOHNSON: In some ways, this feels very much like how we used to think about the cold war, escalation theory, deterrence.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: That kind of the language. Is that the direction we're going in, and is that a useful sort of way of thinking about this?

NIELSEN: Well, I think July (ph) -- I mean, let me start by saying, I think you could -- we haven't named it yet, but I think we already are in Cold War II, but more with Russia, right it's in a sense. And politically, this is completely cold war stuff we're going through now, and it can -- I don't see the breaking point there to where we stop this sort of escalation on the political side between. But this time around, compared to the original cold war, we have now China being a major player and the leading western (ph) power not being a leading player. So this is confusing, right.

LACQUA: But Erik, you have American businessmen who basically yesterday said, look, $60 billion it will also hurt the U.S. economy. How can you quantify that? Do we know by how much?

NIELSEN: Not at the top of my head. It's very, very little, I mean, if you're -- I mean, look, if you're doing the trade tariffs and you do sort of the steel and aluminum and you do a $60 billion on top of that, it is a decimal point on GDP at most, right. But the question is, if the Chinese retaliate and it comes back and forth a couple of times, well, then suddenly it could be.

There was a study by Obstfeld the IMF Chief Economist some years ago that estimates it that if you planted 20% tax -- import tax in America I think it was, on all Chinese imports, you could have something like half a percent cut to U.S. GDP by the exchange rate.

LACQUA: How would China retaliate? So even if they don't, you know, throw the fire on the other side, can they retaliate in measures that we don't really notice, but put investment in Europe? Is there actually -- can Europe benefit from this?

NIELSEN: Yes, I mean, it's all I was going to say, if the (INAUDIBLE) of course, how can they retaliate? I hope they retaliate just like they try to smooth Trump by maybe revoking some of the licenses for his daughters back in China or something, very symbolic, very sort of tell him you don't like what we do.

But the most serious question you ask, yes, I'm sure Europe can benefit instead and I think already, as I understand the conversations between particular Berlin and Beijing are in full flow on this. How can we at least prevent that we get down on the slippery slope to watch each other?

JOHNSON: Does the Trump camp see that as being Europe ending up in China's camp? Europe is trying to figure out how it gets around the aluminum and steel tariffs.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: If the White House perceives that the negotiations are in full flow and the Chinese and the Europeans are negotiating.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: Does that isolate Washington even further?

NIELSEN: Yes, it does. I mean, it's the -- I forget who coined it, I mean, from America first (INAUDIBLE) alone, right. I mean, that idea then it's the problem is I don't know, but I -- my suspect that Trump and Ross (ph) and these people are don't really see things the same way we see them. They say, well, people are just being confused. The "F.T." is up yesterday is saying that it's very -- calling some Europeans, it's very difficult, because he's so unpredictable Trump. I suspect if Trump reads the "F.T." which should probably doesn't, he would say, that's good, that's what I'm messing around with them, right? And -- but this is strange. It's not good for the economy

LACQUA: I mean, it could be seen as a win for the (INAUDIBLE). I know whether he reads the "F.T.", but I know he's watching, so I'm sure he's listening right now.

We'll get back to Erik shortly.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Well, still with us is Erik Nielsen of Unicredit. Erik, how does this translate into your world? Do you have the currency angle? Of you course you haven't said your angle, angle. Do you worry a little bit less about Saudi Arabia in terms of finances than you maybe did six, eight months ago because of the old price?

NIELSEN: Yes, for sure. Right. I mean there's -- I worry over less about them for two reasons. The oil price as you said and the fact that it feels like they're to reform and becoming closer to the west and reform the economy, which haven't been done. Whether they would be successful, I would -- I don't know, right. One has to be skipped but certainly a high oil price and this sort of stabilization is good.

LACQUA: OK. What does that mean? I mean the oil price, what is the metric when you look at the oil price inflation? Does it feed through inflation in the U.S.?

NIELSEN: Yes, yes, it does and that's best, right. I mean that's best and very clear. By you can say we've been asking for more inflation in America and Europe for a long time. We don't want inflation as cost push right. I mean, because oil prices go up.

That's bad inflation. Its -- we want inflation because the output closes and therefore demand push inflation higher, right. That's the -- that's what we really want. But what I meant by good news is that also in it for the west, you need a stable Middle East. And forever stay in Middle East you need oil prices and solar (ph) maybe this (INAUDIBLE) at least north of 50 probably.

JOHNSON: Talking inflation, we just had U.K. CPI drop and maybe the wrong kind of inflation, because it's been driven by what's been happening with the pound. The data just came out a few minutes ago. The pound popping around a little bit on it.

I'm just going to my (INAUDIBLE) screen. The number going through at 2.7. Previously it was 3.0. It was surveyed to come through at 2.8. It's now come down to 2.7.

We do have a bank of England decision coming up in a few days' time. It's going to be interesting to see ultimately whether or not actually the markets price in the bank right in terms of the, A, the inflation expectations, and B, whether or not that isn't likely to lead to an ongoing rate hiking cycle. We'll see. We'll find out later on this week. Marconi is going to tell us.

LACQUA: Yes. And Erik would you bring over to my chart. Now this is basically, we're looking at DWI (ph) repeat function, we're also looking at traders and how much they feel the BOE can act. Do you feel like they can? So this is basically showing at least one of BOE rate hikes this year.

NIELSEN: Yes.

LACQUA: Can they afford to even hike once?

NIELSEN: I wouldn't if I were them. I think -- but I think they will. I mean I think is the -- yes, I think the U.K. economy is too weak, and they should look through the inflation at this stage. That would be my view. I think its -- but I think they have set themselves in motion that they have -- they've had the inflation numbers obviously and they've set themselves in most of it.

(CROSSTALK)

JOHNSON: No. No. No. The U.K. economy is running at -- it was running at 17 miles an hour without shaking, right? The kind of the outputs and it now running at 60 miles an hour without shaking. But if we run the economy 60 miles an hour, it starts to shake. We don't have the same potential growth rate we used to have. So the inflation story is a bigger risk therefore the banks should act earlier, shouldn't it?

NIELSEN: If you're running at 60 miles an hour without shaking, maybe so. I'm looking more at maybe 30 and a lot of shaking.

JOHNSON: OK. (INAUDIBLE) and you're making the point.

NIELSEN: But it's -- so I would -- yes, I don't see why you hurry. I mean the risk that it faces our control here is not very high. So I -- Look lets also (INAUDIBLE) whether the hike ones or not in a year makes no difference to the economy. That's just -- I mean the market gets very excited this thing.

JOHNSON: You know --

NIELSEN: In real life, 25 basis points at one is not important.

LACQUA: You're breaking our heart, Erik.

NIELSEN: Oh sorry.

LACQUA: Erik Nielsen with Unicredit staying with us. We'll talk a little bit more about what the market cares and doesn't care about.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Erik, what are we -- what is (INAUDIBLE) the impact of a cliff edge on the European E.U. economy after the U.K. leaves if we don't have the same ago aggregation of financial services in London, the access to those bit markets, those capital markets, ceases to be there for European companies. What is the downsize for Europe? I'm just trying to understand how strong a card the U.K. where place it ultimately has to play here.

NIELSEN: It's very weak one, right, because it -- the U.K. is small in this context. I think there's days from day one, it believes that you cannot have most of sort of the settlements and the bit --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- on the financial outside the E.U. So there will be some pushback on this one. And there is on this specific issue a degree of also there's a benefit for us if you will. I mean there is a -- you can see how Frankfurt and Paris and Dublin, all other countries and other cities that sort of stopping to sort of the competing to get the financial industries in there. So I -- look, if Brexit is anything but a very soft one, it's a negative for all of us, little (INAUDIBLE) into my mind about that but more so for the U.K., right?

JOHNSON: So, I agree. I just wanting about if I run a company (INAUDIBLE) right funding or sell a bond or whatever it is I need to do. One of the things this happen is the financial crisis is that the U.S. capital markets have become bigger. One of the things that happened is the financial crisis is that the European capital markets have become smaller.

NIELSEN: Right.

JOHNSON: Now one of the things that happened after the financial crisis was that Europe said what we need to do is get deeper capital markets here.

NIELSEN: Right.

JOHNSON: One of the critical factors for our economy if we're going to take it forward from here.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: The most obvious thing to do is to use one of the global financial centers within the time zone to generate that process. Yet we're about to see the cliff edge where for removes that for being a possibility.

NIELSEN: Yes. But in powered up you have the banking union and the capitalize (ph) union under construction, if you will.

JOHNSON: Yes. Slow construction.

NIELSEN: Yes, yes, exactly. But its -- I mean, the banking union has -- I mean from their point of view it's not been slow, but it's, you know, like a war right now. But the capitalize union is underway, right? And the credit will take some years for sure.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Erik Nielsen of Unicredit sitting alongside us here on the desk. Erik, so we're just having a little of a chat in the break, and we were talking about whether or not the fed is going to raise three or four and it kind of went, and I'm a bit worried about next year.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: Should the fed be cutting rates at this point?

NIELSEN: No, probably not. I wouldn't cut rates, but I think if I were a betting man, I think I would bet on a rate cut towards the end of next year. I mean, so people are thinking, how far do they keep going, and nobody is talking about the cost because I think there's a measure of probability that next year sees a significant slowdown.

JOHNSON: Recession?

NIELSEN: You won't get probably a recession like two quarters of negative growth within 2019, I think. But when we come into early 2020, very likely probability (INAUDIBLE) say that's a very high probability and that means growth will slow almost a year before. So that sort of a year now certainly. And that's when the fed typically stop hiking and then at one states down the line towards the end of next year, I could easily see them cut.

JOHNSON: So the fed is going to be cutting as the ECB is exiting. It's going to be an interesting middle conundrum (INAUDIBLE), isn't it?

NIELSEN: Yes, yes. I think its -- yes, exactly. And that's why you have to think Euro-dollar moves higher.

LACQUA: But Erik why would you just not hike as much instead of then -- you know, you use credibility. We've seen it here in Europe about 15 years ago. If you hike and then cut, the markets freak out.

NIELSEN: Yes. Well, you hike until you don't hike anymore, and then you wait for maybe six, nine months, and then you cut in the normal scenario, right? But I think the probability of -- I mean, and so this is my view of next year that at least that it's a high probability. But its -- if I were the fed, I would also hike now, but I would not say four hikes this year. I mean, I think what's in it for that?

LACQUA: The growth is good. What would happen in 18 months from now?

NIELSEN: So my -- there are two issues. Pure macro, half of the increase in private consumption in America has been funded for two years now by a drawdown in household savings, and they seems to its down 2.5%. So this is vulnerable. This is 70% of GDP in America, right?

Then you have the risks of policies, the trade stuff, and the fiscal expansion. And what does the fiscal expansion do for insurance and they'll buy to the 10-year? So, my view would be that there's certainly a risk that sudden this thing falls off quite measurable at sometime down the line.

LACQUA: What does it mean for -- so who would be hit, is it that? But this is regardless of tariffs and trade, or is it?

NIELSEN: So the underlying fundamentals would suggest to me that sometime next year you have a slowdown. Tariffs and trade raises the risk that it happens more abruptly and earlier.

JOHNSON: Do you think the Euro goes up on this? I'm sorry, I'm trying to consider the other argument out, which is --

LACQUA: I'm shocked.

JOHNSON: -- as the fed is -- yes. Sorry. And as the fed has been hiking rates and the interest rate differential on the 10 years go wider and wider and wider, the dollar has gone down. So I'm just going to throw it out there. Does the dollar go up when the fed starts?

NIELSEN: No. No. No. Your --

(CROSSTALK)

JOHNSON: But Euro dollar has gone up when the fed is hiking. They got this huge interest rate --

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: -- differential, so --

NIELSEN: I don't think that's as powerful as the fiscal expansion. I mean, so --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- we had a -- we have a nice -- my colleague (INAUDIBLE) --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- has a great chart on the U.S. budget deficit adjusted for the cyclicals and need (INAUDIBLE) chart --

JOHNSON: The Euro has gone up because of the U.S. twin deficit?

NIELSEN: No, the dollar has gone down, right?

JOHNSON: OK.

NIELSEN: And that's probably the --

JOHNSON: No. No. But its --

NIELSEN: Yes. No. No. No. Because the dollar weakness more than as a Euro spends dollar. That's important too.

LACQUA: That's not how Draghi is feeling it.

NIELSEN: Yes. Yes, yes, exactly and rightly so. I mean look at the trade where the Euro has got up by roughly half of what your dollar has right. So its dollar is dramatic. But --

JOHNSON: The trade (INAUDIBLE) Euro is down because the (INAUDIBLE) hasn't moved or --

NIELSEN: Yes. It's been helping that's right, that's right. I mean, and I mean the other trading partner we have the sterling, right, and then we have the central Europeans and all the rest of it, so its, yes, but there then maybe it's a very big part of the story, right.

LACQUA: All right. This is trade where the Euro, I caught it up in time.

NIELSEN: With --

LACQUA: I'm so happy. There it is. It's there on the left.

NIELSEN: Right.

LACQUA: Between the --

NIELSEN: That's between the Euro Bank.

LACQUA: So that --

NIELSEN: So what's the problem, right?

LACQUA: What do we do from here?

NIELSEN: So that's put to my point is first for the ECB what's the problem, right?

JOHNSON: It's gone sideways. Those on the thin on radio it's gone sideways.

NIELSEN: Yes. So, I think from where does it go from here? I think it will -- we will edge higher. Over this year if I have to -- I mean if I were basically a betting man, I would say maybe 5% or thereabouts. Nothing too dramatic.

JOHNSON: Somebody is already complaining about it now.

(CROSSTALK)

NIELSEN: Yes.

LACQUA: Explain this.

NIELSEN: I mean, yes, they are and yet their export numbers are still growing faster than global trade and global GDP. So they're still getting market shares around the world. But of course it's nicer too -- if you're an exporter to have a weaker currency.

JOHNSON: Who's at the other day one of the ECB --

NIELSEN: And I'll prefer they didn't have, right. I mean --

JOHNSON: Yes. one of the ECB guys the other day was talking about the fact this is as good as it gets for the ECB better much on inflation restore coming through. The growth momentum story's been there, it's

Richard Windsor and Erik Nielsen discuss economics and politics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

RICHARD WINDSOR, FOUNDER, RADIO FREE MOBILE; AND ERIK NIELSEN, CHIEF ECONOMIST, UNICREDIT GROUP; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BB SURVEILLANCE

MARCH 20, 2018

SPEAKERS: RICHARD WINDSOR, FOUNDER, RADIO FREE MOBILE

ERIK NIELSEN, CHIEF ECONOMIST, UNICREDIT GROUP

GUY JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Joining us from Dubai is Richard Windsor, he's founder of Radio Free Mobile, he (INAUDIBLE) top tech. Also with us for the hour, he is Erik Nielsen and he is Unicredit Group Chief Economist.

So, Erik, thank you so much. Stay there, because we'll get to you in a second.

Richard, when it comes to the tech selloff --

RICHARD WINDSOR, FOUNDER, RADIO FREE MOBILE: Good morning.

LACQUA: -- what exactly -- good morning to you -- what exactly freaked the markets? Is it that, you know, had a trajectory, where a lot of these stocks were going when you were driverless cars could go now next and now it's all hanging up in the air?

WINDSOR: No, I think you got a number of factors. I mean you've had the really large -- the really tech companies that have had, you know, one of the greatest runs they've ever had. You've got the prospect of increasing interest rates.

And then also, if you look at the stocks that are dependent on monetization of user data like Google and Facebook and Twitter, these are the ones that have most impacted. So I suspect it's more about these factors, combined with increasing fear of regulation in terms of what people can and cannot do with data that has been given to them by users that are causing the problems.

LACQUA: Yes, we also heard that the E.U. was probably considering a digital tax as a trade to this few (ph) kind of rages on. What would that look like?

WINDSOR: Great question. Very difficult to tell, I mean, I guess what they would look to do would be to impose a tax on revenues that have been derived in the region. That would be the simplest way of doing it as I presume.

But overall, I mean, my personal opinion is hold data issue is it will eventually blow over. And the reason why it will blow over is because there's a fundamental misunderstanding in my opinion in terms of how the internet works and users seem to have the opinion that the internet is free, isn't and never has been. What you're actually doing is just paying for service with personal data.

Once users get more accustomed to that, then I think that there will be an easier situation where you can choose. You pay the cash or you pay with personal data, and that's how I think it's going to evolve going forward.

GUY JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Do you value these companies though at the same level if that is the case? Because, as you say, at the moment, there is this misapprehension that the service is free. But basically these are data monetization companies.

WINDSOR: Exactly. And actually, I think it is. As a matter of fact, the research that Radio Free Mobile has done over the last five years actually (INAUDIBLE) this out, which is that, you know, you have a choice. Let's just take for example, Google. Google has a choice. You could basically come to Google and say yes, you can use my personal data and I will use -- get your services for free or I don't want you to use my personal data, I'll tell you what, I'll pay you $5 a month for the service.

Now, obviously, these companies would set the pricing of that service at the level at which there should be no real impact on revenue overall.

JOHNSON: Do you think there's a breakup risk here, Richard?

WINDSOR: In terms of?

JOHNSON: Are these companies too big, too powerful, somebody pointed out to me earlier on, they spend a huge amount of money in terms of lobbying in Washington. They control huge sways (ph) of the technology sector across the United States and across the world. We've seen it in history, when companies and sectors become too big, there is a regulatory impetus that starts but ultimately ends up leading to breakup.

WINDSOR: I think it's this possibility, but it's a very distinct possibility. If you look at Google, your first question want to ask is, well, what am I going to break it up into? Because, you know, and there is a reasonable argument in this level of Google that it is a one-trick pony, but it does search and everything else is fairly minor.

As a result of that, you would have great difficulty breaking that up into its constituent parts. In the same, you could level exactly the same accusation at Facebook. Facebook generates almost all of its revenue off its social network, so the question is, what would you break it up into?

LACQUA: Let's also bring Erik Nielsen of Unicredit into the conversation. Erik, I know you don't look at this thing day out, but you must have a view on driverless cars and automation and even the end of cash, and the impact it has on the economy in 5, 10, 15 years. Does anything that happens in the last, you know, the last couple of days change that deal?

ERIK NIELSEN, CHIEF ECONOMIST, UNICREDIT GROUP: I'm getting more and more nervous. I think we had maybe an overshot in terms of globalization after the crisis and through the crisis sort of extent and I see a lot of winding back of this. And I think what you're referring to and what we just talked about on the -- in the I.T. industry and the tech industries. I share sort of guy sort of skepticism here.

I mean, to some extent, these companies have been broken up in the sense that they're not free to operate in China and Russia, for example, right? There are positive words that we don't want this, right, and all the Europeans are saying a little bit, I don't really think you pay enough taxes because you shoveling through islands, so maybe, so we should say exactly as Richard said, maybe we should tax the pays with the revenues come in.

But this whole thing is not a smooth process, right? So you have to worry a little about this sort of how that impacts the economy in a negative way.

JOHNSON: But we find ourselves in a situation where the Chinese, as long as you got -- they two sort of two buckets of tech stocks around the world at the moment, you got the kind of the U.S. bucket and you got the Asian bucket, which is largely the Chinese buckets.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: Europe doesn't have much.

NIELSEN: No.

JOHNSON: So it kind of falls into one of those two. The Chinese bucket is going to be made up of companies that are going to get bigger and, therefore, potentially stronger, whereas there is increasingly this regulatory taxation burden that is likely to be put on the U.S. once.

NIELSEN: Right.

JOHNSON: So are we putting ourselves at a disadvantage -- are we heading down the road of a kind of trade war their tech versus our tech? Are we putting ourselves at a disadvantage?

NIELSEN: I don't know if we -- yes, from a very sort of liberal kind of world view we are, in a sense, but I think what we have seen is some of the backlash to what's this in the (INAUDIBLE) of things and (INAUDIBLE) now where these companies seems to be if the reporting is correct, meddling with the political process.

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: So then I think most people will think, well, then there has to be some measures to take this back, right? So I -- and that's what I meant by what I said before. I don't think that taking it, but I think politically, it's understandable and probably desirable, but it's not smooth for the economy as this happens.

LACQUA: And, Richard, what are you watching out for in the next 74 hours? Will it be testimonies to kind of exactly understand where a lot of these big companies go from here?

WINDSOR: My personal suspicion is that things are -- that, you know, you had a bit of fuzz. People start to get worried about the use of data. Obviously, actually and if you look at the data leak, there is piece of happen where at 50, I think it was 50 million accountable data and 50 million of Facebook accounts made it into a private data analysis firm.

If you actually look at Facebook has actually changed its policy so you can no longer do that. So what I suspect will actually happen is there's going to be talk, a bit of softness, but I, you know, I think at the end of the day, we're coming into earnings season. Quite possibly, we're going to have another reason a good season from the big tech companies.

So as a result of that, I suspect a small correction, but then, you know, continuation of business as normal, at least for another quarter or so.

LACQUA: All right, Richard, thank you so much. Richard Windsor there, founder of Radio Free Mobile and Erik Nielsen of Unicredit stays with us.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Erik Nielsen still with us from Unicredit. Erik, where's the tipping point in this story? The Chinese and we've -- we saw this sort of 18 months ago with the Davos speech that was delivered by the Chinese premier, have tried to play sort of the calm, rational actor in this story, but you just kind of wonder where they are being pushed to and at what point they start to retaliate, because that's when the game really starts. Where do you think that point is?

NIELSEN: I don't know, but I think there are a couple of things going on, right? The one part is that it's I think it's an irony that China is now the defender of free trade, right? At the end of the day, they have a lot of subsidized industries --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- and all the rest of it, and so the real tragedy for me here is that these are the protector of the (INAUDIBLE) lateral world have decided that they don't want to be, as the U.S., they don't want to really be the free trade champion anymore.

So, now, we are in this back room and ironically somebody getting sort of - -

JOHNSON: They fills it.

NIELSEN: Job filling in, exactly, in a peculiar way. But where do this -- where do they draw the lines? It's impossible to say, because it's a big political decision for them at the end of the day. They have to do something, but I suspect they will retaliate very modestly, because they don't want I say the exactly --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- they don't want the trade war.

JOHNSON: In some ways, this feels very much like how we used to think about the cold war, escalation theory, deterrence.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: That kind of the language. Is that the direction we're going in, and is that a useful sort of way of thinking about this?

NIELSEN: Well, I think July (ph) -- I mean, let me start by saying, I think you could -- we haven't named it yet, but I think we already are in Cold War II, but more with Russia, right it's in a sense. And politically, this is completely cold war stuff we're going through now, and it can -- I don't see the breaking point there to where we stop this sort of escalation on the political side between. But this time around, compared to the original cold war, we have now China being a major player and the leading western (ph) power not being a leading player. So this is confusing, right.

LACQUA: But Erik, you have American businessmen who basically yesterday said, look, $60 billion it will also hurt the U.S. economy. How can you quantify that? Do we know by how much?

NIELSEN: Not at the top of my head. It's very, very little, I mean, if you're -- I mean, look, if you're doing the trade tariffs and you do sort of the steel and aluminum and you do a $60 billion on top of that, it is a decimal point on GDP at most, right. But the question is, if the Chinese retaliate and it comes back and forth a couple of times, well, then suddenly it could be.

There was a study by Obstfeld the IMF Chief Economist some years ago that estimates it that if you planted 20% tax -- import tax in America I think it was, on all Chinese imports, you could have something like half a percent cut to U.S. GDP by the exchange rate.

LACQUA: How would China retaliate? So even if they don't, you know, throw the fire on the other side, can they retaliate in measures that we don't really notice, but put investment in Europe? Is there actually -- can Europe benefit from this?

NIELSEN: Yes, I mean, it's all I was going to say, if the (INAUDIBLE) of course, how can they retaliate? I hope they retaliate just like they try to smooth Trump by maybe revoking some of the licenses for his daughters back in China or something, very symbolic, very sort of tell him you don't like what we do.

But the most serious question you ask, yes, I'm sure Europe can benefit instead and I think already, as I understand the conversations between particular Berlin and Beijing are in full flow on this. How can we at least prevent that we get down on the slippery slope to watch each other?

JOHNSON: Does the Trump camp see that as being Europe ending up in China's camp? Europe is trying to figure out how it gets around the aluminum and steel tariffs.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: If the White House perceives that the negotiations are in full flow and the Chinese and the Europeans are negotiating.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: Does that isolate Washington even further?

NIELSEN: Yes, it does. I mean, it's the -- I forget who coined it, I mean, from America first (INAUDIBLE) alone, right. I mean, that idea then it's the problem is I don't know, but I -- my suspect that Trump and Ross (ph) and these people are don't really see things the same way we see them. They say, well, people are just being confused. The "F.T." is up yesterday is saying that it's very -- calling some Europeans, it's very difficult, because he's so unpredictable Trump. I suspect if Trump reads the "F.T." which should probably doesn't, he would say, that's good, that's what I'm messing around with them, right? And -- but this is strange. It's not good for the economy

LACQUA: I mean, it could be seen as a win for the (INAUDIBLE). I know whether he reads the "F.T.", but I know he's watching, so I'm sure he's listening right now.

We'll get back to Erik shortly.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Well, still with us is Erik Nielsen of Unicredit. Erik, how does this translate into your world? Do you have the currency angle? Of you course you haven't said your angle, angle. Do you worry a little bit less about Saudi Arabia in terms of finances than you maybe did six, eight months ago because of the old price?

NIELSEN: Yes, for sure. Right. I mean there's -- I worry over less about them for two reasons. The oil price as you said and the fact that it feels like they're to reform and becoming closer to the west and reform the economy, which haven't been done. Whether they would be successful, I would -- I don't know, right. One has to be skipped but certainly a high oil price and this sort of stabilization is good.

LACQUA: OK. What does that mean? I mean the oil price, what is the metric when you look at the oil price inflation? Does it feed through inflation in the U.S.?

NIELSEN: Yes, yes, it does and that's best, right. I mean that's best and very clear. By you can say we've been asking for more inflation in America and Europe for a long time. We don't want inflation as cost push right. I mean, because oil prices go up.

That's bad inflation. Its -- we want inflation because the output closes and therefore demand push inflation higher, right. That's the -- that's what we really want. But what I meant by good news is that also in it for the west, you need a stable Middle East. And forever stay in Middle East you need oil prices and solar (ph) maybe this (INAUDIBLE) at least north of 50 probably.

JOHNSON: Talking inflation, we just had U.K. CPI drop and maybe the wrong kind of inflation, because it's been driven by what's been happening with the pound. The data just came out a few minutes ago. The pound popping around a little bit on it.

I'm just going to my (INAUDIBLE) screen. The number going through at 2.7. Previously it was 3.0. It was surveyed to come through at 2.8. It's now come down to 2.7.

We do have a bank of England decision coming up in a few days' time. It's going to be interesting to see ultimately whether or not actually the markets price in the bank right in terms of the, A, the inflation expectations, and B, whether or not that isn't likely to lead to an ongoing rate hiking cycle. We'll see. We'll find out later on this week. Marconi is going to tell us.

LACQUA: Yes. And Erik would you bring over to my chart. Now this is basically, we're looking at DWI (ph) repeat function, we're also looking at traders and how much they feel the BOE can act. Do you feel like they can? So this is basically showing at least one of BOE rate hikes this year.

NIELSEN: Yes.

LACQUA: Can they afford to even hike once?

NIELSEN: I wouldn't if I were them. I think -- but I think they will. I mean I think is the -- yes, I think the U.K. economy is too weak, and they should look through the inflation at this stage. That would be my view. I think its -- but I think they have set themselves in motion that they have -- they've had the inflation numbers obviously and they've set themselves in most of it.

(CROSSTALK)

JOHNSON: No. No. No. The U.K. economy is running at -- it was running at 17 miles an hour without shaking, right? The kind of the outputs and it now running at 60 miles an hour without shaking. But if we run the economy 60 miles an hour, it starts to shake. We don't have the same potential growth rate we used to have. So the inflation story is a bigger risk therefore the banks should act earlier, shouldn't it?

NIELSEN: If you're running at 60 miles an hour without shaking, maybe so. I'm looking more at maybe 30 and a lot of shaking.

JOHNSON: OK. (INAUDIBLE) and you're making the point.

NIELSEN: But it's -- so I would -- yes, I don't see why you hurry. I mean the risk that it faces our control here is not very high. So I -- Look lets also (INAUDIBLE) whether the hike ones or not in a year makes no difference to the economy. That's just -- I mean the market gets very excited this thing.

JOHNSON: You know --

NIELSEN: In real life, 25 basis points at one is not important.

LACQUA: You're breaking our heart, Erik.

NIELSEN: Oh sorry.

LACQUA: Erik Nielsen with Unicredit staying with us. We'll talk a little bit more about what the market cares and doesn't care about.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Erik, what are we -- what is (INAUDIBLE) the impact of a cliff edge on the European E.U. economy after the U.K. leaves if we don't have the same ago aggregation of financial services in London, the access to those bit markets, those capital markets, ceases to be there for European companies. What is the downsize for Europe? I'm just trying to understand how strong a card the U.K. where place it ultimately has to play here.

NIELSEN: It's very weak one, right, because it -- the U.K. is small in this context. I think there's days from day one, it believes that you cannot have most of sort of the settlements and the bit --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- on the financial outside the E.U. So there will be some pushback on this one. And there is on this specific issue a degree of also there's a benefit for us if you will. I mean there is a -- you can see how Frankfurt and Paris and Dublin, all other countries and other cities that sort of stopping to sort of the competing to get the financial industries in there. So I -- look, if Brexit is anything but a very soft one, it's a negative for all of us, little (INAUDIBLE) into my mind about that but more so for the U.K., right?

JOHNSON: So, I agree. I just wanting about if I run a company (INAUDIBLE) right funding or sell a bond or whatever it is I need to do. One of the things this happen is the financial crisis is that the U.S. capital markets have become bigger. One of the things that happened is the financial crisis is that the European capital markets have become smaller.

NIELSEN: Right.

JOHNSON: Now one of the things that happened after the financial crisis was that Europe said what we need to do is get deeper capital markets here.

NIELSEN: Right.

JOHNSON: One of the critical factors for our economy if we're going to take it forward from here.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: The most obvious thing to do is to use one of the global financial centers within the time zone to generate that process. Yet we're about to see the cliff edge where for removes that for being a possibility.

NIELSEN: Yes. But in powered up you have the banking union and the capitalize (ph) union under construction, if you will.

JOHNSON: Yes. Slow construction.

NIELSEN: Yes, yes, exactly. But its -- I mean, the banking union has -- I mean from their point of view it's not been slow, but it's, you know, like a war right now. But the capitalize union is underway, right? And the credit will take some years for sure.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Erik Nielsen of Unicredit sitting alongside us here on the desk. Erik, so we're just having a little of a chat in the break, and we were talking about whether or not the fed is going to raise three or four and it kind of went, and I'm a bit worried about next year.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: Should the fed be cutting rates at this point?

NIELSEN: No, probably not. I wouldn't cut rates, but I think if I were a betting man, I think I would bet on a rate cut towards the end of next year. I mean, so people are thinking, how far do they keep going, and nobody is talking about the cost because I think there's a measure of probability that next year sees a significant slowdown.

JOHNSON: Recession?

NIELSEN: You won't get probably a recession like two quarters of negative growth within 2019, I think. But when we come into early 2020, very likely probability (INAUDIBLE) say that's a very high probability and that means growth will slow almost a year before. So that sort of a year now certainly. And that's when the fed typically stop hiking and then at one states down the line towards the end of next year, I could easily see them cut.

JOHNSON: So the fed is going to be cutting as the ECB is exiting. It's going to be an interesting middle conundrum (INAUDIBLE), isn't it?

NIELSEN: Yes, yes. I think its -- yes, exactly. And that's why you have to think Euro-dollar moves higher.

LACQUA: But Erik why would you just not hike as much instead of then -- you know, you use credibility. We've seen it here in Europe about 15 years ago. If you hike and then cut, the markets freak out.

NIELSEN: Yes. Well, you hike until you don't hike anymore, and then you wait for maybe six, nine months, and then you cut in the normal scenario, right? But I think the probability of -- I mean, and so this is my view of next year that at least that it's a high probability. But its -- if I were the fed, I would also hike now, but I would not say four hikes this year. I mean, I think what's in it for that?

LACQUA: The growth is good. What would happen in 18 months from now?

NIELSEN: So my -- there are two issues. Pure macro, half of the increase in private consumption in America has been funded for two years now by a drawdown in household savings, and they seems to its down 2.5%. So this is vulnerable. This is 70% of GDP in America, right?

Then you have the risks of policies, the trade stuff, and the fiscal expansion. And what does the fiscal expansion do for insurance and they'll buy to the 10-year? So, my view would be that there's certainly a risk that sudden this thing falls off quite measurable at sometime down the line.

LACQUA: What does it mean for -- so who would be hit, is it that? But this is regardless of tariffs and trade, or is it?

NIELSEN: So the underlying fundamentals would suggest to me that sometime next year you have a slowdown. Tariffs and trade raises the risk that it happens more abruptly and earlier.

JOHNSON: Do you think the Euro goes up on this? I'm sorry, I'm trying to consider the other argument out, which is --

LACQUA: I'm shocked.

JOHNSON: -- as the fed is -- yes. Sorry. And as the fed has been hiking rates and the interest rate differential on the 10 years go wider and wider and wider, the dollar has gone down. So I'm just going to throw it out there. Does the dollar go up when the fed starts?

NIELSEN: No. No. No. Your --

(CROSSTALK)

JOHNSON: But Euro dollar has gone up when the fed is hiking. They got this huge interest rate --

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: -- differential, so --

NIELSEN: I don't think that's as powerful as the fiscal expansion. I mean, so --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- we had a -- we have a nice -- my colleague (INAUDIBLE) --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- has a great chart on the U.S. budget deficit adjusted for the cyclicals and need (INAUDIBLE) chart --

JOHNSON: The Euro has gone up because of the U.S. twin deficit?

NIELSEN: No, the dollar has gone down, right?

JOHNSON: OK.

NIELSEN: And that's probably the --

JOHNSON: No. No. But its --

NIELSEN: Yes. No. No. No. Because the dollar weakness more than as a Euro spends dollar. That's important too.

LACQUA: That's not how Draghi is feeling it.

NIELSEN: Yes. Yes, yes, exactly and rightly so. I mean look at the trade where the Euro has got up by roughly half of what your dollar has right. So its dollar is dramatic. But --

JOHNSON: The trade (INAUDIBLE) Euro is down because the (INAUDIBLE) hasn't moved or --

NIELSEN: Yes. It's been helping that's right, that's right. I mean, and I mean the other trading partner we have the sterling, right, and then we have the central Europeans and all the rest of it, so its, yes, but there then maybe it's a very big part of the story, right.

LACQUA: All right. This is trade where the Euro, I caught it up in time.

NIELSEN: With --

LACQUA: I'm so happy. There it is. It's there on the left.

NIELSEN: Right.

LACQUA: Between the --

NIELSEN: That's between the Euro Bank.

LACQUA: So that --

NIELSEN: So what's the problem, right?

LACQUA: What do we do from here?

NIELSEN: So that's put to my point is first for the ECB what's the problem, right?

JOHNSON: It's gone sideways. Those on the thin on radio it's gone sideways.

NIELSEN: Yes. So, I think from where does it go from here? I think it will -- we will edge higher. Over this year if I have to -- I mean if I were basically a betting man, I would say maybe 5% or thereabouts. Nothing too dramatic.

JOHNSON: Somebody is already complaining about it now.

(CROSSTALK)

NIELSEN: Yes.

LACQUA: Explain this.

NIELSEN: I mean, yes, they are and yet their export numbers are still growing faster than global trade and global GDP. So they're still getting market shares around the world. But of course it's nicer too -- if you're an exporter to have a weaker currency.

JOHNSON: Who's at the other day one of the ECB --

NIELSEN: And I'll prefer they didn't have, right. I mean --

JOHNSON: Yes. one of the ECB guys the other day was talking about the fact this is as good as it gets for the ECB better much on inflation restore coming through. The growth momentum story's been there, it's
