urn:contentItem:5RXV-97Y1-JDPT-T0M9-00000-00RICHARD WINDSOR, RADIO FREE MOBILE; AND ERIK NIELSEN, UNICREDIT GROUP; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE2018-03-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisRICHARD WINDSOR, RADIO FREE MOBILE; AND ERIK NIELSEN, UNICREDIT GROUP; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE

March 20, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

RICHARD WINDSOR, FOUNDER, RADIO FREE MOBILE; AND ERIK NIELSEN, CHIEF ECONOMIST, UNICREDIT GROUP

LACQUA: Joining us from Dubai is Richard Windsor, he's founder of Radio Free Mobile, he (INAUDIBLE) top tech. Also with us for the hour, he is Erik Nielsen and he is UniCredit Group Chief Economist.

So, Erik, thank you so much. Stay there, because we'll get to you in a second.

Richard, when it comes to the tech selloff --

WINDSOR: Good morning.

LACQUA: -- what exactly -- good morning to you -- what exactly freaked the markets? Is it that, you know, had a trajectory, where a lot of these stocks were going when you were driverless cars could go now next and now it's all hanging up in the air?

WINDSOR: No, I think you got a number of factors. I mean you've had the really large -- the really tech companies that have had, you know, one of the greatest runs they've ever had. You've got the prospect of increasing interest rates.

And then also, if you look at the stocks that are dependent on monetization of user data like Google and Facebook and Twitter, these are the ones that have most impacted. So I suspect it's more about these factors, combined with increasing fear of regulation in terms of what people can and cannot do with data that has been given to them by users that are causing the problems.

LACQUA: Yes, we also heard that the E.U. was probably considering a digital tax as a trade to this few (ph) kind of rages on. What would that look like?

WINDSOR: Great question. Very difficult to tell, I mean, I guess what they would look to do would be to impose a tax on revenues that have been derived in the region. That would be the simplest way of doing it as I presume.

But overall, I mean, my personal opinion is hold data issue is it will eventually blow over. And the reason why it will blow over is because there's a fundamental misunderstanding in my opinion in terms of how the internet works and users seem to have the opinion that the internet is free, isn't and never has been. What you're actually doing is just paying for service with personal data.

Once users get more accustomed to that, then I think that there will be an easier situation where you can choose. You pay the cash or you pay with personal data, and that's how I think it's going to evolve going forward.

JOHNSON: Do you value these companies though at the same level if that is the case? Because, as you say, at the moment, there is this misapprehension that the service is free. But basically these are data monetization companies.

WINDSOR: Exactly. And actually, I think it is. As a matter of fact, the research that Radio Free Mobile has done over the last five years actually (INAUDIBLE) this out, which is that, you know, you have a choice. Let's just take for example, Google. Google has a choice. You could basically come to Google and say yes, you can use my personal data and I will use -- get your services for free or I don't want you to use my personal data, I'll tell you what, I'll pay you $5 a month for the service.

Now, obviously, these companies would set the pricing of that service at the level at which there should be no real impact on revenue overall.

JOHNSON: Do you think there's a breakup risk here, Richard?

WINDSOR: In terms of?

JOHNSON: Are these companies too big, too powerful, somebody pointed out to me earlier on, they spend a huge amount of money in terms of lobbying in Washington. They control huge sways (ph) of the technology sector across the United States and across the world. We've seen it in history, when companies and sectors become too big, there is a regulatory impetus that starts but ultimately ends up leading to breakup.

WINDSOR: I think it's this possibility, but it's a very distinct possibility. If you look at Google, your first question want to ask is, well, what am I going to break it up into? Because, you know, and there is a reasonable argument in this level of Google that it is a one-trick pony, but it does search and everything else is fairly minor.

As a result of that, you would have great difficulty breaking that up into its constituent parts. In the same, you could level exactly the same accusation at Facebook. Facebook generates almost all of its revenue off its social network, so the question is, what would you break it up into?

LACQUA: Let's also bring Erik Nielsen of UniCredit into the conversation. Erik, I know you don't look at this thing day out, but you must have a view on driverless cars and automation and even the end of cash, and the impact it has on the economy in 5, 10, 15 years. Does anything that happens in the last, you know, the last couple of days change that deal?

NIELSEN: I'm getting more and more nervous. I think we had maybe an overshot in terms of globalization after the crisis and through the crisis sort of extent and I see a lot of winding back of this. And I think what you're referring to and what we just talked about on the -- in the I.T. industry and the tech industries. I share sort of guy sort of skepticism here.

I mean, to some extent, these companies have been broken up in the sense that they're not free to operate in China and Russia, for example, right? There are positive words that we don't want this, right, and all the Europeans are saying a little bit, I don't really think you pay enough taxes because you shoveling through islands, so maybe, so we should say exactly as Richard said, maybe we should tax the pays with the revenues come in.

But this whole thing is not a smooth process, right? So you have to worry a little about this sort of how that impacts the economy in a negative way.

JOHNSON: But we find ourselves in a situation where the Chinese, as long as you got -- they two sort of two buckets of tech stocks around the world at the moment, you got the kind of the U.S. bucket and you got the Asian bucket, which is largely the Chinese buckets.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: Europe doesn't have much.

NIELSEN: No.

JOHNSON: So it kind of falls into one of those two. The Chinese bucket is going to be made up of companies that are going to get bigger and, therefore, potentially stronger, whereas there is increasingly this regulatory taxation burden that is likely to be put on the U.S. once.

NIELSEN: Right.

JOHNSON: So are we putting ourselves at a disadvantage -- are we heading down the road of a kind of trade war their tech versus our tech? Are we putting ourselves at a disadvantage?

NIELSEN: I don't know if we -- yes, from a very sort of liberal kind of world view we are, in a sense, but I think what we have seen is some of the backlash to what's this in the (INAUDIBLE) of things and (INAUDIBLE) now where these companies seems to be if the reporting is correct, meddling with the political process.

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: So then I think most people will think, well, then there has to be some measures to take this back, right? So I -- and that's what I meant by what I said before. I don't think that taking it, but I think politically, it's understandable and probably desirable, but it's not smooth for the economy as this happens.

LACQUA: And, Richard, what are you watching out for in the next 74 hours? Will it be testimonies to kind of exactly understand where a lot of these big companies go from here?

WINDSOR: My personal suspicion is that things are -- that, you know, you had a bit of fuzz. People start to get worried about the use of data. Obviously, actually and if you look at the data leak, there is piece of happen where at 50, I think it was 50 million accountable data and 50 million of Facebook accounts made it into a private data analysis firm.

If you actually look at Facebook has actually changed its policy so you can no longer do that. So what I suspect will actually happen is there's going to be talk, a bit of softness, but I, you know, I think at the end of the day, we're coming into earnings season. Quite possibly, we're going to have another reason a good season from the big tech companies.

So as a result of that, I suspect a small correction, but then, you know, continuation of business as normal, at least for another quarter or so.

LACQUA: All right, Richard, thank you so much. Richard Windsor there, founder of Radio Free Mobile and Erik Nielsen of UniCredit stays with us.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Erik Nielsen still with us from UniCredit. Erik, where's the tipping point in this story? The Chinese and we've -- we saw this sort of 18 months ago with the Davos speech that was delivered by the Chinese premier, have tried to play sort of the calm, rational actor in this story, but you just kind of wonder where they are being pushed to and at what point they start to retaliate, because that's when the game really starts. Where do you think that point is?

NIELSEN: I don't know, but I think there are a couple of things going on, right? The one part is that it's I think it's an irony that China is now the defender of free trade, right? At the end of the day, they have a lot of subsidized industries --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- and all the rest of it, and so the real tragedy for me here is that these are the protector of the (INAUDIBLE) lateral world have decided that they don't want to be, as the U.S., they don't want to really be the free trade champion anymore.

So, now, we are in this back room and ironically somebody getting sort of --

JOHNSON: They fills it.

NIELSEN: Job filling in, exactly, in a peculiar way. But where do this -- where do they draw the lines? It's impossible to say, because it's a big political decision for them at the end of the day. They have to do something, but I suspect they will retaliate very modestly, because they don't want I say the exactly --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- they don't want the trade war.

JOHNSON: In some ways, this feels very much like how we used to think about the cold war, escalation theory, deterrence.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: That kind of the language. Is that the direction we're going in, and is that a useful sort of way of thinking about this?

NIELSEN: Well, I think July (ph) -- I mean, let me start by saying, I think you could -- we haven't named it yet, but I think we already are in Cold War II, but more with Russia, right it's in a sense. And politically, this is completely cold war stuff we're going through now, and it can -- I don't see the breaking point there to where we stop this sort of escalation on the political side between. But this time around, compared to the original cold war, we have now China being a major player and the leading western (ph) power not being a leading player. So this is confusing, right.

LACQUA: But Erik, you have American businessmen who basically yesterday said, look, $60 billion it will also hurt the U.S. economy. How can you quantify that? Do we know by how much?

NIELSEN: Not at the top of my head. It's very, very little, I mean, if you're -- I mean, look, if you're doing the trade tariffs and you do sort of the steel and aluminum and you do a $60 billion on top of that, it is a decimal point on GDP at most, right. But the question is, if the Chinese retaliate and it comes back and forth a couple of times, well, then suddenly it could be.

There was a study by Obstfeld the IMF Chief Economist some years ago that estimates it that if you planted 20% tax -- import tax in America I think it was, on all Chinese imports, you could have something like half a percent cut to U.S. GDP by the exchange rate.

LACQUA: How would China retaliate? So even if they don't, you know, throw the fire on the other side, can they retaliate in measures that we don't really notice, but put investment in Europe? Is there actually -- can Europe benefit from this?

NIELSEN: Yes, I mean, it's all I was going to say, if the (INAUDIBLE) of course, how can they retaliate? I hope they retaliate just like they try to smooth Trump by maybe revoking some of the licenses for his daughters back in China or something, very symbolic, very sort of tell him you don't like what we do.

But the most serious question you ask, yes, I'm sure Europe can benefit instead and I think already, as I understand the conversations between particular Berlin and Beijing are in full flow on this. How can we at least prevent that we get down on the slippery slope to watch each other?

JOHNSON: Does the Trump camp see that as being Europe ending up in China's camp? Europe is trying to figure out how it gets around the aluminum and steel tariffs.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: If the White House perceives that the negotiations are in full flow and the Chinese and the Europeans are negotiating.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: Does that isolate Washington even further?

NIELSEN: Yes, it does. I mean, it's the -- I forget who coined it, I mean, from America first (INAUDIBLE) alone, right. I mean, that idea then it's the problem is I don't know, but I -- my suspect that Trump and Ross (ph) and these people are don't really see things the same way we see them. They say, well, people are just being confused. The "F.T." is up yesterday is saying that it's very -- calling some Europeans, it's very difficult, because he's so unpredictable Trump. I suspect if Trump reads the "F.T." which should probably doesn't, he would say, that's good, that's what I'm messing around with them, right? And -- but this is strange. It's not good for the economy

LACQUA: I mean, it could be seen as a win for the (INAUDIBLE). I know whether he reads the "F.T.", but I know he's watching, so I'm sure he's listening right now.

We'll get back to Erik shortly.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Well, still with us is Erik Nielsen of UniCredit. Erik, how does this translate into your world? Do you have the currency angle? Of you course you haven't said your angle, angle. Do you worry a little bit less about Saudi Arabia in terms of finances than you maybe did six, eight months ago because of the old price?

NIELSEN: Yes, for sure. Right. I mean there's -- I worry over less about them for two reasons. The oil price as you said and the fact that it feels like they're to reform and becoming closer to the west and reform the economy, which haven't been done. Whether they would be successful, I would -- I don't know, right. One has to be skipped but certainly a high oil price and this sort of stabilization is good.

LACQUA: OK. What does that mean? I mean the oil price, what is the metric when you look at the oil price inflation? Does it feed through inflation in the U.S.?

NIELSEN: Yes, yes, it does and that's best, right. I mean that's best and very clear. By you can say we've been asking for more inflation in America and Europe for a long time. We don't want inflation as cost push right. I mean, because oil prices go up.

That's bad inflation. Its -- we want inflation because the output closes and therefore demand push inflation higher, right. That's the -- that's what we really want. But what I meant by good news is that also in it for the west, you need a stable Middle East. And forever stay in Middle East you need oil prices and solar (ph) maybe this (INAUDIBLE) at least north of 50 probably.

JOHNSON: Talking inflation, we just had U.K. CPI drop and maybe the wrong kind of inflation, because it's been driven by what's been happening with the pound. The data just came out a few minutes ago. The pound popping around a little bit on it.

I'm just going to my (INAUDIBLE) screen. The number going through at 2.7. Previously it was 3.0. It was surveyed to come through at 2.8. It's now come down to 2.7.

We do have a bank of England decision coming up in a few days' time. It's going to be interesting to see ultimately whether or not actually the markets price in the bank right in terms of the, A, the inflation expectations, and B, whether or not that isn't likely to lead to an ongoing rate hiking cycle. We'll see. We'll find out later on this week. Marconi is going to tell us.

LACQUA: Yes. And Erik would you bring over to my chart. Now this is basically, we're looking at DWI (ph) repeat function, we're also looking at traders and how much they feel the BOE can act. Do you feel like they can? So this is basically showing at least one of BOE rate hikes this year.

NIELSEN: Yes.

LACQUA: Can they afford to even hike once?

NIELSEN: I wouldn't if I were them. I think -- but I think they will. I mean I think is the -- yes, I think the U.K. economy is too weak, and they should look through the inflation at this stage. That would be my view. I think its -- but I think they have set themselves in motion that they have -- they've had the inflation numbers obviously and they've set themselves in most of it.

(CROSSTALK)

JOHNSON: No. No. No. The U.K. economy is running at -- it was running at 17 miles an hour without shaking, right? The kind of the outputs and it now running at 60 miles an hour without shaking. But if we run the economy 60 miles an hour, it starts to shake. We don't have the same potential growth rate we used to have. So the inflation story is a bigger risk therefore the banks should act earlier, shouldn't it?

NIELSEN: If you're running at 60 miles an hour without shaking, maybe so. I'm looking more at maybe 30 and a lot of shaking.

JOHNSON: OK. (INAUDIBLE) and you're making the point.

NIELSEN: But it's -- so I would -- yes, I don't see why you hurry. I mean the risk that it faces our control here is not very high. So I -- Look lets also (INAUDIBLE) whether the hike ones or not in a year makes no difference to the economy. That's just -- I mean the market gets very excited this thing.

JOHNSON: You know --

NIELSEN: In real life, 25 basis points at one is not important.

LACQUA: You're breaking our heart, Erik.

NIELSEN: Oh sorry.

LACQUA: Erik Nielsen with UniCredit staying with us. We'll talk a little bit more about what the market cares and doesn't care about.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Erik, what are we -- what is (INAUDIBLE) the impact of a cliff edge on the European E.U. economy after the U.K. leaves if we don't have the same ago aggregation of financial services in London, the access to those bit markets, those capital markets, ceases to be there for European companies. What is the downsize for Europe? I'm just trying to understand how strong a card the U.K. where place it ultimately has to play here.

NIELSEN: It's very weak one, right, because it -- the U.K. is small in this context. I think there's days from day one, it believes that you cannot have most of sort of the settlements and the bit --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- on the financial outside the E.U. So there will be some pushback on this one. And there is on this specific issue a degree of also there's a benefit for us if you will. I mean there is a -- you can see how Frankfurt and Paris and Dublin, all other countries and other cities that sort of stopping to sort of the competing to get the financial industries in there. So I -- look, if Brexit is anything but a very soft one, it's a negative for all of us, little (INAUDIBLE) into my mind about that but more so for the U.K., right?

JOHNSON: So, I agree. I just wanting about if I run a company (INAUDIBLE) right funding or sell a bond or whatever it is I need to do. One of the things this happen is the financial crisis is that the U.S. capital markets have become bigger. One of the things that happened is the financial crisis is that the European capital markets have become smaller.

NIELSEN: Right.

JOHNSON: Now one of the things that happened after the financial crisis was that Europe said what we need to do is get deeper capital markets here.

NIELSEN: Right.

JOHNSON: One of the critical factors for our economy if we're going to take it forward from here.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: The most obvious thing to do is to use one of the global financial centers within the time zone to generate that process. Yet we're about to see the cliff edge where for removes that for being a possibility.

NIELSEN: Yes. But in powered up you have the banking union and the capitalize (ph) union under construction, if you will.

JOHNSON: Yes. Slow construction.

NIELSEN: Yes, yes, exactly. But its -- I mean, the banking union has -- I mean from their point of view it's not been slow, but it's, you know, like a war right now. But the capitalize union is underway, right? And the credit will take some years for sure.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Erik Nielsen of UniCredit sitting alongside us here on the desk. Erik, so we're just having a little of a chat in the break, and we were talking about whether or not the fed is going to raise three or four and it kind of went, and I'm a bit worried about next year.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: Should the fed be cutting rates at this point?

NIELSEN: No, probably not. I wouldn't cut rates, but I think if I were a betting man, I think I would bet on a rate cut towards the end of next year. I mean, so people are thinking, how far do they keep going, and nobody is talking about the cost because I think there's a measure of probability that next year sees a significant slowdown.

JOHNSON: Recession?

NIELSEN: You won't get probably a recession like two quarters of negative growth within 2019, I think. But when we come into early 2020, very likely probability (INAUDIBLE) say that's a very high probability and that means growth will slow almost a year before. So that sort of a year now certainly. And that's when the fed typically stop hiking and then at one states down the line towards the end of next year, I could easily see them cut.

JOHNSON: So the fed is going to be cutting as the ECB is exiting. It's going to be an interesting middle conundrum (INAUDIBLE), isn't it?

NIELSEN: Yes, yes. I think its -- yes, exactly. And that's why you have to think Euro-dollar moves higher.

LACQUA: But Erik why would you just not hike as much instead of then -- you know, you use credibility. We've seen it here in Europe about 15 years ago. If you hike and then cut, the markets freak out.

NIELSEN: Yes. Well, you hike until you don't hike anymore, and then you wait for maybe six, nine months, and then you cut in the normal scenario, right? But I think the probability of -- I mean, and so this is my view of next year that at least that it's a high probability. But its -- if I were the fed, I would also hike now, but I would not say four hikes this year. I mean, I think what's in it for that?

LACQUA: The growth is good. What would happen in 18 months from now?

NIELSEN: So my -- there are two issues. Pure macro, half of the increase in private consumption in America has been funded for two years now by a drawdown in household savings, and they seems to its down 2.5%. So this is vulnerable. This is 70% of GDP in America, right?

Then you have the risks of policies, the trade stuff, and the fiscal expansion. And what does the fiscal expansion do for insurance and they'll buy to the 10-year? So, my view would be that there's certainly a risk that sudden this thing falls off quite measurable at sometime down the line.

LACQUA: What does it mean for -- so who would be hit, is it that? But this is regardless of tariffs and trade, or is it?

NIELSEN: So the underlying fundamentals would suggest to me that sometime next year you have a slowdown. Tariffs and trade raises the risk that it happens more abruptly and earlier.

JOHNSON: Do you think the Euro goes up on this? I'm sorry, I'm trying to consider the other argument out, which is --

LACQUA: I'm shocked.

JOHNSON: -- as the fed is -- yes. Sorry. And as the fed has been hiking rates and the interest rate differential on the 10 years go wider and wider and wider, the dollar has gone down. So I'm just going to throw it out there. Does the dollar go up when the fed starts?

NIELSEN: No. No. No. Your --

(CROSSTALK)

JOHNSON: But Euro dollar has gone up when the fed is hiking. They got this huge interest rate --

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: -- differential, so --

NIELSEN: I don't think that's as powerful as the fiscal expansion. I mean, so --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- we had a -- we have a nice -- my colleague (INAUDIBLE) --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: -- has a great chart on the U.S. budget deficit adjusted for the cyclicals and need (INAUDIBLE) chart --

JOHNSON: The Euro has gone up because of the U.S. twin deficit?

NIELSEN: No, the dollar has gone down, right?

JOHNSON: OK.

NIELSEN: And that's probably the --

JOHNSON: No. No. But its --

NIELSEN: Yes. No. No. No. Because the dollar weakness more than as a Euro spends dollar. That's important too.

LACQUA: That's not how Draghi is feeling it.

NIELSEN: Yes. Yes, yes, exactly and rightly so. I mean look at the trade where the Euro has got up by roughly half of what your dollar has right. So its dollar is dramatic. But --

JOHNSON: The trade (INAUDIBLE) Euro is down because the (INAUDIBLE) hasn't moved or --

NIELSEN: Yes. It's been helping that's right, that's right. I mean, and I mean the other trading partner we have the sterling, right, and then we have the central Europeans and all the rest of it, so its, yes, but there then maybe it's a very big part of the story, right.

LACQUA: All right. This is trade where the Euro, I caught it up in time.

NIELSEN: With --

LACQUA: I'm so happy. There it is. It's there on the left.

NIELSEN: Right.

LACQUA: Between the --

NIELSEN: That's between the Euro Bank.

LACQUA: So that --

NIELSEN: So what's the problem, right?

LACQUA: What do we do from here?

NIELSEN: So that's put to my point is first for the ECB what's the problem, right?

JOHNSON: It's gone sideways. Those on the thin on radio it's gone sideways.

NIELSEN: Yes. So, I think from where does it go from here? I think it will -- we will edge higher. Over this year if I have to -- I mean if I were basically a betting man, I would say maybe 5% or thereabouts. Nothing too dramatic.

JOHNSON: Somebody is already complaining about it now.

(CROSSTALK)

NIELSEN: Yes.

LACQUA: Explain this.

NIELSEN: I mean, yes, they are and yet their export numbers are still growing faster than global trade and global GDP. So they're still getting market shares around the world. But of course it's nicer too -- if you're an exporter to have a weaker currency.

JOHNSON: Who's at the other day one of the ECB --

NIELSEN: And I'll prefer they didn't have, right. I mean --

JOHNSON: Yes. one of the ECB guys the other day was talking about the fact this is as good as it gets for the ECB better much on inflation restore coming through. The growth momentum story's been there, it's been fantastic. It gets harder from here.

NIELSEN: Yes.

JOHNSON: Do you buy that, or do you think the ECB's kind of can coast along for a little bit longer?

NIELSEN: No, I think that -- so, I think we are close to sort of the peak of Eurozone growth, which is not (ph) of 2% although the shop indicators suggest that it could actually move up above 2.5 towards to 3, right? I don't think its going get up there.

So I think we are sort of cruising and maybe hitting off a little bit. Yes. So the ECB, and then if you look a year out, if I'm broadly right on the U.S., the Europe will also have a hit, right. There's no --

JOHNSON: Yes.

NIELSEN: So then you see Euro zone growth drop back to 1.5, 1.7 or thereabout. So from the ECB point of view, yes, you can sort of remove the Q.E. and that -- but you won't get inflation up to 2% for a while.

LACQUA: All right. We could go on for about --

NIELSEN: Yes.

LACQUA: -- 50 miles. OK. All right, Erik Nielsen UniCredit Group Chief Economist back on.

END

urn:contentItem:5TYN-5M91-F0JP-W1N6-00000-00Rich harvest for tech Big Brother2018-12-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 28Rich harvest for tech Big BrotherSupratim Adhikari

The competition watchdog's push to bring Facebook and Google to heel is the first step in injecting a level of control over businesses that play by the rules of a "surveillance" economy.

The fuel of this new economy is consumer data, vast volumes of which are being sucked up and dissected on a daily basis by technology companies.

But policing algorithms is not quite as simple as breaking up cosy cartels and price gouging. That's because the tech giants are not really interested in producing and selling goods, they are not interested in manipulating prices. What they are interested in is our digital footprint.

Tracking that footprint can happen many ways and, until recently, it had all been done with almost no oversight.

The internet browser is the first point of access. It starts picking up data on the sites a user visits frequently through search history, as well as the general configuration of a consumer's device - the operating system, the display resolution, the type of processor.

Most of the data harvesting happens on the website or the app, where "cookies" log the actions of users to build a profile. Littered across the web, these cookies are the building blocks of a digital ID that is available to the highest bidder on the web.

There is another layer of surveillance, where apps on mobile devices collect location information, which is critical for services like Google Maps, online food delivery and catching an Uber.

All this information is collected as part of a user's everyday interaction on the web and once combined with the personal infor-mation that we share on social media sites, like Facebook and Twitter, creates a comprehensive digital profile of an individual.

It's far from an exact science, no one other than the companies know how the algorithms work and how effective they are, but it's a business model that oils the engine of the surveillance economy and lines the coffers of Facebook, Google and Amazon.

It also powers the essential trade-off of privacy for service that underpins the transaction model of the internet - lots of free services on offer as long as there is enough personal data there to be harvested.

There's no argument from the tech companies on that point, but it's a different story when it comes to making the trade-off as clear as possible to its users. "User data helps us serve relevant ads, and these ads help fund our services and make them free for everyone," a Google spokeswoman said.

Google gives users control of how their data is used through the MyAccount website.

In 2017, Australians visited MyAccount.google.com more than 22 million times, the company said.

But it needs to do a lot more to convince regulators, with the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission recommending the companies seek explicit permission from users to collect their data and give consumers more control. According to Telsyte managing director Foad Fadaghi, it will get harder for tech companies to maintain the status quo, especially as the regulatory screws tighten globally. "The US will itself put out privacy principles similar to Europe's General Data Protection Regulation," he said. "And in the future, it doesn't matter what device you use, they will be subject to unified privacy standards." "Every company is pretty much a data company and there is chance that we end up with the companies adopting a user-pay model, or a combined subscription style model, with the ultimate cost imposed on the customer and advertisers." So far the regulatory focus is on software, but it's only a matter of time before the scrutiny extends to hardware companies, including Apple. Kath Blackham, managing director of Australian voice experience agency Versa, says it's the rising tide of smart speakers and voice assistants that are going to be the next flash point.

With more than 1.5 million Australian households set to own a smart speaker (Google Home, Amazon Echo, Apple HomePod) by the end of this year, these devices are another snooping opportunity for big tech.

"People don't fully understand how these things work, and while you have to invoke the voice assistants to wake them up, the devices are always listening passively," Ms Blackham said. There are no clear guidelines on how intently these speakers are listening to conversations, and Ms Blackham said the next generation of these devices, like Facebook's Portal smart display, had screens and cameras."Google and Amazon don't give you any information about what data is captured and how it's captured. We should be able to demand more control off our data and what's happening to it."

urn:contentItem:5YXB-2RY1-JCJY-G2F9-00000-00Rich List 2020: profiles 501-6002020-05-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisRich List 2020: profiles 501-600The Sunday Times

501= BAKIR COLA AND FAMILY Hotels £259m ▲£9m

Cola, 77, owns three London hotels. As well as the four-star Kensington Close, and the five-star Westbury in Mayfair, he most recently added the Hilton London Kensington, bought from Vincent Tchenguiz for £260m in 2018. Cola's holding company paid a £60m dividend in 2015-16. The Kurdish-born hotelier, who fled Iraq when Saddam Hussein came to power, sold Covent Garden's 170-bedroom Kingsway Hall hotel in 2014 for £100m. A strong increase in the assets of his main UK company had initially prompted us to push Cola's wealth up to £269m this year, but the closure of his hotels during the coronavirus crisis leads us to scale that back to just a £9m rise. We take account of other interests in calculating the Monaco resident's fortune.

2019: £250m, 490= 2019: £250m, 490= 501= BILL, TIM AND POLLY GREDLEY AND FAMILY Property and horseracing £259m ▲£18m

Gredley, 87, who grew up in London's bomb-ravaged East End, started property firm Unex. The operation, based near Newmarket, is now largely owned by his children, daughter Polly, 33, and his 34-year-old international showjumper son Tim, who last year married Irish Sky Sports presenter Rachel Wyse at Adare Manor in Limerick, with friends posting pictures on social media under the hashtag #gredwed. As well as a range of commercial premises in Cambridge, the company also owns property in Peterborough and the eye-catching 26-storey Unex Tower in Stratford, east London. The business made £23.8m profit in 2018-19 and is worth its net assets of nearly £243.7m, up £18.6m in a year. These include £3m of art and a £9.5m stable of racehorses, many of which are bred and kept at the family's Stetchworth Park Stud. We add nearly £15m for other interests.

2019: £241m, 504= 2019: £241m, 504= 501= GUY AND JULIA HANDS Finance and hotels £259m ▼£6m

Biting the hand that fed, dealmaker Hands, 60, said in February that the private-equity industry was "not fit for purpose for the world we now live in". After making £300m at Japanese bank Nomura, he set up London-based Terra Firma, investing nearly £15bn since 1996. Guernsey resident Hands and his wife Julia, 60, co-founded a chain of 19 country house hotels, including Ettington Park in Stratford-upon-Avon. Their closure during the coronavirus pandemic is reflected in a cut.

2019: £265m, 470= 2019: £265m, 470= 501= DAVID MABEY AND FAMILY Construction £259m ▲£28m

It is a classic tale of poacher turned gamekeeper. Mabey, 58, once spent eight months in jail because of bribes to Saddam Hussein's Iraqi regime to secure bridge-building contracts. But last year three UK companies were provisionally found guilty of price-fixing of safety equipment - after a tip-off from Mabey's firm, which was one of the trio but escaped punishment as a result of its whistleblowing. His Reading-based industrial and property group made £30.7m profit and saw its assets rise £26.5m to £180.9m in 2017-18.

2019: £231m, 520= 2019: £231m, 520= 505 STEVEN FERGUSON Oil services and gas services £256m ▲£6m

Last year Monaco-based Ferguson, 60, was revealed to be among the wealthy individuals earning a fortune from letting property via Airbnb and Booking.com in Edinburgh, where he owns nearly 30 residences. He set up a business supplying containers for the oil and gas industry in the North Sea at the age of just 16 and it grew into Aberdeenshire's Ferguson Group, bought by Australian giant Brambles for £320m in 2014.

2019: £250m, 490= 2019: £250m, 490= 506 JOEL AND DANNY WYLER Investment £255m ▲£13m

The Wyler brothers run Granaria Holdings, based in The Hague, which was started by their grain trader grandfather in 1912. London-based Joel, 70, gives his nationality at Companies House as Kittitian - a native of St Kitts - while Dutch national Danny, 68, lives in Monaco. The siblings took over in 1982 at the family-controlled group, which listed (EURO)8.4bn assets in the early 2000s and has businesses ranging from nuts and snacks to industrial operations. The pair are partners in London's ACPI Investment Managers, bought by Swiss private bank UBP in 2018, and Danny is a trustee of the Royal Opera House. We agree with Dutch magazine Quote's 2019 rich list on size of their fortune.

2019: £242m, 502= 2019: £242m, 502= 507 OLIVER COOKSON Health supplements £254m ▼£52m

Cookson, 41, is focused on angel investing and property ventures via his OSC Group. He made £58m by selling sports nutrition business Myprotein to the Hut Group in exchange for a stake in the Manchester-based online retailer that we value at £201m. The liquidation of his company Monocore last year leads us to lower his wealth further.

2019: £306m, 423 2019: £306m, 423 508= THE DUKE OF BUCCLEUCH AND FAMILY Land and art £253m ▲£23m

The 10th Duke of Buccleuch and 12th Duke of Queensberry, 66-year-old Richard Scott, stepped down early last year as chairman of his family's estate business, where his elder son Walter, 35, the Earl of Dalkeith, is now vice-chairman. The family's home in Dumfries and Galloway is Drumlanrig Castle, a 17th-century pile with 120 rooms, 17 turrets and four towers that featured in the swashbuckling historical fantasy series

Outlander

- boosting visitor figures considerably. The grounds have also hosted Tough Mudder endurance events and the Galloway country fair.

Buccleuch's estate was built up over about 700 years and includes 575 properties, 189,000 acres of agricultural land and 24,520 acres of forestry. The duke has other estates including Dalkeith, near Edinburgh - the smallest at 2,200 acres. He is enthusiastic about green energy and has converted an abandoned open-cast coal site at Glenmuckloch into an energy park with wind turbines. A further eight turbines planned for the site will provide enough energy for 16,000 homes.

The 9th Duke, who died in 2007, left £320m in his will, bequeathing art treasures - among them, works by Gainsborough, Rembrandt and a number of Dutch masters - and antique furniture valued at £224m. But we cut that back to £150m, taking account of any likely tax bill. Parent company MDS Estates made £31.7m profit in 2017-18, a rise largely due to a reappraisal of the family's land and other holdings, while its assets increased by £23.2m to £166.9m.

2019: £230m, 522= 2019: £230m, 522= 508= GORDON SANDERS AND FAMILY Care homes £253m ▲£3m

Sanders, 74, owns Essex-based Runwood Homes, which provides nursing and residential care across 72 UK sites. The operation has been criticised by regulators in relation to care standards and in 2018 was investigated by local police over alleged neglect of residents. He denied any wrongdoing and the case was dropped with no charges being brought. Profits fell more than 70% to £4.6m in 2017-18, but this was mainly due to directors' remuneration of £20.1m. Despite the operation's woes, a £5.3m dividend justifies raising Sanders.

2019: £250m, 490= 2019: £250m, 490= 510 GARY WIDDOWSON Scrap metal and property £251m ▲£10m

Norfolk's 2,000-acre Kelling estate, featuring a grade II listed arts and crafts-style mansion, a collection of traditional cottages and holiday lets and a country-house hotel, is owned by Widdowson, 62. He made his money in recycling, selling his London-based business in 2006 for £120m. The former international showjumper and his wife Beverley became the first owners to have two horses selected for the same Olympic team, at the Rio Games in 2016.

2019: £241m, 504= 2019: £241m, 504= 511= VISCOUNT ASTOR AND FAMILY Property and retailing £250m ▼£8m

Captivated by the majesty of Scottish wildlife, a-hunting David Cameron did go on his stepfather-in-law Astor's sprawling Jura island estate last year. Though well beyond shooting distance of Westminster, upon dispatching a magnificent stag, the former Tory leader named it "Boris". He socked it to his back-stabbers on another hunt the year before, too, when a deer he called "Gove" became target practice. Whether the heads were stuffed and mounted is open to speculation. The 20,000-acre Tarbert estate on Jura is just one of the Astors' properties.

Their 17th-century Ginge Manor in Oxfordshire is near where Cameron married Samantha, daughter of Lady Annabel, 71, and her first husband Sir Reginald Sheffield. She wed the 4th Viscount William, 68, grandson of Nancy Astor, the first female MP, in 1976. Annabel netted £7m from the £40m sale of her Oka furniture outfit in 2018. The family's Sableknight property company developed the former Times Newspapers headquarters in London in the late 1990s. It made a £6.8m loss in 2018, when net assets fell by £9.8m to £194.9m, a decline blamed on weak equity markets, but the family took a £2.5m dividend.

2019: £258m, 483 2019: £258m, 483 511= DAVID BLOOD Finance £250m ▼£100m

Blood, 61, and former US vice-president Al Gore founded Generation Investment Management, which focuses on sustainable capitalism and has poured funds into online supermarket Ocado and work management platform Asana. Profits fell slightly to £245.8m at the London-based operation, where there are $23bn assets under management. In 2018 it paid out £43.2m to one member, believed to be Blood, who has cut his stake in the business. Philanthropy also leads us to trim his wealth.

2019: £350m, 374= 2019: £350m, 374= 511= GRAEME AND YVONNE BROOKS Aviation £250m No change

Founded in 1985 by Brooks, 66, and based near Gatwick, Avtrade provides commercial aircraft components and other support services to more than 800 airlines - dispatching 5,000 parts a month to 120 countries. The company, which also handles aircraft leasing, sales and repairs, has operations in Dubai, Singapore, Moscow, Miami and Guangzhou, China. In 2017-18 profits climbed by nearly 27% to £30.3m on £179.4m turnover and with £101.2m assets, plus a strong balance sheet, the outfit is worth £250m. It is owned by Brooks and his 64-year-old wife Yvonne, a fellow director.

2019: £250m, 490= 2019: £250m, 490= 511= RODGER DUDDING Property £250m No change

Dudding is better known as "Mr Lock-Up" and Britain's "king of lugs", or lock-up garages, owning more than 14,000 such units. He also looks after 400 supercars and classic vehicles for the wealthy at his secret depots in north London, while at the same time building up quite a collection himself, with 470 models worth around £100m. Dudding, 82, has cannily developed good links with the film industry, picking up fees for his vehicles' appearances in

Downton Abbey

,

Luther

and a host of other television series and movies. There is even a film studio at his new £3.5m car storage facility. The son of a naval officer, he took an engineering apprenticeship from 1954-59 at Chatham dockyard, then after his maritime career was cut short by injury, Dudding went into business.

In 1970 he launched London-based Lonsto, which makes and installs ticketing and queue management systems for clients including banks, health centres, airports and supermarkets. The lock-up garages operation came about by accident in 1975, when a friend suggested he should buy a block of lugs in south London. Realising the garage business was fragmented and not regarded seriously, Dudding single-handedly changed all that. He also owns several hundred retail units, more than 700 flats and has a range of commercial mews properties.

He is building homes on top of some of his garages. "My strategy is to buy for long-term investment or rental income," he said, "then look at that block of garages for development opportunities down the line, whether it's a pair of semi-detached houses, a small block of flats or a mews-style development."

2019: £250m, 490= 2019: £250m, 490= 511= MICHAEL GOOCH AND FAMILY Finance £250m No change

The acquisition of New York-based GFI Partners by BGC Partners in 2016 netted Gooch, 61, and his family £185m. The Essex-born former accountant set up the Wall Street inter-dealer broker, a specialist in government bond options, after he was made redundant in 1987. He floated the operation in 2005 and stayed on as chief executive until 2013. The proceeds of the GFI sale and other pay over the years should still put his fortune at £250m - not bad for someone who got into foreign exchange trading after a chat with someone he met over a pint. His son Mickey is a comedian.

2019: £250m, 490= 2019: £250m, 490= 511= MICHAEL GREGORY Engineering services £250m No change

Gregory, 75, built up his tool-retailing business Cromwell into a chain with more than 50 stores, before selling the Leicester-based hardware operation in 2015 to New York-listed Grainger for £310m. He is a steam-train enthusiast, having paid for the restoration of numerous engines and carriages.

2019: £250m, 490= 2019: £250m, 490= 511= PADDY MCKILLEN AND FAMILY Property £250m ▲£46m

Belfast-born property tycoon McKillen, 64, is teaming up with U2 singer Bono to build a "cultural and wellness hub" in Dublin, transforming the site of the Tramyard cafe into a leisure and co-working space. McKillen's son Paddy Jr, 47, may also be in line for a return of up to 50% on his (EURO)30m investment in a prime Dublin residential site.

2019: £204m, 596= 2019: £204m, 596= 518= JOHN APTHORP AND FAMILY Food and wine £248m ▲£7m

Last year Majestic Wine was acquired for £95m, delivering a windfall for Apthorp, 85, whose family owned 15% of the shares. The Watford-based operation owned online retailer Naked Wines, which subsequently floated, and with many customers wanting home deliveries of wine during the coronavirus lockdown, its share price rose, valuing the family's stake at £26.3m. Apthorp previously sold his Bejam frozen-food firm to Iceland, making £70m, as well as offloading £38m of Majestic stock in two tranches.

2019: £241m, 504= 2019: £241m, 504= 518= STEVEN LAMPRELL Oil services £248m ▼£54m

Lamprell is the founder of one of the largest oil and gas services companies in the Gulf and his Dubai-based operation has now diversified into renewable energy. Founded in 1976, the business that bears his name floated in 2006 and is now worth just £46.3m, a drop of £162.5m on the previous year. The 69-year-old entrepreneur made £230m at its listing and retains a stake valued at £15.3m, a £54m fall in 12 months, leading us to clip his fortune in line with the outfit's sinking share price. He owns Suffolk's Chadacre estate, mentioned in the Domesday Book, and was so determined to acquire the property that he paid £16m - £6m over the asking price. He owns racehorses and plays polo.

2019: £302m, 428 2019: £302m, 428 518= ALEX LANGSAM Hotels £248m ▼£12m

Last year Britannia group was named by Which? as Britain's worst hotel chain for the seventh year running, and did itself no favours during the Covid-19 outbreak when it sacked and evicted staff from its Aviemore hotel, later claiming it was an "administrative error". Langsam, 81, studied economics at Aberystwyth University because, he once joked, it was the only place that would let him do so after he failed his maths O-level. He owns at least half of his Manchester-based operation, which we cut in value to £176.8m after the coronavirus shutdown.

2019: £260m, 478= 2019: £260m, 478= 521 LORD BROWNLOW Business services £247m ▲£7m

Brownlow, 56, who with his company Huntswood has given more than £3m to the Tory party, last year received a peerage. He has also shown his munificence to Samantha Cameron, with his finance firm Havisham Assets investing £2.5m in the former prime minister's wife's fashion brand Cefinn. The Newcastle Polytechnic economics graduate and one-time policeman co-founded Reading-based Huntswood in 1996, transforming the recruitment consultancy into a regulatory and compliance specialist. He owns almost 60% of the £350m operation, a holding worth £210m, and should have received nearly £14m dividends in 2017-18, when profits recovered to £28.1m. He gave £637,000 to the Tories ahead of last December's general election.

2019: £240m, 507= 2019: £240m, 507= 522 TED FORT Engineering £245m ▲£5m

Two redundant machines bought by Fort, 83, at a Ministry of Defence auction in 1967 for just £550 laid the foundations for Burnley-based Fort Vale. Today his business is a world leader in making precision valves, fittings and other equipment for tank containers and tankers, for the oil and nuclear industries. Profits fell to £16m in 2018-19, but this number would have been significantly higher were it not for large executive pay, with £7m pocketed by the highest-earning director, believed to be Fort.

His wealth is bolstered by £51m of property and personal assets as well as a further £55m in cash and other investments. He owns seven commercial buildings, as well as homes in Montserrat, Antibes, Lancashire and the New Forest. Fort says he was 40 years old when he came to believe that it was his "responsibility" to create wealth. "You need a wealth-creating section of society to help pay for infrastructure for it to function and the resources for it to progress," he wrote in his autobiography,

An Engineer of Coincidence

.

2019: £240m, 507= 2019: £240m, 507= 523 SIR PAUL AND LADY SMITH Fashion £242m ▼£8m

The "godfather of British style" has been turning his business around after some difficult years, but the coronavirus crisis forced the retailer to close all its shops and suspend online sales, leading us to trim our valuation of the business from £275m to £260m. Nottingham-born Smith, 73, has a £137.8m stake and we add a majority share in a property firm part-owned by his wife Pauline, 79, with almost £62m assets, up £4m in a year.

2019: £250m, 490= 2019: £250m, 490= 524 PAUL NEWEY Finance £241m ▼£1m

Known in card-playing circles as "Top dollar man", Newey, 51, has raked in almost $5.4m at the poker table over the years. Last September he won his first big live tournament, picking up £156,400 at the inaugural British Poker Open, held at Aspers casino in Stratford, east London. But his largest winnings came in 2006 from the £200m sale of Ocean Finance, the Tamworth-based subprime lender he set up in 1991 after he was made redundant. In 2010 he launched New Wave Ventures, funding start-ups and other businesses looking to grow, and owns half of the investment vehicle, which saw its assets fall by £2.6m to £23m in 2018-19. A YouTube video of Newey scooping £1.3m at a $5,000-a-spin slot machine in Las Vegas has been watched more than two million times. The footage shows him pointing to the display when it stands at $1m and simply saying: "Lovely".

2019: £242m, 502= 2019: £242m, 502= 525 DAVID REISS AND FAMILY Fashion £240m No change

Reiss, 77 last Friday, started out in 1971 selling menswear in the City, only moving into women's clothing 29 years later. His brand was boosted by pictures of the future Duchess of Cambridge in one of its dresses, and private equity group Warburg Pincus took a majority holding in 2016, valuing the operation at £230m. Although the Covid-19 outbreak closed his shops, online sales continued, and with many of his well-heeled customers able to weather the financial impact of the pandemic, we leave Reiss's fortune unchanged.

2019: £240m, 507= 2019: £240m, 507= 526= DUNCAN SINCLAIR AND FAMILY Property £238m ▲£5m

Established by brothers Frank and Irving Sinclair in 1937, London's Mountview Estates saw steady profits of £34.6m in 2018-19. Accountant Sinclair, 72, succeeded his father Irving as chairman in 1990 and is the operation's chief executive. The family's stake is worth £204.8m, down £200,000 in a year, and there should have been dividends of almost £8m paid in the latest accounts.

2019: £233m, 519 2019: £233m, 519 526= MARK WATKIN JONES AND FAMILY Construction £238m ▼£62m

Last November the Watkin Jones family sold shares worth £52.5m in its eponymous building firm, which dates back to 1791 and has become a leading UK provider of student accommodation. Since 1999 the Gwynedd-based operation has completed 123 developments with 41,000 beds, as well as managing 18,000 beds and build-to-rent apartments. It has also put up 2,500 homes via 80 developments, but the outfit's shares plunged when the coronavirus crisis gathered pace and it is now worth £388.7m.

Watkin Jones, 51, who served as group chief executive until last January, started helping out at the business aged 12 and by 17 was running construction sites. When he took charge of the company a few years later it had a turnover of just £17m - in 2018-19 its revenue was £374.8m. He sold a holding worth £7.4m in 2018 to fund a divorce settlement and the family retains a £70m interest. It offloaded £46m of stock in the float and the latest accounts of three separate ventures showed £56.3m combined assets.

2019: £300m, 431= 2019: £300m, 431= 528 PIERRE LAGRANGE Hedge fund and fashion £237m ▼£2m

The

Kingsman

spy capers were apparently inspired by Huntsman, the bespoke Savile Row tailor Lagrange has owned since 2013. The imagination of film director Matthew Vaughn was stoked after a visit to the 171-year-old business, which has provided clothing for

Downton Abbey

and the movie

Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy

. Despite its famous clientele, Huntsman has struggled recently, with its debts rising by £2.2m to £10.4m in 2018. Profits fell slightly to £17.9m on more than £255m turnover in 2018, though assets grew £15.3m to £158.2m. Despite the lower earnings, rising sales and higher equity mean we still value the business at £210m, and add £3m other wealth to McCann, 63, and clan.

2019: £212m, 564= 2019: £212m, 564= 576 CHAI PATEL Healthcare £212m ▲£58m

Born in Uganda to Indian parents, Patel, 64, later qualified as a doctor before quitting the NHS for the City. He made £45m from the sale of Priory Healthcare and £30m from the acquisition of Darlington-based care home operation HC-One. He owns 90% of social care specialist Court Cavendish, which showed £91.9m assets in 2018-19, up £51.7m in a year.

2019: £154m, 768= 2019: £154m, 768= 577= MARTIN AINSCOUGH AND FAMILY Construction equipment £210m No change

Ainscough, 67, has spent £20m developing the world's first inland surfing lagoon in Snowdonia - even though he had not set foot on a surfboard before launching the project - with a Hilton hotel being built at the site and climbing attraction Adrenaline Indoors opening in summer. He made his fortune founding and building up his Wigan-based crane hire business, before selling it to the management for £255m in 2007. Today he is heavily involved in property through Ainscough Strategic Land, which has completed developments in Cheshire, Lancashire and elsewhere.

2019: £210m, 569= 2019: £210m, 569= 577= ASSEM ALLAM AND FAMILY Generators £210m No change

Egyptian-born Allam, 80, and his family own the Championship football team Hull City, who earlier this year were fighting to avoid relegation to League One before the season was suspended. Allamhouse, where his various UK interests are held, turned in £4.3m profit on £124.7m sales in 2018. His sustained philanthropy over the past 12 months has included a £3.5m donation to the NHS in Hull for robotic surgery, diabetes, digestive disease and laser-eye operation facilities.

2019: £210m, 569= 2019: £210m, 569= 577= RICHARD BEATTIE Loyalty cards and yachts £210m No change

Hong Kong-based Beattie, 69, a former WH Smith shop assistant, founded TCC, a world leader in loyalty card schemes, which operates in more than 70 countries, employs 600 staff and has clients including Tesco, Argos and Selfridges. He remains the majority shareholder in TCC, which has acquired companies making digital gaming campaigns and using spending data to provide business intelligence on customers.

2019: £210m, 569= 2019: £210m, 569= 577= KOOLESH SHAH AND FAMILY Hotels £210m ▲£18m

Since 1988 Shah, 64, has built a collection of hotels via his London Town Group. His 35-year-old son Nikhil, a Cambridge maths graduate, has joined him on the board, bringing expertise in digital operations such as a hotel booking platform and S-Cube, an oil and gas exploration data service used to help discover oil in Guyana last year. Shah's expanding hospitality empire saw assets rise by nearly £20m to £131m in 2018 but the Covid-19 pandemic has hit hoteliers hard, removing £10m from his valuation.

2019: £192m, 637= 2019: £192m, 637= 577= CATHERINE ZETA-JONES AND MICHAEL DOUGLAS Films £210m No change

Zeta-Jones revealed a personal project during the coronavirus lockdown: to learn to play pool. Her teacher is her actor husband Douglas, with whom she shares a birthday, last September celebrating her 50th and his 75th. In February the Hollywood couple led mourners at the funeral of Douglas's 103-year-old father Kirk, but can look forward to a happier occasion in November to mark their 20th wedding anniversary, brushing aside a short estrangement.

Movie veteran Kirk left most of his £61m fortune to charity but Swansea-born Zeta-Jones and Douglas have made their own mark on the industry, appearing in films grossing £5.2bn worldwide in their heyday. From her TV breakthrough in

The Darling Buds of May

, Zeta-Jones starred in Hollywood hits including

Entrapment

,

The Mask of Zorro

and

Ocean's Twelve

- most recently taking the title role in

Cocaine Godmother

, the TV life story of a Colombian drug lord.

She has also landed lucrative advertising contracts with Elizabeth Arden, T-Mobile, Alfa Romeo and Di Modolo jewellery, last year joining her daughter Carys, 17, to promote Fendi bags. Douglas, whose defining roles included

Wall Street

and

Basic Instinct

, and Zeta-Jones have an extensive property portfolio, and last year they downsized their country house just north of New York, selling one mansion for £16.5m and buying another nearby for £3.5m; their new home, on 12 acres overlooking the Hudson River, has 12 bathrooms, 8 bedrooms, a 42ft indoor pool and a library with temperature-controlled bookshelves.

They also have a £5m apartment beside New York's Central Park. They take Instagram-able holidays at their ski retreat in Canada and are reportedly trying to sell their four-bedroom holiday home in Bermuda. We put Zeta-Jones's share of film revenues and other wealth at £80m and with no blockbusters on the horizon, pin the couple's fortune.

2019: £210m, 569= 2019: £210m, 569= 582 HEINRICH FELDMAN AND FAMILY Property £209m No change

No 1 Poultry, the landmark City building once referred to by Prince Charles as a "1930s wireless set", was sold for £110m in 2014 by Feldman. His main holding company Inremco 26, showed £53.3m assets in 2017-18 and we see more than £160m in other family operations belonging to Feldman, 84, and his wife Dwora, 83 on Wednesday.

2019: £209m, 583= 2019: £209m, 583= 583= KEITH BRADSHAW AND FAMILY Car sales and care homes £208m ▼£11m

Bradshaw returned from west Africa in the 1970s with some savings and co-founded the Takare nursing-home operation, later merging it with the Care First group, bought by Bupa in a £273m deal that valued his stake at £21m. The Birmingham-born businessman also helped set up the £250m Listers car dealership group, which made £13.8m profit on £1.23m sales in 2018-19, although the coronavirus crisis has since largely stopped the motor trade in its tracks.

His family owns almost 50% of the £225m Stratford-upon-Avon-based operation, with the rest belonging to Terry Lister (qv). The Bradshaws should also have received half of the £8m dividends paid out in the latest accounts. Bradshaw, 76, has a flourishing musical instrument distributor and a large property portfolio held by his Nurton Developments.

2019: £219m, 553 2019: £219m, 553 583= SIR CHRIS EVANS Biotechnology £208m No change

Evans writes with confidence that science will save us from the coronavirus and has urged governments to speed up drug testing by relaxing some regulations. He has floated 20 businesses on the stock market worth a combined £1.33bn over the years since starting his first biotechnology company in Cambridge at the age of 28. The 62-year-old Welshman, born and raised in Port Talbot where his father was a steelworker, had to sell the cottage he lived in with his wife Anne to raise the cash for his first venture, Enzymatix. His breakthrough came after he went on to buy up small biotech firms from a troubled parent company. Since 1996 he has been investing in pioneering start-ups. Property and other deals shore up his wealth.

2019: £208m, 585= 2019: £208m, 585= 583= STEPHEN AND PAUL HARRISON Construction £208m ▲£41m

The Harrisons, brothers Stephen, 50, and Paul, 48, co-founded and run Leeds housebuilder Harron Homes, which since 1992 has grown beyond its West Yorkshire roots to construct properties in the northwest, north Wales and the Midlands. In 2019 profits increased by 28% to £23.1m on higher sales of £164.7m sales and with assets rising to £104.8m, the operation is now worth £200m. We add £8m for dividends and other holdings to the siblings, who own all of the operation.

2019: £167m, 712= 2019: £167m, 712= 583= ANWAR AND YAKUB PATEL Pharmacies £208m ▲£10m

The sale of 111 chemists in 2005 netted £130m for the Patels - Anwar, 65, and brother Yakub, 66 - who kept hold of 30 pharmacies and continue to expand. Gorgemead, the Bolton-based holding company of their Cohens Chemist chain, showed £44.6m assets in 2017-18, a figure depressed by a £22m loan to Anwar. The siblings also operate Prinwest, a separate pharmaceutical wholesaler worth £100m.

2019: £198m, 627 2019: £198m, 627 583= SUSAN TOBBELL Fuel distribution £208m ▲£8m

Tobbell, 68, and business partner Graham Peacock (qv) have begun building a second petrol-station chain. The pair sold their Epping-based MRH (GB) network of 450 sites for £1bn in 2016, with Tobbell, its finance director, picking up about £220m for her 22% stake. Their new operation, TG Convenience Stores, already has more than 20 outlets and early last year signed a deal to sell fuel under the Texaco brand. SGN, its parent, generated £3.2m profit on £34m turnover in 2018-19, valuing the chain at £20m and her holding at £7.6m. She also has a £1.7m interest in AIM-listed bus service provider Rotala and has been a long-term supporter of the Liberal Democrats, advising the party on commercial issues for several years.

2019: £200m, 606= 2019: £200m, 606= 588 EDWARD McALPINE AND FAMILY Construction £207m ▲£5m

McAlpine, 41, is the fifth generation to lead family construction business Sir Robert McAlpine, which is currently developing Channel 4's new hub in Leeds. The broadcaster is moving into the Majestic, a grade II listed former cinema considered to be one of the city centre's most famous buildings. Hemel Hempstead-based parent company Newarthill only made £660,000 profit in 2018, but assets rose by £5.4m to just under £77.3m. McAlpine had a famous stepmother in Angharad Rees, the late actress who starred as Demelza in the original series of

Poldark

.

2019: £202m, 602= 2019: £202m, 602= 589= MICHAEL FLATLEY Entertainment £206m ▲£2m

Flatley's

Riverdance

was partway through a 25th-anniversary UK tour before Covid-19 shut down venues. The international appeal of the Chicago-born former construction worker's terpsichorean extravaganzas remains sprightly, with his

Lord of the Dance

playing six nights at the Shanghai Grand Theatre in January, followed by European dates in February and March.

Although the 61-year-old Irish-American star has retired from the stage, he still produces and choreographs his shows, which over the years have sold more than 15 million DVDs. He once even turned to creating art by tap dancing on canvas - works that typically sold for £17,000 each. Much of the proceeds of his ventures have been ploughed into property or invested with his friend Warren Buffett.

Flatley's principal residence is a £10m hilltop home in Monaco and he also has a £20m beach house in Barbados. Other assets include an art and jewellery collection worth more than £3m. His fortune has been put as high as £421m, but we are more cautious in our valuation, raising him by £2m this year. He still owns Castlehyde, the 18th-century Cork mansion he bought in 2001 and spent three years renovating at a cost of (EURO)27m. The property was on the market at (EURO)20m for more than two years without attracting a buyer, leading to the price being dropped to (EURO)12.5m, and it was reported last year that the house was no longer up for sale.

2019: £204m, 596= 2019: £204m, 596= 589= SIR COLIN GILTRAP Car sales £206m ▼£3m

Eighty-year-old Giltrap opened his first dealership, Auckland's Monaco Motors, while still in his mid-twenties in 1966, acquiring the Porsche distribution rights for New Zealand eight years later. The Kiwi later snapped up franchises for Lamborghini, Aston Martin, Mercedes and Jaguar and by the 1970s had added British operations such as Chelsea Mercedes. He also took a stake in Malaya Group before it became HR Owen, a leading UK luxury car dealer. Over the years, Giltrap has poured millions into motor sport, founding and funding the New Zealand team in the now defunct A1 Grand Prix series. His Giltrap Group is still his homeland's biggest car dealer and he owns 67% of the business, while his sons Michael and Richard, who run the outfit, have smaller holdings. We agree with the Kiwi National Business Review's 2019 rich list on the wealth of Giltrap, who divides his time between London and Auckland and was knighted in 2012 for services to motor sport and philanthropy.

2019: £209m, 583= 2019: £209m, 583= 589= FRANK HESTER Software £206m ▲£46m

In his youth Hester, 54, wrote a computer program for his mother that allowed her to manage the payroll at the family business in about 10 minutes, rather than the usual two days. He founded TPP - the Phoenix Partnership - supplying patient-records software to more than 7,000 NHS organisations, including at least 2,600 GP practices, and the Leeds-based operation is worth £200m.

2019: £160m, 731= 2019: £160m, 731= 589= DAVID ROBERTS AND FAMILY Property and art £206m ▼£9m

Over more than 30 years Roberts, 63, has overseen £3bn of property transactions. He started Mayfair operation Edinburgh House, specialising in shopping centres, and the business had £52.6m assets in 2018. He co-owns German property manager Estama, which has at least (EURO)4bn assets under its wing. He is best known for his David Roberts Art Foundation, which is involved in art projects nationwide.

2019: £215m, 556= 2019: £215m, 556= 593= LORD ARCHER Novels £205m ▲£5m

Archer had a big 80th birthday bash planned last month before the coronavirus spoilt the party. He has also missed out on meeting his second granddaughter, who was born after the epidemic struck. The former Tory MP, who was once jailed for perjury, has said one of the few joys of lockdown is having time to write.

He has lost none of his ambition or energy as he enters his ninth decade, and gets up at 6am every day to write for eight hours at his home in Grantchester, near Cambridge, where he is working on a projected series of eight books tracing the rise of fictional London detective William Warwick. The first,

Nothing Ventured

, was published in September by Macmillan, and the second,

Hidden in Plain Sight

, in March. The series follows Archer's seven

Clifton Chronicles

books, which sold more than a million copies in the UK and almost 10 million globally.

Archer quit parliament in 1974 to write his first novel,

Not a Penny More, Not a Penny Less

, after losing his fortune in a fraudulent investment scheme. Since then he has sold 275 million books, providing him with the funds to assemble an art collection worth £100m and buy homes in London, Cambridgeshire and Mallorca.

Last year he split from his long-term literary agents, Curtis Brown, and in January he reportedly filed legal documents with the High Court in a move to sue the agency for £500,000 in unpaid royalties. The agency denies his claims.

2019: £200m, 606= 2019: £200m, 606= 593= GAVYN DAVIES AND BARONESS NYE Finance £205m No change

Former BBC chairman Davies, 69, had a Goldman Sachs stake thought to be worth £87.5m at its 1999 float. His Fulcrum asset manager had a leaner 2018, with profits falling below £7m and equity down to £10.2m. Meanwhile, his London-based Active Partners investment operation, which has interests in businesses including Leon and Honest Burgers, raised £100m of additional funding earlier this year. He is married to Nye, 65, Gordon Brown's former diary secretary.

2019: £205m, 587= 2019: £205m, 587= 593= WILLIAM DE WINTON Hedge fund £205m No change

De Winton, 56, was a managing director at Morgan Stanley before joining Mayfair-based hedge fund Lansdowne Partners, where he ran its Global Financials vehicle until he stepped down in 2015. Although a retired partner, he would have picked up a share of the £90.7m profits made by the business in 2018-19. In 2007 the US Trader Monthly magazine's list of top 100 highest-paid hedge fund stars put his income at between $100m and $150m, and we see three stakes worth £730,000 in public companies owned personally by de Winton. He is a member of the Royal Academy of Music's governing body and supports a variety of musical organisations, including the Wigmore Hall and London Philharmonic Orchestra. De Winton donated £10,000 to Full Fact, which bills itself as the "UK's independent fact-check charity".

2019: £205m, 587= 2019: £205m, 587= 593= SIR PETER HARRISON AND FAMILY Computers £205m No change

In 1979 Harrison, 83, bought Chernikeeff, a sinking marine instruments firm, for the princely sum of £133,000 and 20 years later sold the business, which he grew into the UK's largest privately owned computer network integration services company, in two tranches for £300m. Since then his eponymous foundation has given away nearly £45.4m over 21 years. A passionate sailor, he once sponsored and led a British challenge to the America's Cup and is a vice-president of Chelsea football club along with Joe Hemani (qv).

2019: £205m, 587= 2019: £205m, 587= 593= SIR JONATHAN IVE Computers £205m ▲£13m

Ive, 53, left Apple last summer after 27 years during which he created a succession of coveted devices including the iMac, iPhone and iPad, establishing himself as the leading industrial designer of the tech era. His new California-based venture, LoveFrom, will focus on wearable technology and healthcare products for Apple and other clients. Its name was inspired by a team talk given by the Apple founder, Steve Jobs, who said that "if you make something with love and care, you are expressing your gratitude to humanity".

Chingford-born Ive, known as "Jony", studied at the former Newcastle Polytechnic and was working for a London company called Tangerine when Apple recruited him in 1992. The company was going through a sticky patch when he was promoted four years later to head its design studio, and he played an integral role in its transformation into the world's first trillion-dollar company by the time he left.

Now holding dual nationality and with more than 5,000 patents to his name, Ive has been showered with honours on both sides of the Atlantic. He was knighted in 2012, had his portrait by acclaimed German photographer Andreas Gursky hung in the National Portrait Gallery last October, and is halfway through a five-year term as chancellor of the Royal College of Art in London.

Although Ive's pay and shareholding at Apple have not been disclosed, its boss Tim Cook received a combined £203.9m in 2018 and 2019. Ive has a £10m San Francisco home, where he lives with his wife, historian Heather Pegg. The couple, who have twin sons, were at school together.

2019: £192m, 637= 2019: £192m, 637= 593= MAYANK PATEL Foreign exchange £205m No change

The son of an Indian businessman who fled Uganda to escape Idi Amin's regime, Patel, 52, started London-based foreign exchange operation Currencies Direct with £8,500 savings, selling it for more than £200m to a private equity firm and retaining a significant minority interest. He now has a role at Birmingham University advising aspiring entrepreneurs and runs private investment company Azibo Group.

2019: £205m, 587= 2019: £205m, 587= 599 ROBERT JELLEY AND FAMILY Construction £204m ▲£12m

The government's Help to Buy scheme has been crucial to the recent success of Jelson Homes, accounting for nearly half of the Leicester housebuilder's sales in 2018-19. Jelley, 64, is the fifth generation of his family to run the business, which owns property worth £107.1m and showed £178.2m assets, a £11.6m rise in a year. Three other property operations have £17.7m combined equity.

2019: £192m, 637= 2019: £192m, 637= 600 SIR JOHN MACTAGGART AND FAMILY Property £203m ▲£3m

Western Heritable, the family property group chaired by Mactaggart, 69, and founded by his great-grandfather, also Sir John, owns a commercial portfolio mostly in London and New York, and over the years has developed more than 2 million sq ft of office, retail and hotel space, as well as 8,000 residential units. Its two main operations - Mactaggart Heritable and Mactaggart Hotel Holdings - showed £187.9m assets in 2018.

urn:contentItem:5VN8-TY11-DXVP-V1XV-00000-00Rich Lowery: Don't break up Big Tech2019-03-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:55ZLexisNexisNVDAILYRich Lowery: Don't break up Big TechRich Lowry

The worst ideas in Washington are often bipartisan. Big Tech is about to learn this lesson, if it hasn't already.

Elizabeth Warren is out with a headline-grabbing proposal to break up Big Tech companies, the sort of overly ambitious government plan that once would have engendered knee-jerk Republican opposition. Not anymore. Who says we all can't get along?

When the senator tweeted her (understandable) objection that Facebook had taken down her ads attacking Facebook and other tech companies, Ted Cruz agreed that the companies have too much power.

Tech is caught in a right-left pincer. Conservatives don't like these companies because they are owned and operated by sanctimonious Silicon Valley liberals subject to the worst sort of groupthink. Progressives don't like them because they are colossal profit-making enterprises.

That's why there is some chance Washington might get together and, along the lines Warren proposes, effectively outlaw the business models of some of the most successful and iconic American companies.

Warren's idea to cleave off the platforms of the tech companies and have them run as "platform utilities" separate from the rest of their business is unworkable and is justified by a series of errors and misjudgments.

It's not true, as Warren asserts, that the antitrust suit against Microsoft in the 1990s opened up the space for Google and Facebook to thrive. Microsoft never got the internet and left the space open for Google and Facebook all by itself, as often happens with a large incumbent wedded to its business model.

She charges that the tech companies use mergers to limit competition and cites Facebook's acquisition of WhatsApp. It's hard to discern the harm here. When the social network bought it, WhatsApp was available for a fee. Now it's free, and more people use it than ever. What's the problem?

She calls out Google for allegedly killing off its competitors by burying them in its searches. It's not obvious that Google actually does this, although its search business inherently involves constantly making choices to try to best serve what people want to see. No government regulator is going to improve Google's searches, or is qualified to even try.

Warren's proposal is obviously formulated without taking any account of the interests of consumers, who are the ones who made the tech companies so large.

Why does Google provide for free a tool without which it's impossible to imagine contemporary life? Because it can monetize it with advertising. Without the advertising, which Warren insists should be a separate business, Google has no incentive to devote engineers to improving its search engine.

By the same token, no one will welcome iPhones that no longer come with or sell Apple apps. And would people really appreciate having to go to two different Amazons, one just a platform, one selling Amazon products?

This is all silly, as are the mergers that Warren pledges to reverse, including Amazon's acquisition of Whole Foods. Amazon doesn't have anything close to a monopoly in food retail. Rather than taking over the sector, it's spurring investment and innovation. The nation's largest supermarket chain, Kroger, was slated to increase its spending on investment 200 percent in 2018.

The tech giants aren't stand-pat companies. Amazon alone spent more than $22 billion on investment in 2017. The development of autonomous vehicles, artificial intelligence and voice recognition wouldn't be nearly as advanced if it weren't for the research of the tech companies. The behemoth of yesteryear, General Electric, isn't making these investments.

None of this is to deny genuine concerns about tech companies. They need rules for content that honor the spirit of the First Amendment, and perhaps there should be tighter regulations around privacy. But any real offenses should be addressed with fixes directed at specific conduct, rather than with a massive politically imposed reorganization.

That's a very bad idea, and if you had any doubt, watch it get a respectful hearing from both sides in Washington.
